questions.text:
A 50-year-old cirrhotic patient has been posted for a laparotomy procedure. He has encephalopathy and severe ascites. His pre-operative workup results are given below. According to the Child-Turcotte-Pugh scoring system, which class would the patient fall into?

Serum bilirubin: 3.2 mg/dl
Serum albumin: 2.4 g/dl
Prothrombin time: increased by 7 seconds
INR: 2.5
questions.solution:
The Child-Turcotte-Pugh class for the patient described is Class C.

The points for:

  • Serum bilirubin of 3.2mg/dl: 3
  • Serum albumin of 2.4g/dl: 3
  • INR of 2.5: 3
  • Uncontrolled encephalopathy: 3
  • Uncontrolled ascites: 3

Therefore the Child-Turcotte-Pugh class for the total points (3+3+3+3+3)= 15 is Class C.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male came to the casualty with a history of intake of antipsychotics for 4 days. He presents with grimacing, abnormal posturing, and increased tone in the muscles with a flexed neck. Which of the following is the best drug in the management of this case?
questions.solution:
The patient has developed acute muscular dystonia. Benztropine can be used for the management of acute dystonia.

Acute dystonia is an extrapyramidal side effect of antipsychotics that occurs within 1-5 days of intake. It is characterized by spasms of the muscles of the tongue, face, neck, and back.

questions.text: A 14-month-old baby was brought with complaints of continuous watering from the eyes,  present since birth. Antibiotic eye drops and frequent massaging to express the contents of the nasolacrimal duct did not show much improvement. Which of the following would be the next best step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of chronic dacryocystitis and the next best step in the management of this patient is the probing of the nasolacrimal duct under anesthesia.

Dacryocystitis is the inflammation of the lacrimal sac. It generally affects infants and adults, most commonly females over 40 years of age. Congenital dacryocystitis is almost always chronic, while acquired dacryocystitis may be acute or chronic.

Congenital dacryocystitis is due to incomplete canalization of the lacrimal system, most often at the valve of Hasner. In newborns, antibiotic drops and frequent massaging to express the contents of the nasolacrimal duct and sac clear out most infections. However, if the symptoms persist beyond a year without improvement, probing of the nasolacrimal duct under anesthesia is advised. Balloon dilatation of the duct or placement of a silicone tube can be done after localizing the level of obstruction.

Other options:

Option B: Antibiotic drops with repeated syringing is the first line of treatment in adults with chronic dacryocystitis.

Option C: In adults, if dacryocystitis persists after repeated syringing, anatomical assessment with digital subtraction macrodacryocystography localises the level of obstruction.

Option D: Dacryocystorhinostomy is the surgical management of chronic dacryocystitis and is advised in adults with blockage at the level of joining of the nasolacrimal duct and sac.

questions.text:
A known amount of heavy water and inulin are injected intravenously into a healthy young male. The volume of distribution of heavy water and inulin is 36 liters and 12 liters, respectively. Which of the following estimations are true about this condition?
  1. Total body water is 36 L
  2. Intracellular fluid volume is 12 L
  3. Extracellular fluid volume is 9 L
  4. Plasma volume is 3 L
  5. Volume of interstitial fluid is 6 L
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, total body water of the person is around 36 L, and plasma volume is around 3 L. So, statements 1 and 4 are true.

Step 1- Find volumes of total body water and ECF.

Heavy water measures the total body water, whereas inulin measures the extracellular fluid (ECF). Therefore, in this person, total body water is 36 L, and the ECF volume is 12 L.

Step 2- Calculate intracellular fluid (ICF).

ICF = total body water - ECF

Therefore, ICF volume in this person is 24 L.

Step 3- Calculate the plasma volume and volume of the interstitial fluid.

Interstitial fluid constitutes three-fourth of the ECF and plasma volume constitutes one-fourth of ECF. Therefore, the volume of plasma is 1/4th of 12 L, which is 3 L, and the volume of interstitial fluid is 3/4th of 12 L, which is 9 L.

questions.text: What type of tympanogram is expected in this condition?
questions.solution:
The given image is diagnostic of serous otitis media, and type B tympanogram is seen with this condition.

Following features in the given image favours the diagnosis of serous otitis media.

  • The golden yellow colour of the tympanic membrane (due to clear watery straw-coloured effusion filling the middle ear)
  • Structures of the middle ear are seen clearly (due to the clear fluid in the middle ear cavity)
  • Thin leash of blood vessels are seen along the handle of the malleus and the periphery of the tympanic membrane (this differentiates the condition from ASOM where there is marked congestion of the tympanic membrane)

questions.text: A 43-year-old diabetic female notices that on the extension of her fingers, the middle finger alone extends only with extra force and snaps while doing so. There is an audible click when the finger is flexed and the extension is as depicted in the clip below. She has had these complaints for the past 2 months but has not sought treatment for this condition prior to this. What would you recommend as the management for this patient?

choices.text: Corticosteroid injection at mouth of the tendon sheath
Flexor synovectomy with excision of flexor digitorum superficialis
Strict glycemic control to facilitate spontaneous recovery

questions.solution:
The condition depicted in the video is a trigger finger. In this case, the patient has not tried medical treatment first and hence glucocorticoid injection must be first tried before considering a surgical option.

Trigger finger is caused by stenosing tendovaginitis of the flexor sheath. There is nodular or fusiform swelling on the flexor tendon that prevents it from moving along the A1 pulley. When the finger is flexed or extended, the nodular swelling passes through the A1 pulley with a snap, leading to a triggering effect. The nodule can get trapped behind the A1 pulley leading to a locking of the finger in flexion.

Treatment of trigger finger - 

  • Splinting of the fingers
  • NSAIDs, physiotherapy.
  • Administration of corticosteroid injection.
  • Refractory cases need surgery by incising over the A1 pulley.
  • In patients with rheumatoid arthritis, flexor synovectomy with excision of one slip of flexor digitorum superficialis is preferred so that the fibrous pulley is preserved.
  • In children age <3 years, spontaneous recovery is expected.

Related Pearl: Important Injuries of the Hand

Gamekeeper's thumb: It is an injury of the thumb leading to avulsion, rupture or damage of the ulnar collateral ligament. It is commonly seen in gamekeepers and following a fall on an outstretched hand.

 
Mallet finger/baseball finger: It is a disruption to the extensor tendon over the DIP joint. It occurs when a collision with a hard object (e.g., a ball) forces it to flex more than its normal range of motion.
 

 

Jersey finger: It is an avulsion injury of the flexor digitorum profundus at the insertion of the base of the distal phalanx. The ring finger most commonly involved.

 

Trigger finger: A nodule on the flexor tendon prevents it from moving along the A1 pulley. This causes the finger to be stuck in a flexed position.

 

Boxer's fracture: It is a break in the neck of the metacarpal. It is caused by striking an object with a closed fist, as seen in boxing. The little finger is the most commonly affected.

questions.text:
You are evaluating a 39-year-old male patient for malabsorption and vitamin B12 deficiency. He undergoes a Schilling test and the findings observed are given in the table. What is the likely diagnosis?
Test Absorption
Co-labeled cobalamin Reduced
With intrinsic factor Normal
With pancreatic enzymes Reduced
With Antibiotics for 5 days Reduced
questions.solution:
Normal absorption of Vit B12 with intrinsic factor is seen in Pernicious Anemia.

Pernicious anemia can be defined as a severe lack of intrinsic factor due to gastric atrophy. People who have pernicious anemia can't absorb enough vitamin B12 from food. This is because they lack intrinsic factor, a protein made in the stomach. 

Related Pearl: Schilling Test

The Schilling test is done to determine the cause of vitamin B12 deficiency. It involves the administration of radiolabeled vitamin B12 followed by the 24-hour collection of urine. The test is then repeated with an additional component that can promote vitamin B12 absorption. If the additional component is able to correct the defect and radiolabeled vitamin B12 is absorbed, it will be detected in the urine.

questions.solution:
Among the given options, the correct one is 1-B, 2-D, 3-A, 4-E, 5-C.

1. Wilson and Blair B. Salmonella typhi
2. Sorbitol MacConkey D. Escherichia coli O157:H7

Wilson and Blair's medium is selective for Salmonella species. It is a type of selective and indicator media. Salmonella typhi reduces sulphite to sulphide in the presence of glucose and produces jet black colonies with a metallic sheen due to the production of H2S on Wilson and Blair bismuth sulphite medium. S. paratyphi A produces green colonies due to the absence of H2S production.

An image of Wilson and Blair's medium is given below-

Sorbitol MacConkey is used for identifying E. coli O157:H7. Unlike most other E.Coli serotypes, the Shiga toxin-producing E.Coli (STEC) O157: H7 does not use sorbitol and produces clear colonies on the Sorbitol MacConkey agar. The non-STEC produces pink colonies. 

An image of the Sorbitol MacConkey medium is given below- 

BCYE agar or buffered charcoal, yeast extract agar is selective for Legionella species which are nutritionally fastidious.

Composition of BCYE Agar-

  • Agar
  • ACES buffer- To maintain the pH for optimal growth
  • Yeast extract- Supplies the protein and other nutrients necessary to support growth
  • Charcoal- Activated charcoal decomposes hydrogen peroxide, a metabolic product toxic to Legionella species.
  • L-Cysteine- It is an essential amino acid, incorporated to satisfy specific nutritional requirements of Legionella species
  • Ferric Pyrophosphate- Used as an iron source
  • Ketoglutarate monopotassium salt- Alpha-ketoglutarate is added to stimulate growth.

An image of BCYE agar is given below-

Skirrow’s medium is selective for Campylobacter species. It contains vancomycin, polymyxin B, and trimethoprim to inhibit the growth of other bacteria. Colonies may be observed after overnight incubation.

An image of Skirrow's medium is given below- 

Macleod medium is selective for Corynebacterium diphtheriae. Potassium tellurite in McLeod's medium or Potassium Tellurite Agar is reduced to metallic tellurium by Corynebacterium diphtheriae to produce black colonies.

An image of McLeod medium is given below-

questions.text:
Which of the following clinical scenarios are correctly matched to the respective clauses application to these cases?
  1. A surgeon performs thyroidectomy after obtaining relevant informed consent from the patient, but the recurrent laryngeal nerve was injured intraoperatively. 
  2. A doctor performing life-saving procedures on a patient with life-threatening RTA injuries without obtaining consent.
  3. A surgeon concealing rare adverse outcomes of surgery to the anxious patient and revealing the details to close relatives of the patient.
  4. A surgeon accidentally left a cotton swab inside the abdomen post-laparotomy.

A- The doctrine of therapeutic privilege

B- Res Ipsa Loquitor

C- The doctrine of emergency

D- Medical maloccurrence
questions.solution:
The correct option is 1-D, 2-C, 3-A, 4-B

Scenario 1:

Medical Maloccurrence:  The patient fails to respond properly or may suffer some adverse reactions to the drug which may lead to severe injuries or permanent deformities, despite all proper care given by the doctor during treatment. This is known as a medical maloccurrence. If the doctor can prove this before the court, it will be an absolute defence against malpractice.

Scenario 2:

Under IPC 92, the doctor can perform life-saving procedures on a patient with life-threatening injuries without obtaining consent. The guiding principle is whether the delay in treatment in order to obtain consent would result in harm to the patient. This is the doctrine of emergency. Under some circumstances like emergencies, informed consent may be neither possible nor necessary.

Scenario 3: 

If full disclosure is disadvantageous to the patient (e.g. in patients with anxiety), then the doctor can withhold certain information from the patient. However, he should disclose the full information to a competent relative of the patient. This is called therapeutic privilege.

Scenario 4:
Res Ipsa Loquitor means the thing or fact speaks for itself. It is obvious evidence of the negligent act committed. For example, swabs left in the abdominal cavity post laparotomy. The negligent act is so obvious that the patient need not prove the negligence. 

This doctrine applies to both civil and criminal negligence. All of the following conditions should be fulfilled for this doctrine:

  • In the absence of negligence, there would not have been any injury usually
  • The doctor had complete control over the injury-producing instrument or treatment.
  • The patient was not a part of contributory negligence.

questions.text: A biochemist performed electrophoresis on lipoproteins during a study and the result obtained is shown below. The marked lipoprotein which has moved nearest to the anode is likely to be ______.
questions.solution:
On electrophoresis, HDL moves farthest on the electrophoretic plate towards the anode.

HDL has the highest electrophoretic mobility and the least percentage of lipid content. HDL particles are the densest with a high protein-to-lipid ratio. 

Chylomicron is the largest lipoprotein and has the most amount of triglycerides. Chylomicron particles have the lowest density and the largest size. They contain the highest percentage of lipids and the lowest percentage of protein.

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman who has been complaining of unilateral headache and jaw pain for 2 weeks, now comes with complaints of blurry vision. She also has a history of stiffness and pain in her shoulders and hips. Visual field examination shows a pale optic disc. Which of the following is the most probable pathophysiology seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient's clinical picture is suggestive of giant cell arteritis (GCA) with polymyalgia rheumatica which is most commonly associated with anterior ischemic optic neuropathy (AION).

AION is due to the interference in the circulation of the posterior ciliary artery supplying the anterior part of the optic nerve.

Anterior ischemic optic neuropathy (AION):

The two types are as follows:

  • Arteritic AION: caused by giant-cell arteritis
  • Non-arteritic AION (NAAION): most common

The image given below shows pale chalky white optic disc edema of arteritic AION.

In GCA with visual changes, corticosteroid therapy should be started as soon as possible. An intravenous loading dose of 200 mg hydrocortisone or 500 mg methylprednisolone administered slowly over one hour is recommended. It is followed by high doses of oral prednisolone (1 mg/kg/day) given daily for the first week. A maintenance dose of 5–15 mg is continued for at least 6–12 months.

Other Options: 

Option A: Central retinal artery occlusion presents as a sudden painless loss of vision. It is most often caused due to an embolus from an atherosclerotic plaque. Fundus examination shows an opaque, milky-white retina with a cherry-red spot as shown below.

Option C: Central retinal vein occlusion also causes painless loss of vision, although not as rapidly as CRAO. Fundoscopy demonstrates tortuous engorged veins and retinal hemorrhages as shown below.

Option D: Posterior ischemic optic neuropathy involves the small pial vessels supplying the intraorbital portion of the optic nerve. Although it is associated with vasculitides like giant cell arteritis and systemic lupus erythematosus, it doesn't affect the fundus. There is no edema or hemorrhage on fundoscopy.

questions.text: A 16-month-child is brought with a history of abdominal distension and delayed mental development. On examination, the cornea is cloudy and there appears to be hepatosplenomegaly. The radiograph of the child is given below. What is the probable diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis in this patient is Hurler's syndrome.

As the child presents with mental retardation, hepatosplenomegaly, cloudy cornea and given x-ray shows a J-shaped sella turcica and a thickened calvaria, the most likely diagnosis is Hurler's Syndrome.

Hurler's syndrome is also known as mucopolysaccharidosis 1. This is due to the defect in the α-L iduronidase leading to the accumulation of heparan sulphate and dermatan sulphate.

Radiological features in Hurler Syndrome:

  • Macrocephaly
  • J-shaped sella (seen in above radiograph)
  • Thickened calvaria (skull cap)
  • Oar-shaped ribs (seen below)
  • Hook-shaped vertebral bodies

 

Other options:

Option A- Tay-Sachs disease is a hereditary neurodegenerative disorder due to the deficiency of the enzyme hexosaminidase-A resulting in the excess storage of GM2 ganglioside within the lysosomes of cells. The clinical features include developmental delay, intellectual impairment, seizures, and breathing difficulty.

The CT image shows macrocephaly and reduced attenuation of the cerebral white matter. MRI can delineate deep white matter demyelination, and indicate calcification in thalami on T2 weighted sequences.

Option C- Gaucher disease is the most common lysosomal storage disorder characterized by autosomal recessive inheritance due to the deficiency of the glucocerebrosidase enzyme. This results in the accumulation of a glycolipid (glucocerebroside) within the lysosomes of macrophages.

The clinical features include bone pain, pathological fractures, bone crises hepatosplenomegaly, and hematological disturbances.

The radiological features of the skeletal involvement include osteopenia, osteonecrosis, fractures (pathological), Erlenmeyer flask deformity, and H-shaped vertebra.

Option D- Hunter's disease is also known as mucopolysaccharidosis 2 resulting from the deficiency of iduronate sulfatase. This causes the accumulation of dermatan sulfate and heparan sulfate.

The clinical features include abnormal facies characterized by the prominent forehead, flattened nasal bridge, coarse facies, gingival hyperplasia, macroglossia, short stature, dysostosis multiplex, macrocephaly, intellectual disability, hepatosplenomegaly.

These patients lack clouding of the cornea.

The radiological features include thickened calvaria, enlargement of the skull, broad clavicle and ribs, thoracolumbar kyphosis, hip dysplasia, and genu valgum deformity.

questions.text:
A 33-year-old female patient is brought to the emergency department with dyspnea, fatigue, and altered mental status. Examination reveals a temperature of 101 F. Laboratory investigations show a platelet count of 60,000 cells/cu mm and creatinine levels of 2.5 mg/dl. Peripheral smear shows the findings below. Choose the correct statements regarding this patient's condition.
  1. There will be an increase in the levels of vWF metalloprotease
  2. The presence of schistocytes on the peripheral smear is highly specific for this condition
  3. Upshaw-Schulman syndrome is an acquired form of this condition
  4. This condition results in defective platelet adhesion and aggregation
  5. Plasma exchange therapy is the mainstay of treatment
questions.solution:
The given clinical complex describes the classical pentad of thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura. This condition results in defective platelet adhesion and aggregation and plasma exchange therapy is the mainstay of treatment.

TTP: It is a deficiency of, or antibodies to, the metalloprotease ADAMTS13 (a disintegrin and metalloproteinase with a thrombospondin type 1 motif, member 13), which normally cleaves multimers of VWF. The persistence of the VWF molecules causes pathogenic platelet adhesion and aggregation. This causes localized platelet thrombi and fibrin deposits at various sites leading to the classic pentad of TTP.

Pentad of TTP Remarks

questions.text: A young patient having a dibucaine number of 80 was prescribed topical anesthetic dibucaine. Which of the following statements is true regarding dibucaine number?

choices.text: A homozygote patient with abnormal allele will have a dibucaine number of 80
Dibucaine number measures  the amount of pseudocholinesterase enzyme
Percentage of activation of pseudocholinesterase is termed as dibucaine number
Adequacy of pseudocholinesterase can be determined qualitatively by dibucaine number

questions.solution:
Among the given options, Option D i.e Adequacy of pseudocholinesterase can be determined qualitatively by dibucaine number is the true statement

  • Dibucaine is a local anesthetic. It inhibits normal pseudocholinesterase activity by 80% but inhibits atypical enzyme activity by only 20%.
  • Dibucaine number refers to the percentage of inhibition of pseudocholinesterase activity.
  • A patient with normal pseudocholinesterase has a dibucaine number of 80; a homozygote will have a dibucaine number of 20.
  • The dibucaine number measures pseudocholinesterase function, not the amount of enzyme. Therefore, the adequacy of pseudocholinesterase can be determined
    • Quantitatively in units per liter - in the laboratory
    • Qualitatively by dibucaine number 

Related Pearl: Dibucaine number

  • High dibucaine number (80) means the high quantity of normal and low quantity of atypical pseudocholinesterase: normal response to succinylcholine and mivacurium.
  • Low dibucaine number (<30) means the low quantity of normal and high quantity of atypical pseudocholinesterase: prolonged succinylcholine and mivacurium block.

questions.text: A primigravida in her 1st trimester presents with genital prolapse. On examination, the cervix visible outside the introitus is replaced into the vagina and held in place by a ring pessary. What is the ideal time to remove the pessary?

choices.text: At the end of her 1st trimester

questions.solution:
Genital prolapse in pregnancy is treated with the application of a ring pessary which should be kept in place until the 18th–20th week of pregnancy, when the body of the uterus is sufficiently enlarged to sit on the brim of the pelvis.

Patients may present with copious vaginal discharge and a decubitus ulcer may develop if the cervix remains outside the introitus. If the uterus does not rise above the pelvis by the 16th week of pregnancy, there is a chance of incarceration of the uterus.

The symptoms are mostly pronounced in early pregnancy.

There is an increased chance of miscarriage, premature rupture of membranes and chorioamnionitis during pregnancy.

Treatment involves the application of a ring pessary to keep the cervix in place. A ring pessary is also used to treat prolapse in very elderly women who cannot be surgically managed. It is used as an adjunct to pelvic floor physiotherapy. It is also used in puerperium to facilitate involution.

The image below shows a ring pessary.

If the pelvic floor is too lax, the patient is advised to lie in bed with the foot end elevated, and the prolapsed mass is covered with a gauze soaked in glycerine and acriflavine. This is continued until the 18th–20th week of pregnancy till the prolapsed mass is reduced in size and replaced inside the vagina.

questions.text: A college-going student was brought to the ER after suffering a head injury in the college sports event. The 2nd year PG tells you to calculate GCS as you were the only intern available. On examination, you find out that the student was confused, he opens his eyes spontaneously, flexes one limb on painful stimuli, and can localize the stimulus with the other limb. You calculate the Glasgow Coma Score to be________
questions.solution:
The Glasgow Coma Score in this patient is 13.

To calculate the GCS score, the following clinical points have to be considered:

  • The score for verbal response: 4, because he is confused
  • The score for eye-opening: 4, because his eyes are opening spontaneously.
  • The score for best motor response: 5, because he can localize pain

Therefore, the GCS score is (4+4+5) = 13.

  • In case of endotracheal intubation or tracheostomy, the verbal component of the score is denoted as NT.
  • A score of  ‘1’ is not recorded in missing components, instead, NT is used
  • when a component is Not Testable, a total score is not recorded because the score will be low and this could be confusing to medical colleagues. This may also imply that the patient is more unwell than they actually are.

Note: The minimum frequency of observations for patients with GCS equal to 15 should be as follows, starting after the initial assessment in the emergency department:

  • Half-hourly for 2 hours,
  • Then 1-hourly for 4 hours,
  • 2-hourly thereafter.

Should the patient with GCS equal to 15 deteriorate at any time after the initial 2-hour period, observations should revert to half-hourly and follow the original frequency schedule.

questions.text: A newly joined trainee at the gymnasium was able to lift about 8 Kilograms of weight using both his upper limbs. When two more kilograms were added, he could not resist and had dropped the weight down. Which receptor and nerve fiber are responsible for his inability to bear the weight?

choices.text: Golgi tendon organ and Ib fiber
Golgi tendon organ and Ia fiber

questions.solution:
The Golgi tendon organ and Ib fiber are responsible for his inability to bear the weight.

Here, in the scenario given, two types of physiological reflexes have happened.

  • Stretch reflex/myotatic reflex - This has been responsible for the ability to bear the initial 8 kgs of weight by the trainee.
  • Inverse myotatic/ Inverse stretch reflex - When two more kgs have been added, this has brought the inhibition of motor neuron discharge to his muscles which are responsible for his inability to bear the weight.

Golgi tendon reflex (Inverse myotatic/ Inverse stretch reflex) is disynaptic, is the opposite of the stretch reflex.

When the tension on the muscle becomes extreme, the inhibitory effect from the Golgi tendon organ, carried by Ib afferents, leads to instantaneous relaxation of the entire muscle. This effect is called the lengthening reaction.

It is a protective mechanism to prevent tearing of the muscle or avulsion of the tendon from its attachments to the bone.

Note: Muscle spindles senses changes in muscle length (stretch).

questions.text:
A 25-year-old male comes into the ER with pain around his ankle after twisting his ankle while playing football. Which of the following indicates the need for ankle X-rays according to Ottawa rules?

1 - Pain around the malleolus
2 - Numbness distal to the ankle
3 - Inability to bear weight on the ankle
4 - Bone tenderness at the posterior edge of the medial or lateral malleolus 
5 - Ability to take 10 steps in the ER
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette describes a case of an ankle injury. The Ottawa ankle rules are used to determine the need for ankle X-rays in such cases.

The Ottawa ankle rules state that an x-ray is needed if any of the following conditions are met-

  1. Pain around the malleolar zone. 
  2. Bone tenderness at the posterior edge or tip of the lateral/medial malleolus/base of the 5th metatarsal bone. 
  3. An inability to bear weight immediately after the injury.
  4. Inability to walk 4 steps in the emergency department.

Acute injury of lateral ligaments of the ankle:

Clinical features -  Presents with a  history of a twisting injury. Pain and swelling may be present. A sprain is suspected if the patient is able to walk and bruising is only faint and slow to appear; a more severe injury is suspected if bruising is marked and the patient is unable to put any weight on the foot.

Investigation - X-ray is indicated based on the Ottawa ankle rules as mentioned above.

Treatment - Rest, ice, compression, and elevation (RICE), which is recommended for 1–3 weeks. Protection in the form of crutches, splints, or brace may be added. Persistent problems at 12 weeks after injury, despite physiotherapy, may signal the need for operative treatment.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements are true regarding testicular tumors?

1 -  Elevated tumor markers are found almost exclusively in non-seminomatous germ cell tumors 
2 -  Most neoplasms arise from the Leydig or Sertoli cells  
3 -  The most common site of spread is the retroperitoneal lymph nodes
4 -  Percutaneous testicular biopsy is the diagnostic modality of choice
5 -  Vertebral imaging must be performed to evaluate for evidence of metastasis
questions.solution:
The following statements are true about testicular tumors:

  • Statement 1: Elevated tumor markers are found almost exclusively in non-seminomatous germ cell tumors 
  • Statement 3: The most common site of spread is the retroperitoneal lymph nodes

Testicular tumors are the most common solid malignancy in men aged 15-35 years of age. Cryptorchidism is a major risk factor. Testicular tumors commonly arise from germ cells and only rarely arise from Sertoli/Leydig cells. Further germ cell tumors are classified as seminomatous and non-seminomatous.

Most men are diagnosed with an asymptomatic enlarging mass. They commonly spread to retroperitoneal lymph nodes.

Initially, α-fetoprotein, β-human chorionic gonadotropin, and lactate dehydrogenase levels must be checked. Elevated tumor markers are found almost exclusively in non-seminomatous germ cell tumors. There is no role for percutaneous biopsy due to the risk of seeding the scrotal wall. An open testicular biopsy by delivery of the testicle through the inguinal canal is recommended in cases where metastatic disease to the testicle is suspected. 

Chest and abdominal imaging must be performed to evaluate for evidence of metastasis.

Surgical treatment with orchiectomy or retroperitoneal lymph node dissection(RPLND) is advised.

questions.text: Which of the following findings of cirrhosis is not due to portal hypertension?
questions.solution:
Spider angiomas seen in patients with chronic liver disease are not due to portal hypertension.

Portal hypertension is defined as the elevation of the hepatic venous pressure gradient to >5 mmHg. It occurs due to resistance to blood flow in the liver due to fibrosis and nodules of regenerating parenchyma, and due to increased splanchnic blood flow. The complications of portal hypertension are esophageal varices with variceal bleeding, splenomegaly, ascites, and portal hypertensive gastropathy.

Spider angiomas (also known as spider naevus or spider telangiectasias) consist of a central arteriole, about pin-headed in size from which steadily narrowing capillaries radiate like spider legs, as shown below. They are believed to occur due to the altered metabolism of sex steroids. They are not specific to cirrhosis, and can be seen in pregnancy, and otherwise healthy individuals as well (up to 3 small lesions can be considered normal). 

 

Other findings on physical examination that occur due to inadequate hepatic metabolism of sex steroids include:

  • Testicular atrophy, loss of chest hair, and gynecomastia in males
  • Menstrual irregularities in females
  • Decreased libido
  • Palmar erythema, which is a symmetrical, bilateral, non-painful redness of palms due to cutaneous vasodilation. The center of the palm is usually spared.

Other features of cirrhosis and their underlying pathophysiology are summarized below:

questions.text: A 3-day-old neonate is being evaluated for the findings shown below. Which of the following is the gold standard for diagnosis of this condition?
questions.solution:
The above clip depicts neonatal seizure of focal clonic type. Video electroencephalogram (EEG) is the gold standard for diagnosis.

Neonatal seizures are defined as the occurrence of sudden, paroxysmal, abnormal alteration of electrographic activity at any point from birth to the end of the neonatal period. It can be focal clonic, focal tonic, myoclonic seizure, or epileptic spasm. 

 A focal clonic seizure is characterized by multiple, repetitive, rhythmic contractions of muscle groups of the limbs, face, or trunk, and-

  • Maybe unifocal or multifocal.
  • May occur synchronously or asynchronously in muscle groups on one side of the body
  • May occur simultaneously but asynchronously on both sides.
  • It cannot be suppressed by restraint.
  • Focal clonic seizures may be unifocal, confined to specific muscle groups including those of the proximal or distal limbs, trunk or neck, or regions of the face
  • These seizures may migrate from one region to another according to traditional Jacksonian features

Video-EEG is the gold standard for diagnosis and quantification of seizures in neonates. The diagnosis is based on clinical observation combined with EEG monitoring

Magnetic resonance imaging (option C) is a preferred modality to evaluate for evidence of hypoxic-ischemic injury, intracranial hemorrhage, ischemic stroke, or brain malformations

Genetic testing for evidence of KCNQ2 (Option D) mutations is positive in a large majority of patients. It also helps in specific treatments for some associated syndromes. 

Computed tomography (Option A) is generally avoided in neonates since MRI provides superior resolution with no exposure to ionizing radiation. 

WHO recommendation:

  • Clinically apparent seizures in the neonate should be treated if they last >3 minutes or are brief serial seizures.
  • If electroencephalography (EEG) is possible, all electrical seizures should also be treated, even in the absence of clinically apparent conditions.
  • In all neonates with seizures, hypoglycemia, CNS infection, and hypocalcemia should be ruled out before anti-epileptic drug treatment.

questions.text: A female patient presents with multiple itchy hypopigmented skin lesions. Examination findings are shown in the image given below. What is the most likely causative agent of the suspected condition?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario and the image showing multiple hypopigmented macules and patches on the chest strongly suggest tinea versicolor or pityriasis versicolor. The most likely causative agent are the Malassezia species.  

Malassezia species that are commonly involved in Tinea versicolor:

  • Malassezia globosa
  • Malassezia sympodialis
  • Malassezia furfur

Malassezia species are lipophilic fungi. They cause the degradation of lipid-producing acids like azelaic acid that inhibit tyrosinase, resulting in hypopigmented patches. 

Clinically, tinea versicolor presents with hypopigmented patches or hyperpigmented or reddish patches due to inflammation. It commonly affects the upper trunk, upper arms, neck, and abdomen. They may be mildly itchy and have fine scales. 

Lesions fluoresce under Wood’s lamp. On potassium hydroxide (KOH) mount and microscopy the Malassezia species appear as short unbranched, non-pigmented hyphae and spherical cells. This is also called the spaghetti and meatballs or bananas and grapes appearance. 

Treatment involves selenium sulfide, topical or oral azoles. 

Other options:

Option A: Piedraia hortae is a non-pathogenic opportunist that infects human hair causing black piedra. It is characterized by dark, hardened nodules firmly attached to the hair.

Option B: Exophiala werneckii/ Hortaea werneckii/ Phaeoannellomyces werneckii/ Cladosporium werneckii cause tinea nigra–gray to black non-inflammatory, non-scaling, well-demarcated macular lesions usually on the palm.

Option D: Microsporum causes dermatophytosis/ tinea/ ringworm.

questions.text: A 35-year-old primigravida presents with pain and numbness in the first three digits of her hand. The patient reports that the pain is worse at night and to relieve the pain she shakes her hand. She has a positive Phalen's and Tinel's test. Which among the following treatments will you recommend for this patient?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is indicative of carpal tunnel syndrome(CTS). Carpal tunnel syndrome in pregnant females is first managed with wrist splinting.

Carpal tunnel syndrome (CTS) refers to the complex of symptoms and signs brought on by compression of the median nerve as it travels through the carpal tunnel. 

Clinical features:

  • Pain, paresthesia of the first three digits, and the radial half of the fourth digit. The symptoms are worse at night relieved by shaking or wringing their hands or by placing them under warm running water. It may progress to weakness and clumsiness of the hand.
  • Durkan's test is the most specific test for the diagnosis of carpal tunnel syndrome. In Durkan's test, direct median nerve compression is done. The presence of paresthesias and pain denotes median nerve compression.
  • Phalen's test - Elicited by holding the wrist flexed fully. The appearance of sensory symptoms within 60 seconds implies a positive test. 
  • Tinel's sign - Sensory symptoms can also be reproduced by percussing over the median nerve.

The diagnosis of carpal tunnel syndrome is usually clinical. Nerve conduction studies are done to confirm the diagnosis in case of atypical presentation of carpal tunnel syndrome.

Clinical grading of CTS -

  • Mild -  Numbness, tingling, or discomfort in the median nerve distribution but no sensory loss, weakness, sleep disruption, or interference with activities of daily living (ADLs)
  • Moderate - Sensory loss in the median distribution, or if nocturnal symptoms occasionally disrupt sleep. However, ADLs are normal
  • Severe - If nocturnal symptoms routinely disrupt sleep, weakness in the median distribution, or the patient is unable to carry out ADLs.

Treatment: 

In cases of mild clinical symptoms splinting or glucocorticoid injections may be first tried. Additionally in cases where it is pregnancy-induced wrist splinting may provide respite without the need for surgical interventions as the cause is transient and symptoms improve upon delivery. Surgical decompression is recommended for severe CTS or if non-surgical management fails.

questions.text: An infant presented with a lack of tonicity of the abdominal wall along with a wrinkled appearance of the skin as shown in the figure. questions.solution:

  • Genitourinary Defects

  • Predominantly seen in males

  • Vesicoureteric Reflux
  • Limb Anomalies and scoliosis

Treatment :

  • Ureteric dilatation - not until an obstruction occurs
  • Bilateral orchidopexy - for cryptorchidism
  • Abdominal wall reconstruction - performed in conjugation with orchidopexy at 6-12 months of age through abdominoplasty.

questions.text:
Given below are various injection techniques. You are also provided with a list of various medications of which one of them is advised to be given using the Z-Track technique. Match the injection technique where we use the Z-track method, with the drug that needs to be delivered by that route.
  1. Injection Ferric Carboxy maltose.
  2. Injection insulin glargine.
  3. Injection Long acting depot Olanzapine.
  4. Injection Platelet activating factor.
questions.solution:
The Z-track technique is used for intramuscular administration (Figure A) of long-acting depot antipsychotics like Olanzapine.

Procedure:

  • Stretch the skin by pulling it laterally away from the intended point of injection.
  • Insert the needle into the site at a 90˚angle, aspirate by pulling back to see if the needle has a penetrated vessel.
  • If blood is aspirated withdraw the needle, and repeat the procedure at another site with new equipment and medication.
  • If no blood is aspirated administer the injection.
  • Wait for 10 seconds and then withdraw the needle, and release the skin allowing the displaced tissue to seal the needle track.

 

Other drugs:

questions.text: The method of shoulder reduction shown below is called ________
questions.solution:
The given method of shoulder reduction is Stimson's method.

Stimson’s gravity method: The patient is made to lie prone with the arm hanging over the side of the bed. A weight may be attached to the elbow or wrist. The shoulder may reduce after 15-20 minutes. 

Other methods of reduction for anterior shoulder reduction are:

  • Hippocratic method (traction counter-traction): Gently increasing traction is applied to the arm with the shoulder in slight abduction.  Counter-traction is applied with the heel in the axilla.
  • Kocher's maneuver: traction, external rotation, adduction, medial rotation (TEAM).

Bigelow method: This a method of reduction of hip dislocation.

(Note: There is also a method of reduction of hip dislocation called Stimson's gravity method, where the same concept of using gravity is performed to reduce the dislocation, but that procedure is not very practical).

Related Pearl: Methods of reduction of shoulder dislocation

Hippocratic method - The doctor applies a firm and steady pull on the semi-abducted arm of the patient by keeping his foot on the axilla against the chest wall. The foot is used as the fulcrum.

Stimson's gravity technique: Patient is left prone and weight is attached to the elbow or wrist on the affected side. Gravity stretches the muscle and reduction occurs in 15-20 minutes.

questions.text: A 27-year-old photographer presented with confusion, delirium, and corrosion near the mouth. He was found with an empty bottle containing hydrocyanic acid. He is tachycardic and hypotensive. Resuscitative measures are unsuccessful, and his body is sent for postmortem analysis. What would be the color of post-mortem hypostasis in this case?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette is suggestive of hydrocyanic acid (HCN) poisoning, and the colour of postmortem hypostasis in case of HCN poisoning is brick red. 

HCN is a toxic chemical acid found in bitter almonds, peaches, apples, cherries, etc. It has the smell of bitter almonds. It is usually present in its glycoside form, amygdalin, along with certain co-enzymes like emulsion complex, these co-enzymes hydrolyze amygdalin to release HCN. HCN is a common chemical used in leather tanning, electroplating, metal extractions, and photographic fixing. 

Mechanism of action: It is a protoplasmic poison releasing cyanide ions, which inhibit complex IV of cellular respiratory enzyme systems. It leads to histotoxic anoxia.

Postmortem findings: 

  • External: The smell of bitter almonds, brick red postmortem hypostasis. Rigor mortis appears early, and jaws are firmly closed.
  • Internal: In suspected cyanide poisoning cases, the cranial cavity should be opened first to perceive the bitter almond smell that is marked in brain tissue. Diffuse cerebral oedema such that white and gray matter cannot be differentiated, haemorrhages in the lungs.

Toxicological analysis: Preserve lungs to demonstrate the gas in a nylon bag. The spleen is the best specimen to demonstrate cyanide poisoning.

Laboratory diagnosis includes a classical triad of

  1. Narrow arterio-venous oxygen difference,
  2. Anion-gap metabolic acidosis, and
  3. Elevated lactate concentration.

HCN may be identified by gas chromatography or spectrophotometry.

Lee-Jones Test: This test indicates the presence of cyanide. The test can be positive for salicylates, too.

Treatment: Shift the patient to a room with fresh air and remove his clothes. Establish proper airway, breathing, and circulation. Inhalational amyl nitrate is administered, and 100% oxygen therapy is also given. Wash skin and eyes with large amounts of water to remove any contact poison, if any. A slow infusion of 3% sodium nitrate solution, followed by a slow infusion of 25% sodium thiosulfate solution, is given.

questions.text: Which among the following patterns of leukonychia are not due to pathology in the structure marked as A?
questions.solution:
The marked structure is the nail matrix and Muehrcke’s lines are not associated with pathology here. The pathology is in the nail bed.

Muehrcke’s lines are narrow white transverse bands, parallel to the lunula. They are associated with chronic hypoalbuminemia. They have also been seen in patients receiving chemotherapy. The lines may resolve following albumin infusions, on correction of the hypoalbuminemia.

Mees lines (Transverse leukonychia) are single or multiple white transverse bands, in the arcuate form of the lunula. They reflect a systemic disorder like arsenic poisoning, thallium poisoning, chemotherapy, or septicemia. The pathology is in the nail matrix.

Longitudinal leukonychia - The pathology is a parakeratotic focus in the nail matrix. It is seen in Darier disease or due to a small tumor.

Punctate leukonychia - Seen as 1-3 mm white spots on the nail. It is caused by minor trauma to the nail matrix in manicures and is also seen in alopecia areata.

questions.text: The contrast-enhanced CT of the abdomen of a 75-year-old woman shows the following findings. Which Bosniak class does the cyst belong to?
questions.solution:
The presence of a simple renal cyst without any septations, calcifications, or enhancing soft tissue components is classified as Bosniak class I. They do not require treatment or follow-up imaging.

Bosniak classification:

Depending on the CT characteristics the renal cysts are classified mainly into four classes:

Class I: It is a simple benign cyst, without any septations.

Class II: The cyst consists of one or more thin (<1 mm) septa running through them. Class II lesions are benign.

The subcategory class IIF includes lesions with multiple class II features, large hyperdense cysts (>3cm), or hyperdense cysts that are totally intrarenal. These cysts are more complex and do not fit into categories II or III. They require follow-up for up to 5 years to exclude malignancy.

Class III: These are complicated cysts having thickened septa with nodular areas of calcification. The walls of the cyst or septae show enhancement. The class III lesions should be surgically explored or biopsied. <50% will turn out to be malignant.

Class IV: These are malignant lesions with solid enhancing nodules. Surgical removal to be considered.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male patient involved in a road traffic accident was brought to the emergency room where a neurosurgeon was available. Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) dropped by 4 points from the time of injury to hospitalization. CT scan reveals the following findings. Which of the following is the best treatment option for this patient?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, a CT scan shows a concavo-convex-shaped hematoma on the left side suggestive of a subdural hematoma (SDH). The best treatment option for this patient with a subdural hematoma and who has a drop in GCS by 4 points is open craniotomy.

Subdural Hematoma (SDH):

Acute SDH results from the accumulation of blood between the arachnoid membrane and the dura. The tearing of a bridging vein running from the cerebral cortex to the dural sinuses is the most common cause of acute SDH. Elderly and alcoholic patients due to brain atrophy are at a higher risk of acute SDH formation after head trauma. On head CT scan, SDH appears as a bright or mixed-density, crescent-shaped (concavo-convex) lesion (as seen in the question)

Open craniotomy for the evacuation of acute SDH is indicated for the following:

  1. Thickness >1 cm
  2. Midline shift >5 mm
  3. GCS drops by two or more points from the time of injury to hospitalization.

Note: Conservative management can be done in patients with a midline shift of <10 mm on a CT scan and a GCS score of 15 initially, reserving urgent craniotomy and evacuation of the hematoma in deteriorating neurological symptoms.

questions.text: Which of the following investigation is shown in the radiograph?
questions.solution:
The contrast radiograph given above is that of barium follow-through.

It is useful in visualising small bowel pathology. It is performed following a barium meal examination of the oesophagus, stomach, and duodenum. It is inferior to enteroclysis where contrast is administered through NG tube. It is also used to evaluate the function of the small bowel.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female sex worker is brought to the casualty following fever, altered mental status, headache, nausea, and vomiting. During the examination, it is seen that the pupils are irregular in shape and small in size. They do not respond to light reflex but respond well to accommodation reflex.  This finding occurs due to a defect in
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, the near reflex is present, whereas the light reflex is absent. This is due to a defect in the tectum. This abnormal pupillary response is called Argyll Robertson pupil and is seen in neurosyphilis.

Pathway for light reflex

  • Afferent fibers travel from the retina to the optic nerve, optic chiasma, and terminate in the pretectal nucleus.
  • Internuncial fibers connect the pretectal nucleus with Edinger Westphal nuclei of both sides.
  • Parasympathetic fibers arise from the Edinger Westphal nuclei of both sides, travel along the oculomotor nerve, and relay in the ciliary ganglion. Postganglionic fibers travel along short ciliary nerves to innervate sphincter pupillae.

Clinical correlate- Since internuncial fibers connect the pretectal nucleus with Edinger Westphal nuclei of both sides, consensual light reflex is seen.

Pathway for accommodation reflex

  • The afferent fibers travel from the retina to the optic nerve, optic chiasma, optic tract, lateral geniculate body, optic radiations, and parastriate cortex. 
  • Impulses from the parastriate cortex are relayed to the Edinger Westphal nucleus of both sides via the occipito-mesencephalic tract and pontine centers.
  • From Edinger Westphal nucleus efferent travel along the third nerve and reach sphincter pupillae and ciliary muscles.

Other abnormal pupillary reactions are:

  1. Amaurotic light reflex- On flashing light to the affected eye, there is no direct light reflex in the affected eye, and there is no consensual light reflex in the normal eye. This occurs due to a lesion in the optic nerve or retina.
  2. Efferent pathway defect- Absence of both direct and consensual light reflex on the affected side and presence of both direct and consensual light reflex on the normal side. It occurs due to a defect in the efferent pathway.
  3. Wernicke’s hemianopic pupil.-In this condition, light reflex (ipsilateral direct and contralateral consensual) is absent when light is thrown on the temporal half of the retina of the affected side and nasal half of the normal side, while it is present when the light is thrown on the nasal half of the affected side and temporal half of the normal side. It occurs due to a lesion in the optic tract.
  4. Marcus Gunn pupil- The pupil dilates in response to light. It is the earliest indication of optic nerve damage.
  5. Adie’s tonic pupil. In this condition, the light reflex is absent and the response to near reflex is very slow and tonic. The affected pupil is larger than normal (anisocoria). It is caused by post ganglionic parasympathetic pupillomotor damage.

questions.text: A senior resident uses Diene’s stain to stain the micro-organisms which appear as shown below. This characteristic appearance is shown by which of the following bacteria?
questions.solution:
Diene's method of staining is used for diagnosis of mycoplasma. It is also known as Eaton agent since Eaton was the first person to isolate Mycoplasma pneumoniae. 

The colony is typically biphasic, with a fried egg appearance, consisting of a central opaque granular area of growth extending into the depth of the medium, surrounded by a flat, translucent peripheral zone. 

Mycoplasma colonies can be studies either with a hand or after staining with Diene's method. For Diene's method, a block of agar containing the colony is cut and placed on a slide. It is covered with a cover slip on which an alcoholic solution of methylene blue and azure has been dried. 

Mycoplasma are the smallest free-living microorganisms and they can be grown in a cell-free medium. They lack a cell wall and are higly pleomorphic. They occur as granules and filaments of various sizes. They were previously called pleuropneumonia-like organisms (PPLO) since they were thought to cause pleuropneumonia in many animals and humans.

The species of mycoplasma causing human infections are:

  • M.pneumoniae causing pneumonia
  • Ureaplasma urealyticum causing non-gonococcal urethritis
  • M.hominis and M.gentalium causing genital tract infections.

questions.text: The lung compliance of a 40-year-old patient with shortness of breath has been compared to that of a normal person in the pressure-volume curve below. What is the likely diagnosis based on this chart?
questions.solution:
The interpretation of the above pressure-volume curve shows that the patient has increased lung compliance, making the likely diagnosis of pulmonary emphysema. 

Compliance is the tendency for tissue to resume its original position after an applied force has been removed.

After an expiration during quiet breathing, the lungs have a tendency to collapse and the chest wall has a tendency to expand. The interaction between the recoil of the lungs and the recoil of the chest can be measured through a spirometer and a curve of airway pressure plotted against volume is the pressure-volume curve of the total respiratory system (Ptr).

Compliance of the lung and chest wall is measured as the slope of the PTR curve, or, as a change in lung volume per unit change in airway pressure (ΔV/ΔP). 

  • The curve is shifted downwards when compared to normal in case of decreased compliance. Eg. pulmonary edema, and interstitial pulmonary fibrosis due to alveoli being prevented from getting inflated. Decreased compliance is also seen in sarcoidosis.
  • The curve is shifted upwards and to the left in case of increased compliance. Eg. emphysema, normal aging lungs due to decreased elastic recoil of lungs (a tendency of the lungs to become less stretched).

 

Increased compliance seen in emphysema is due to - 

Related Pearl: Lung Compliance

Compliance is the change in lung volume per unit change in the surrounding pressure.

It is represented by the formula:

Compliance = ΔV/ΔP

Factors Affecting Compliance

  • Lung volume: smaller the lungs, smaller is the compliance
  • For a given lung size, the compliance becomes less at extremes of lung volume
  • Compliance is slightly greater when measured during deflation than during inflation
  • If the surface tension is more, compliance is less
  • Compliance measured with saline is more than compliance measured with air.

Compliance is decreased in conditions such as:

  • Pulmonary fibrosis: Due to increased fibrous tissue in the lung, making it less elastic, and thus less expandable.
  • Alveolar edema, which prevents the expansion of some alveoli.
  • If lung remains unventilated for a long time, in a low volume lung, due to atelectasis (collapse) of lung units or increased surface tension.
  • Increased pulmonary venous pressure.

Compliance is increased in conditions such as:

  • Pulmonary emphysema
  • Normal aging lung

questions.text:
Match the toxin to its mechanism of action.
Toxin Mechanism of action
1- Diphtheria toxin A- Overactivates adenylate cyclase and increases cAMP
2- Cholera toxin B- Inactivates 60s ribosomal subunit
3- Clostridium perfringens- alpha toxin C- Inactivates elongation factor- EF2
4- Botulinum toxin D- Phospholipase action degrading cell membranes
   E- Inhibits release of neurotransmitter
questions.solution:
The correct match is 1-C, 2-A, 3-D, 4-E

Diphtheria toxin acts by inactivating elongation factor- EF2, thereby inhibiting protein synthesis.

Cholera toxin acts by over-activating adenylate cyclase and increasing cAMP which causes increased chloride secretion and water efflux into the gut.

The alpha-toxin of clostridium perfringens acts as a phospholipase (lecithinase C) and causes degradation of cell membranes and results in tissue damage. In the presence of calcium and magnesium ions, this toxin splits lecithin into phosphorylcholine and diglyceride.

Botulinum toxin acts by blocking the production or release of acetylcholine at the synapses and neuromuscular junctions.

Inactivation of the 60s ribosomal subunit is caused by Shiga toxin.

Related Pearl: Mechanism of action of various bacterial toxins

The mechanism of action of various bacterial toxins are as given below:

Increase in cAMP

  • Bordetella pertusis
  • Bacillus anthracis
  • Vibrio cholerae - Cholera toxin
  • Enterotoxigenic E.coli (ETEC) - heat labile toxin

Increase in cGMP

  • Enterotoxigenic E.coli (ETEC) - heat stable toxin

Inhibition of protein synthesis

  • Diptheria toxin: inhibit elongation factor-2 (EF-2)
  • Pseudomonas: inhibit elongation factor-2 (EF-2)
  • Clostridium difficile
  • Enterohemorrhagic E.coli (EHEC)-Shiga-like toxin: inhibit 60S

questions.text: A 45-year-old man is diagnosed with amnesia. Which of the following will not be impaired in this patient?

choices.text: Name of pet bird growing up

questions.solution:
The ability to drive a bicycle is not impaired in this patient.

The ability to drive a bicycle is a non-declarative memory and this type of memory is preserved in amnesia.

Non-declarative memory includes:

  • Skill learning
  • Habit learning
  • Simple forms of conditioning

Declarative memory supports the conscious recollection of facts and events. For example:

  • Memory for routes, lists, faces, melodies, objects
  • Memory for other verbal and nonverbal material

The memory of the melody of his favorite song, the name of pet bird growing up and route navigation are all types of declarative memory. This is impaired in amnesia.

Related Pearl: Forms of Memory

From physiologic point of view memory is divided into explicit and implicit forms.

questions.text: A 7-month-old child with acute diarrhea is being treated with oral rehydration solution (ORS).  Which of the following is correct regarding zinc supplementation in this child?
questions.solution:
A 7-month-old child being treated for acute diarrhea should be supplemented with oral zinc at 20 mg/day for 10-14 days.

Zinc administration for diarrhea management can significantly reduce mortality and hospital admission. In addition, it improves diarrhea recovery rates and reduces the inappropriate use of antimicrobials.

Zinc supplementation is usually done for 10 to 14 days. The dosage is age-dependent as follows:

Age <6 months: 10 mg/day

Age >6 months:  20 mg/day

questions.text: A 22-year-old male patient who was diagnosed with myopia at 10 years of age came for an opinion on LASIK surgery. On routine preoperative assessment, the estimated residual stromal bed was calculated to be 200 μm, and surgery was deferred. Which of the following anticipated complications made the surgeon take such a decision?
questions.solution:
LASIK, when performed in this patient, would predispose him to ectasia of the cornea (keratectasia) because of the inadequate residual stromal bed thickness.

Because LASIK is a procedure involving the ablation of stroma, a preoperative calculation of the residual stromal bed thickness can aid the eye surgeon to predict the postoperative risk for corneal ectasia.

The residual stromal bed thickness can be calculated by subtracting the anticipated flap thickness and maximum ablation depth from the central corneal thickness. A residual stromal bed thickness of 250 to 300 μm is generally recognized as a minimum requirement before LASIK surgery. Hence, the calculation of central corneal thickness is an important element of preoperative evaluation.

Patient selection is of utmost importance in refractive eye surgeries. The following factors must be considered before taking up a patient for refractive eye surgery.

  • Minimum age of 21 years
  • Stable refraction for at least 1 year
  • Measurement of the central corneal thickness ( to calculate the residual stromal bed thickness)
  • A detailed review of ocular and systemic conditions

Limitations and contraindications of LASIK: The following group of patients poses a high risk for laser vision correction, and when done are associated with adverse surgical outcomes.

  • Collagen vascular disease
  • Autoimmune and immunodeficiency diseases
  • Pregnant and nursing mothers
  • Keratoconus
  • Chronic intake of isotretinoin and amiodarone
  • Fuchs corneal dystrophy
  • Ophthalmic herpes simplex and herpes zoster

Other options:

Option A- Punctate epithelial dystrophy (dry eye) is the most frequent complication of LASIK surgery, and the same can be managed with frequent lubrication using artificial tears.

Option B- Flap displacement usually occurs within 24 hours after surgery. Once diagnosed, the flap should be lifted and repositioned as soon as possible.

Option D- The corneal epithelium grows in the interface between the flap and stromal bed. This is termed epithelial ingrowth. If it causes vision disturbances, Nd:YAG laser application is warranted to treat the condition.

questions.text:
An MRI scan of a 40-year-old male who presented with hearing difficulty, frequent episodes of tinnitus, and imbalance is given below. Which of the following statements are correct considering the likely diagnosis?
  1. The patient will have poor speech discrimination that is disproportionate to pure-tone hearing loss.
  2. Roll-over phenomenon is seen.
  3. External beam radiotherapy is the treatment of choice.
  4. Most commonly arises from the cochlear division of the VIIIth nerve.
  5. Recruitment phenomenon is present.
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette and MRI scan are suggestive of acoustic neuroma. Here, the patient will have poor speech discrimination that is disproportionate to pure-tone hearing loss, and the roll-over phenomenon is seen making statements 1 and 2 correct.

Acoustic neuroma also known as vestibular schwannoma or eighth nerve tumor more commonly arises from the vestibular and rarely from the cochlear division of the eighth nerve. It is a cerebellopontine angle tumour mostly seen in the age group of 40–60 years.

Clinically, patients with acoustic neuroma are present with progressive unilateral sensorineural hearing loss with tinnitus. Poor speech discrimination on speech audiometry is the characteristic feature of acoustic neuroma. Vestibular symptoms like imbalance or unsteadiness are seen.

Hitzelberger’s sign which is the hypoaesthesia of the posterior meatal wall when the tumor affects the sensory fibers of the facial nerve is seen.

Roll-over phenomenon which is the reduction in discrimination score when loudness is increased beyond a particular limit is commonly observed. Recruitment phenomenon is absent.

MRI with gadolinium contrast is the gold standard for the diagnosis of acoustic neuroma. Ice-cream cone appearance of the tumor is seen.

Surgical removal of the tumor is the treatment of choice. The approach depends on the size of the tumor. 

External beam radiation is not recommended as it causes significant damage to the surrounding brain and neural structures. Stereotactic radiosurgery is a reasonable alternative for people who refuse or cannot tolerate surgery.

questions.text:
Choose the correct statements regarding "A" in the image shown.
  1. It is synthesized primarily in the liver
  2. It is a negative acute phase reactant
  3. Mutations leading to its excess production are implicated in Wilson's disease
  4. It represses iron release from the macrophages
  5. Its deficiency is implicated in hemochromatosis
questions.solution:
The molecule represented as "A" in the given image is hepcidin. It is synthesized in the liver, represses iron release from the macrophages, and its deficiency is implicated in hemochromatosis.

Hepcidin is the key regulatory hormone that allows the liver to communicate with the bone marrow. It has anti-bacterial properties and derives its name from hepatic bactericidal protein. It is also called liver-expressed antimicrobial peptide (LEAP-1).

It is produced in the liver. It suppresses basolateral iron transport in the intestine and iron release from the macrophages and other cells by binding to ferroportin. It is a positive acute-phase reactant and its values strongly correlate with ferritin.

Hepcidin responds to liver-mediated signals, HFE, TfR2, and hemojuvelin. Mutations in hepcidin cause a form of hemochromatosis. It is excreted by the kidney and reabsorbed in the proximal tubules.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male was diagnosed with AIDS and was started on antiretroviral drugs. After 10 months patient came to OPD and examination revealed hands as shown. The following change is encountered with the use of which of the following antiretroviral agents?
questions.solution:
The image shows the Nail hyperpigmentation which is commonly encountered with the use of zidovudine. This is seen with chronic zidovudine administration. 

The adverse effects of Zidovudine are:

  • Fatigue, malaise, myalgia, anorexia, headache, insomnia
  • Erythrocytic macrocytosis
  • Nail hyperpigmentation
  • Myopathy
  • Bone marrow suppression leading to anemia and granulocytopenia

questions.text: A morbidly obese diabetic woman with congestive heart failure comes with a history of failed metformin therapy. The patient does not want to take injections. She is started on Canagliflozin. Which of the following is a side effect of the newly added medication?
questions.solution:
Canagliflozin is an SGLT – 2 inhibitor and is associated with an increased risk of urogenital infections.

SGLT-2 inhibitors reduce glucose levels by selectively inhibiting the sodium-glucose co-transporter 2 in the proximal convoluted tubules of the kidney. This results in increased excretion of glucose which increases the risk of urinary and genital mycotic infections.

The loss of urinary glucose may promote weight reduction which is advantageous to this patient. The glucose-lowering is independent of insulin secretion or sensitivity.

Inhibition of SGLT-2 co-transporter also results in increased sodium excretion, causing diuresis. Although this reduces the systolic blood pressure by 3-6 mm oh Hg and is beneficial in reducing the risk of cardiovascular-related deaths, they might lead to acute kidney injury and should be avoided in patients with renal failure. It may also lead to dehydration, hyperkalemia and worsening of diabetic ketoacidosis.

Other side effects of SGLT-2 inhibitors include an increased risk of fractures, leg and foot amputation with canagliflozin, and a possible increased risk of bladder cancer with dapagliflozin.

Other Options:

Option A: Lactic acidosis is a known complication of biguanides (metformin).

Option B: Weight gain is a complication of sulfonylureas and thiazolidinediones. SGLT-2 inhibitors promote weight loss.

Option D: Thiazolidinediones are associated with worsening of macular edema in some diabetic patients.

questions.text: A 56-year-old man undergoes renal transplantation. Within minutes of completing the anastomosis, the transplanted kidney appears cyanotic & mottled, and it is found to be completely anuric. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this?
questions.solution:
This patient's clinical features are suggestive of Hyperacute rejection. Hyperacute rejection occurs when preformed anti-donor antibodies are present in the circulation of the recipient.

Hyperacute rejection:

  • Occurs within minutes or hours after transplantation.
  • Immunoglobulin and complement are deposited in the vessel wall, causing endothelial injury and fibrin-platelet thrombi.
  • Neutrophils rapidly accumulate within arterioles, glomeruli, and peritubular capillaries.
  • The kidney cortex then undergoes outright necrosis (infarction). Hence the transplant appears cyanotic & mottled.

Related Pearl: Classification of Transplant Rejection Reactions

Hyperacute rejection (minutes to hours):

  • Mechanism: Antidonor antibodies present in the circulation of the recipient
  • Histopathological findings:
    • Grossly, cyanotic and mottled graft with pale white areas
    • Neutrophils accumulate
    • Acute fibrinoid necrosis of vessel walls or complete occlusion by thrombi

Acute rejection (days to weeks):

  1. Acute cellular rejection (acute T cell-mediated rejection):  
    • Mechanism: CD8+ CTLs directly destroy graft or CD4+ cells secrete cytokines that damage graft.
    • Histopathological findings:
      • Tubulointerstitial pattern (type I): extensive interstitial and tubular inflammation associated with focal tubular injury
      • Vascular pattern - Inflammation (type II) and necrosis (type III): Endotheliitis (swollen endothelial cells with lymphocytes between endothelium and vessel wall)
  2. Acute antibody-mediated (humoral) rejection: 
    • Mechanism: antibodies bind to endothelium and activate complement causing damage and graft failure
    • Histopathological findings:
      • Inflammation of glomeruli and peritubular capillaries.
      • Activation of the antibody-dependent classical complement pathway.
      • Focal thrombosis in small vessels. 

Chronic rejection (months to years):

  • Mechanism: T-cells react against alloantigens and secrete cytokines which stimulate fibroblasts and vascular smooth muscle cells (graft arteriosclerosis). Chronic rejection may also be antibody-mediated.
  • Histopathological findings:
    • Predominantly vascular changes (intimal thickening and vascular occlusion)
    • Glomerulopathy with duplication of basement membrane
    • Interstitial fibrosis and tubular atrophy with loss of renal parenchyma

questions.text: A 43-year-old male patient is being evaluated for sweating, palpitations, and pallor that occur a few times a day. He was diagnosed with pheochromocytoma and planned for surgery. Choose the incorrect statement regarding anesthesia for this patient.

choices.text: Ketamine may exacerbate the effects of his condition
Halothane can be used safely in this patient
Vecuronium is safe to use in this patient

questions.solution:
Halothane should not be used in the patient as it sensitizes the heart to the arrhythmogenic effects of epinephrine.

Pheochromocytoma is a condition where the chromaffin tissue, most commonly in the adrenal medulla, produces excessive norepinephrine and epinephrine. 

Other anaesthetic drugs to be avoided in a pheochromocytoma patient are:

  • Succinylcholine - can cause fasciculations which lead to raised intraabdominal pressure and catecholamine release from the tumor
  • Ketamine - as it is sympathomimetic and might exacerbate the effects of adrenergic agonists
  • Anticholinergics and Pancuronium – vagal blockade leading to tachycardia
  • Atracurium – due to histamine release which may provoke catecholamine release. The safest options for these patients would be vecuronium and rocuronium

Other considerations in patients with pheochromocytoma:

  • Phenoxybenzamine, an alpha1-antagonist, which can be administered orally, is often given preoperatively to reverse the vasoconstriction. This results in a drop in arterial blood pressure and a drop in hematocrit
  • Phentolamine is used intraoperatively to control hypertensive episodes
  • A major regional block such as spinal/epidural could block sensory and sympathetic discharge in the area of the surgical field. But catecholamines released from the pheochromocytoma could still bind to receptors all over the body.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with a lump in the upper outer quadrant of the breast. Histopathology showed the following appearance. Which of the following is true about this tumour?
questions.solution:
The histopathological image shows Indian file appearance which is suggestive of lobular carcinoma of the breast. Mutation in CDH-1 gene is associated with lobular carcinoma.

  • Multicentric
  • Pathogenesis: Mutation in CDH-1 gene which encodes for cadherin. Loss of E-cadherin leads to small, monomorphic discohesive cells arranged one after another. This arrangement is called an Indian file/ Single file appearance.
  • Desmoplasia is minimal or absent
  • They are Luminal-A type
  • Excellent prognosis

Note: Mutation in CDH-1 also pose a high risk for gastric signet ring cell carcinoma.

questions.text: According to DeLancey's levels of support of the genital organs, uterosacral ligaments belong to which level of pelvic support?
questions.solution:
According to DeLancey, the uterosacral ligaments and cardinal ligaments belong to level 1.

This dense visceral connective tissue complex maintains the vaginal length and horizontal axis. It allows the vagina to be supported by the levator plate and positions the cervix just superior to the level of the ischial spines. Defects in this support complex may lead to apical prolapse.

Level I support suspends the proximal vagina. Level II support attaches the midvagina along its length to the arcus tendineus fascia. Level III support results from the fusion of the distal vagina with adjacent structures. 

Pubococcygeus is the deepest part of the levator ani muscle. Injury to it can cause enterocele, cystocele, and urethral descent.
