questions.text: A 19-year-old male patient comes to the clinic for follow-up 3 weeks after a traumatic fracture in his right upper limb. On examination, he was found to have a hard palpable mass near the fracture site. X-ray of the area shows the findings below. A histological section shows central fibrous tissue and mature bone at the periphery. Which of the following is true about this patient's diagnosis?

choices.text: It is a type of connective tissue metaplasia
It is a type of connective tissue hyperplasia
It is a type of connective tissue hypertrophy
It is a type of malignant transformation

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario describes a case of traumatic heterotopic ossification. Myositis ossificans is a type of heterotopic ossification which occurs as a result of pathological connective tissue metaplasia.

Metaplasia is a reversible change in which one differentiated cell type (epithelial or mesenchymal) is replaced by another cell type. It usually represents an adaptive response in which one cell type is replaced by another more capable of handling the stressor. Although, in the case of myositis ossificans, it is not clearly seen as an adaptive response.

Common examples of metaplasia include- Barrett's esophagus (squamous epithelium replaced by intestinal-like columnar cells due to chronic gastric reflux), columnar to squamous epithelium in the respiratory tract of chronic smokers.

Connective tissue metaplasia is the formation of cartilage, bone, or adipose tissue (mesenchymal tissues) in tissues that normally do not contain these elements. Myositis ossificans is characterized by heterotopic bone formation within muscle tissue following traumatic injury to the area with hemorrhage into it. Heterotopia refers to the presence of normal cells in abnormal places.

There are three types of heterotopic ossification known

  • Myositis ossificans progressiva: A rare genetic condition with the autosomal dominant transmission with variable penetrance. This leads to recurrent painful soft-tissue swellings. Patients usually die from restrictive lung disease
  • Traumatic myositis ossificans: This case develops after a single blow to the area, a muscle tear, or repeated minor trauma. The painful area gradually develops masses with a cartilaginous consistency and within 4-7 weeks, a solid mass of bone can be felt
  • Neurogenic heterotopic ossification: Heterotopic bone formation around joints, limiting mobility. Seen in patients with traumatic brain or spinal cord injury.

Other options-

Option (B): Hyperplasia is increased cell number in response to hormones and growth factors that occur in tissues whose cells are able to divide and have abundant stem cell reserve. Common examples- female breast during puberty and pregnancy, benign prostatic hyperplasia, etc.

Option (C): Hypertrophy is an increase in cell size and organ size which occurs in response to increased workload in tissues incapable of cell division. Common examples- uterus during pregnancy, cardiac muscle in response to chronic hypertension (due to overload), skeletal muscles in bodybuilders, etc.

Related Pearl: Three point bony relationship in elbow:

The three bony points in the elbow are :

  • Tip of the medial epicondyle
  • Tip of the lateral epicondyle
  • Olecranon

When the elbow is in 90 degrees of flexion, these points form an isosceles triangle. When the elbow is extended, they lie transversely in a straight line.

The three-point bony relationship is maintained in the case of supracondylar fracture of the humerus as the fracture occurs above the level of these bony landmarks.

Conditions where it is distorted:

  • Fracture medial condyle and epicondyle
  • Fracture lateral condyle and epicondyle
  • Intercondylar fracture of humerus
  • Fracture olecranon
  • Elbow dislocation

questions.text: A woman with an obstetric score of G3P2L0 presents with 9 weeks of amenorrhea. She has a history of two pregnancy losses, both of which occurred in the second trimester. What is the next step of management?
questions.solution:
The next step of management in this scenario is an ultrasound scan.

In this scenario of recurrent second-trimester abortions, cervical insufficiency has to be suspected as one of the main causes. Miscarriages due to cervical insufficiency are characterized by painless cervical dilatation and expulsion of the fetus.

According to the RCOG guidelines, women with a current singleton pregnancy and a previous history of 3 or more preterm births or second-trimester miscarriages are offered history-indicated cervical cerclage at 11 to 14 weeks of gestation.

However, before placing a history-indicated cerclage, patients are offered first-trimester ultrasound screening to ensure viability, and singleton pregnancy and to rule out major fetal anomalies.

Women with a singleton pregnancy and a previous history of one preterm birth or second-trimester miscarriage are offered serial ultrasound scans for the measurement of the cervical length and if the cervical length is less than 25mm at less than 24 gestational weeks, an ultrasound-indicated cervical cerclage may be done at 14 to 24 weeks of gestation.

In women with no prior history of preterm birth and incidentally found short cervix, progesterone therapy is preferred over cerclage. 

Causes of mid-trimester Spontaneous Pregnancy Losses:

Fetal Anomalies  Uterine Defects  Placental causes  Maternal Disorder 
Chromosomal aberrations Congenital anomalies Abruptio, Previa Autoimmune syndromes 
Structural abnormalities Leiomyomas  Defective spiral artery formation  Infections
  Incompetent cervix  Chorioamnionitis  Metabolic causes

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman slipped while skiing and fell on an outstretched hand. She complains of pain in her right wrist joint and deformity. Her wrist X-rays are shown below. Which muscle do you think exerts tension on the broken distal fragment of the affected bone?
questions.solution:
The brachioradialis inserts into the lowest part of the lateral surface of the radius just above the styloid process. The radius gets fractured 2 cm above its lower end in a Colle’s fracture, and the insertion of the brachioradialis exerts tension.

Colle’s Fracture

The most common fracture among the older generation is a transverse fracture of the distal end of the radius with dorsal displacement of the distal fragment. It is a fracture at the cortico-cancellous junction, and the distal fragment may collapse into extension, dorsal displacement, radial tilt, and shortening.

Management -

  • Undisplaced fracture - immobilisation in a below-elbow plaster cast for six weeks
  • Displaced fractures - manipulative reduction followed by immobilisation in Colles' cast in palmar flexion, pronation, and ulnar deviation.
  • Comminuted fractures -  transfixed percutaneously using two K-wires  

Injuries occurring due to fall on the outstretched hand 

  • Clavicle fracture

questions.text: A patient developed a thyroid storm following radioiodine treatment. During the management, he is being given 5 drops of potassium iodide every 6 hours. This inhibits thyroid hormone synthesis by:
questions.solution:
Potassium iodide inhibits thyroid hormone synthesis by Wolff- Chaikoff effect. Large doses of iodide inhibit organic binding of the iodide and hence decrease thyroid hormone synthesis.

Other options:

Option A: Jod-Basedow phenomenon is the increased synthesis of thyroid hormone following exposure to iodine.

Option C: Second wind phenomenon is seen in patients with McArdle disease. After a short break from strenuous exercise, the patients can continue exercise without pain

Option D: Thyrotoxicosis factitia is the ingestion of excess thyroid hormone leading to thyrotoxicosis.

Related Pearl: Thyroid storm / Thyrotoxic crisis:

It is an emergency caused by an acute exacerbation of hyperthyroidism. 

Precipitating factors:

  • When a thyrotoxic patient has been inadequately prepared for thyroidectomy
  • Abrupt cessation of antithyroid medications
  • Stress
    • Infection
    • Thyroid or non-thyroid surgery
    • Trauma in patients with untreated thyrotoxicosis
  • Acute iodine load
    • Amiodarone administration 
    • Exposure to iodinated contrast agents
    • Following RAI therapy

Clinical features:

  • Fever
  • Tachycardia
  • Altered mentation (delirium, psychosis, coma)
  • GI symptoms (nausea, vomiting, diarrhoea)
  • Atrial fibrillation and cardiac failure - most common causes of death

questions.text: Which of the following is the first line drug of choice in a patient with myasthenia gravis?
questions.solution:
Pyridostigmine is the first-line drug of choice in the treatment of symptomatic myasthenia gravis.

Treatment for myasthenia gravis involves:

  • Symptomatic treatment: Anticholinesterase agents – Pyridostigmine is the initial therapy of choice.
  • Chronic immunomodulating therapy: Glucocorticoids (prednisone) and immunosuppressive drugs (azathioprine, mycophenolate mofetil, cyclosporine) implemented in patients significantly symptomatic on pyridostigmine.
  • Rapid immunomodulating treatment: IVIG and therapeutic plasma exchange—Used to tide over severe illness (myasthenic crisis) and as 'bridge' therapy before surgery, or starting chronic immunomodulating treatment.
  • Surgical approach: Thymectomy

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl complains of lower abdominal pain. History reveals she has mild pain around the time of ovulation every month and the pain subsides within a few hours. Pelvic examination is normal. How will you manage the condition?
questions.solution:
Acute lower abdominal pain around ovulation that typically subsides within a few hours indicates ovulatory pain or Mittelschmerz syndrome. It is treated conservatively with rest and NSAIDs such as acetaminophen.

The pain has been hypothesised to be due to the following reasons:

  • Swelling of the ovarian follicles around the time of ovulation
  • Disruption of the ovarian surface epithelium during ovulation
  • Irritation of the peritoneum by blood from ruptured Graafian follicle
  • Contraction of ovarian smooth muscle and ligaments
  • Contraction of the fallopian tube

The pain may be one sided or bilateral. When one sided, it can be used to predict the ovary involved in ovulation.

questions.text: A young man brings his wife to the psychiatrist, saying she has had spells of uncontrollable overeating followed by self-induced vomiting at least 1-2 times every week for the past four months. There is no history of restriction of food intake, and her body mass index is found to be 19 kg/m2.  What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis based on the given clinical history of binge eating followed by self-induced vomiting, with weight within the normal range, is bulimia nervosa.

Bulimia nervosa is marked by episodes of binge eating in individuals with a morbid fear of being fat. This is followed by compensatory behaviours such as self-induced vomiting, laxative abuse, and the use of enemas. This is done to prevent weight gain. This pattern is seen at least once a week for ≥3 months. It is commonly seen in women. The weight is usually within the normal range. In some cases, the patients are obese or underweight. Sexual activity remains unaffected, unlike anorexia nervosa patients, who are usually not interested in sex.

It can be treated with cognitive-behavioural therapy (CBT) and pharmacotherapy. CBT involves disrupting the cycle of repeated binge eating-purging and changing the patient's beliefs about food, body weight, and body image. Important drugs used in the treatment of bulimia nervosa are fluoxetine, imipramine, desipramine, trazodone, and monoamine oxidase inhibitors.

Other options:

Option A: Anorexia nervosa is diagnosed by the presence of restriction of food intake that leads to significantly low body weight. Intense fear of gaining weight or persistent behaviour that interferes with weight gain is seen.

Option C: Avoidant food intake disorder is commonly seen in infancy or early childhood. It is characterized by a lack of interest in eating food. This is based on the sensory features of food or the perceived consequences of eating. The patients have significant nutritional deficiencies.

Option D: Binge eating disorder is characterized by recurrent episodes of binge eating without the recurrent use of compensatory behaviours.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male patient, a known case of colon carcinoma came to the hospital with complaints of loss of appetite for 3 months.  Which of the following drugs is best suited to be prescribed in this patient to increase appetite?
questions.solution:
Cyproheptadine has an appetite-stimulating effect and has been used to promote weight gain in poor eaters.

It mainly blocks 5 hydroxytryptamine receptors and also has H1 antihistaminic and sedative properties. Side effects include drowsiness, dry mouth, ataxia and weight gain.

Loratidine, Cetirizine and Azelastine are second generation antihitamines.

Loratidine (option A) is a long acting H1 antihistamine and is useful in urticaria and atopic dermatitis

Cetirizine (option B) inhibits release of histamine and cytotoxic mediators from platelets and has superior efficacy ion urticaria and atopic dermatitis. 

Azelastine (option C) inhibits the intracellular adhesion molecule (ICAM-1) on nasal mucosa and is useful in allergic rhinitis.

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy is brought in cardiopulmonary arrest to the ER, the EMT has tried to gain venous access for the past 1 minute, but in vain. It is decided to get access through the following method. Which of the following is true regarding resuscitation using this route?

choices.text: Only emergency epinephrine can be given through this route
Only blood products and fluids can be administered through this route
Any medications, blood products, and fluids can be administered
Only fluids to be given through this route

questions.solution:
The given image shows intraosseous cannulation for fluid transfusion in the anterior proximal tibia. Any and all medications, blood products, and fluids can be administered through this route.

The intraosseous route is an alternative to the intravenous (IV) route in the transfusion of fluids in shock. 

  • The marrow of long bones has a rich network of vessels that drain into a central venous canal, emissary veins, and ultimately the central circulation.
  • So, the bone marrow functions as a non-collapsible venous access route.

Intraosseous cannulation is recommended for patients in whom IV access proves difficult or unattainable. (e.g., in cardiopulmonary arrest). In such a case, if venous access is not available within 1 min, an intraosseous needle should be placed in the anterior proximal tibia.

Complications are uncommon, but may include osteomyelitis with prolonged infusions and tibial fracture.

questions.text: A first-year medical student is performing the following test on a given urine sample in the biochemistry lab. The urine sample is heated with BaSO4. The reagent, a solution of ferric chloride is added to the adsorbed precipitate. The positive test would indicate the presence of which of the following?
questions.solution:
The given biochemical test is Fouchet's test. It is used for detecting the presence of bile pigments in urine. 

In Fouchet's test, urine is heated with barium sulfate which adsorbs bilirubin. Ferric chloride is added which oxidizes the adsorbed bilirubin to biliverdin which produces a green color.

Principle for all tests to detect bile pigments: Oxidizing agents readily oxidize bilirubin to biliverdin to form a green color.

Other tests for Bile pigments:

  • Ehrlich's aldehyde reagent test - Bile pigments react with para dimethyl amino benzaldehyde to form a red color. 
  • Gmelin's test -  Nitric acid is used as the oxidizing agent. 
  • Schlesinger's test - Zinc ions are used as oxidizing agents.

questions.text: A randomized control trial showed an effective treatment against a disease and it was then incorporated by a hospital. Which of the following is subsequently expected to happen?
questions.solution:
A new effective treatment for a disease would reduce the duration of the disease, thereby reducing prevalence.

Related Pearl: Incidence and Prevalence

  • Incidence in Epidemiology:

Incidence is the number of new cases occurring in a defined population during a period of time. The incidence rate is expressed in person-time units, usually per 1000 per year. It is given by the following formula:

It is generally used for acute illnesses. It provides insight into the effectiveness of health services and programs. Incidence can be determined from cohort studies and longitudinal studies.

The incidence rate of spells of sickness =  (Number of spells of sickness starting in the specified period/Mean number of people exposed to that risk in the specified time) x 1000.

Special types of incidence rates:

1. Attack rate: It is used when there is a risk for a limited period of time.

2. Secondary attack rate: It is the number of exposed persons developing the disease within the range of incubation period following exposure to a primary case.

  • Prevalence in Epidemiology:

Prevalence is the proportion of all cases, old and new, of a particular disease at a given point in time or over a period of time in a given population. It is a proportion, not a rate or ratio. Prevalence is always expressed in percentage.

It is given by the formula:

It is useful to determine the magnitude of health problems. It can be determined from cross-sectional studies.

Types:

1. Point prevalence is the prevalence at a point in time. Usually, prevalence is point prevalence unless otherwise specified.

2. Period prevalence is the prevalence over a period of time.

Relationship between Incidence and Prevalence:

Prevalence depends upon incidence and duration.

Prevalence = Incidence x Mean Duration

Longer the duration of the disease, the greater the prevalence.

Few examples:

  • In acute diseases, because of rapid recovery/death prevalence will be relatively lower than incidence. This is because, in some diseases (eg. food poisoning), the disease is so short-lived, there are no "old cases".
  • In chronic diseases like TB, prevalence will be higher than incidence.
  • If a new treatment for a disease is effective, incidence does not change but prevalence decreases as the duration of disease decreases.
  • If the treatment only prevents death but doesn’t cure the disease, it may cause a paradoxical increase in prevalence.

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy was brought to the clinic with complaints of a nose bleed. Examination of the nose with a speculum reveals the source of bleed in the anteroinferior septum. The bleeding is controlled by sitting upright, bending forward, and pinching the nose. Which among the following is the artery that does not contribute to the formation of the vascular anastomosis that is most likely involved in this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
The posterior ethmoidal artery does not contribute to the formation of Kiesselbach’s plexus. Kiesselbach’s plexus is the vascular anastomosis situated in the Little’s area, a region in the anteroinferior part of the septum above the vestibule. It is the commonest site for epistaxis.

The posterior ethmoidal artery is a branch of the ophthalmic division of the internal carotid artery, which supplies the nasal septum but does not contribute to Kiesselbach’s plexus.

The contributing arteries of the Kiesselbach's plexus are -

  • Sphenopalatine artery
  • Greater palatine branches of the maxillary artery, which is a branch of the external carotid artery.
  • Septal branch of the superior labial artery, which is a branch of the facial artery which in turn is a branch of the external carotid artery.
  • Anterior ethmoidal branch of the ophthalmic division of internal carotid artery.

Trotter’s method in which the patient is made to sit, leaning a little forward over a basin to spit any blood and breathe quietly from the mouth is the first step to control epistaxis.

questions.text:
Given below is an image showing the biochemical mechanism of the fungal cell wall and the various target checkpoints affected by the antifungals. Match the different cases to the drug of choice.

Case 1: A 32-year-old woman presents to the OPD with complaints of vaginal discharge, dysuria, and intense itching. A wet smear with 10% KOH solution shows budding yeast cells.

Case 2: A patient presents with fever for 1 week, with abdominal distension, loss of appetite, and lymphadenopathy. There is a poor response to antibiotics and antimalarials. The Widal test is negative but rk39 is positive. 

Case 3: A 48-year-old woman presented with yellowish discoloration of toenails. The discoloration spread proximally as a streak in the nail and later the entire nail was affected. Gradually, the entire nail became brittle and separated from the nailbed. 

Case 4: A 50-year-old diabetic woman with dermatophyte infection of the scalp was started on an oral drug, she presents today with symptoms suggestive of porphyria.
questions.solution:
The correct answer is 1-D, 2-C, 3-B, 4-A. 

Case 1:

The clinical symptoms of vaginal discharge associated with thick curdy white precipitate and the smear of vaginal discharge showing budding yeast cells are suggestive of a Candida infection. A single dose of fluconazole 150 mg can treat this condition effectively. It acts by inhibiting ergosterol synthesis (Path D).

Azole group of antifungal are grouped into two types :

  • Imidazole- clotrimazole, ketoconazole ,luliconazole
  • Triazole- Itraconazole, fluconazole, voriconazole, posaconazole, and isavuconazole

Triazoles act by inhibition of ergosterol synthesis. The azole group inhibits the fungal cytochrome P450 enzyme called 14-α-sterol demethylase and results in an impairment of conversion of lanosterol to ergosterol. This results in the depletion of membrane ergosterol.

Candida is a gram-positive yeast-like fungus. The diagnosis of candidal infection can be confirmed by microscopic examination of smear of vaginal discharge with 10% KOH solution, which dissolves all other cellular debris leaving behind mycelia and spores of candida.

The image shows candida in Gram's satin of vaginal smear. 

 

 

Case 2:

This patient should be managed with liposomal amphotericin B (Drug C). It acts by forming pores in the fungal cell membrane.

This is a case of visceral leishmaniasis, and it presents with fever associated with rigor and chills. Splenomegaly and hepatomegaly are common. Lymphadenopathy is common in most endemic regions, but in the Indian subcontinent, it is rare. 

Diagnosis is by ELISA and the indirect immunofluorescent antibody test (IFAT) and rk39 which detects antibodies to Leishmania donovani. 

Medical Therapy :

In most endemic regions (except in India and Mediterranian countries):

  • Pentavalent antimonial is the drug of choice (sodium stibogluconate or meglumine antimoniate)
  • If initial pentavalent antimonial fails, then amphotericin B (AmB) is used.

In India and Mediterranian countries:

  • Liposomal AmB is the drug of choice.

Other drugs used in the treatment of visceral leishmaniasis include: paromomycin and miltefosine.

Case 3: 

Tinea unguium or onychomycosis is defined as the infection of the nail plate by fungus. Trichophyton rubrum accounts for most cases, but many fungi may be causative. Oral terbinafine is the treatment of choice for Tinea unguium or onychomycosis and works by inhibition of ergosterol synthesis. 

Squalene epoxidase is an enzyme that converts squalene to squalene epoxide (Path B). Terbinafine acts as a non-competitive inhibitor of “squalene epoxidase”, an early step enzyme in the synthesis of fungal ergosterol. This results in the accumulation of sterol squalene which is toxic to the organism.

Clinical features: A yellowish discoloration occurs, which spreads proximally as a streak in the nail. Later, subungual hyperkeratosis becomes prominent and spreads until the entire nail is affected. Gradually, the entire nail becomes brittle and separated from its bed as a result of the piling up of subungual keratin.

Diagnosis is made by KOH mount examination of clippings or curettings that include dystrophic subungual debris.

Oral Terbinafine at 250 mg/day is given for a duration of 6 weeks for fingernails infection and 3 months (12weeks)  for toenails infection.

           FIRST LINE DRUG                   DURATION
 Oral Terbinafine - 250mg/day

Fingernails - 6weeks.

Toenails - 12weeks
Oral Itraconazole- 400mg/day for 1week

Fingernails - regimen repeated every month for 2 to 3 months

Toenails - regimen repeated every month for 3 to 4 months
  • Second-line drug: Oral Griseofulvin dose 1 g/day for 4–8 months (longer for toenails)
  • Topical treatment with amorolfine or ciclopirox olamine can be used in mild infections affecting the distal nail plate only or non‐linear superficial onychomycosis.

Case 4:

For dermatophytic infections of the scalp, the first line of therapy includes Topical Azoles. But in this case, she was started on an oral drug. The most effective oral anti-fungal against the dermatophytes infections of hair and scalp is Griseofulvin. Griseofulvin is known to precipitate porphyria. 

Griseofulvin acts by inhibiting microtubule assembly (Path A).

questions.text:
Given below is an image of the oldest non-service type of latrines in India and few statements regarding the same. Pick out the correct statements.
  1. The image shows a bore-hole latrine.
  2. It was introduced in the 1930s to combat hookworm infections.
  3. No special staff is needed for upkeep as after using the latrine is closed and another hole is dug elsewhere.
  4. Fly breeding is common and the soiled mass is a source of infection
  5. A special equipment called auger is used to dig a borehole latrine
questions.solution:
The correct answer is 1, 2, 3 and 5.

The oldest non-service type of latrines in India is the borehole latrine and was introduced in the 1930s to combat hookworm infections. Special equipment called auger is used to dig a borehole latrine.

Advantages

  • No special staff is needed for upkeep as after using the latrine is closed and another hole is dug elsewhere
  • As the pit is dark, the breeding of flies is less. Anaerobic digestion of the nightsoil converts it into a harmless mass
  • No water pollution when located far from a water source.

Demerits:

  • It fills up rapidly
  • Augers may not be readily available
  • Difficulty in digging deeper holes in areas of loose soil and high subsoil water levels

questions.text:
An elderly man underwent Roux-en-Y gastric bypass surgery for obesity. He now presents to his physician with complaints of dizziness, fatigue, and tremors 2 hours after the ingestion of a carbohydrate-rich meal. His symptoms occur mainly due to
  1. Hypoglycemia
  2. Small volume of food intake
  3. High osmotic load of food
  4. Increased release of insulin
  5. Increased release of glucagon
questions.solution:
The patient is presenting with features of late dumping syndrome following Roux-en-Y gastric bypass surgery. This occurs due to an increased release of insulin and hypoglycemia.

Dumping syndrome occurs due to rapid gastric emptying. It is commonly seen following gastric surgeries. It can be divided into

  • Early dumping syndrome- Occurs after ingestions of foods with a high osmotic load. Increased osmotic load in the intestine leads to the sequestration of fluid from the circulation into the gastrointestinal tract. Patients will develop hypovolemia and hypotension.
  • Late dumping syndrome- Occurs after ingestion of a large volume of meals and meals which are rich in carbohydrates. A large amount of glucose is absorbed from the intestine which leads to a rapid increase in blood sugar levels. This in turns results in increased release of insulin which causes hypoglycemia. 

The mainstay in the management of dumping syndrome is dietary manipulation. The patient is advised to have small volume, regular meals that are rich in protein, fat, and low in carbohydrates. Somatostatin analogue like octreotide is used in the management of intractable syndromes.

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman presents with acute onset of blurry vision in the right eye since morning. She also complains of pain on movement of the right eye for two days. questions.solution:
The image depicts a Relative Afferent Pupillary Defect. This finding along with the clinical scenario is suggestive of an acute relapse of multiple sclerosis, and methylprednisolone is used for immediate management.

The patients' symptoms of blurry vision and pain on movement of the eye are suggestive of optic neuritis. The above image shows a relative afferent pupillary defect (Marcus-Gunn pupil) on the swinging flashlight test. On shining the torchlight to the normal eye, both the pupils constrict due to intact direct and indirect light reflexes to the stimulus carried by the normal optic nerve. On swinging and shining the torchlight to the diseased eye, both the pupils appear to dilate. This is due to the damage to the optic nerve carrying the afferent fibers in the diseased eye, resulting in the loss of direct and indirect light reflexes. This phenomenon is seen in cases of unilateral optic nerve damage, like in this patient's optic neuritis.

High-dose intravenous methylprednisolone 1000 mg daily for five days is the drug of choice for acute exacerbation of multiple sclerosis.

Other options:

Options B and C: Plasma exchange can be used for an acute relapse of MS but is not the first preferred treatment. It can be used along with steroids or in case of poor response to steroids. Beta Interferon can be used in relapsing MS to slow the attack rate and reduce disability. It is not suitable for an acute episode of optic myelitis.

Option D: Acyclovir is an antiviral and is not effective in the treatment of optic neuritis due to acute MS. 

2017 revised, McDonald’s criteria is used in the diagnosis of multiple sclerosis. The McDonald’s criteria takes into consideration the clinical attacks and objective lesions. In addition, it also involves an assessment of the lesions based on MRI and other imaging techniques.

questions.text: All of the following are health care delivery indicators, except _______.
questions.solution:
Bed turnover ratio is an example of utilization rates of health services, not a health care delivery indicator.

The provision of health care and the equity of distribution of health resources in different parts of the country are reflected by health care delivery indicators.

Examples are:

  • Doctor-population ratio
  • Doctor-nurse ratio (option D)
  • Population-bed ratio (option C)
  • Population per health/ subcentre
  • Population per trained birth attendant (option A)

Utilization of services is expressed as the proportion of people in need of a service who receive it in a given period. It is considered to be indicative of the health status of the population.

The following are utilization rates:

  • The proportion of infants immunized against 9 diseases in the expanded program on immunization (EPI)
  • The proportion of women receiving antenatal care and supervised delivery 
  • Percentage of population using family planning methods
  • Bed occupancy rate
  • The average length of stay
  • Bed turnover ratio

questions.text: A factory worker at a plastic pipe factory presented with weight loss and abdominal pain in the right upper quadrant for the last 6 months. He had hepatomegaly. CT abdomen revealed that most of the liver was infiltrated by contrast-enhanced mass and the presence of thorium was detected. What is the most likely diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
The clinical picture of the factory worker with upper quadrant abdominal pain, hepatosplenomegaly, and the CT inference suggest angiosarcoma of the liver.

Angiosarcoma of the liver is usually seen in individuals having occupational exposure to agents such as vinyl chloride, arsenic, or thorotrast. The gross specimen of the liver shows greyish-white lesions, with multiple reddish-brown hemorrhagic foci and several blood-filled spaces. CT is the preferred investigation and it reveals infiltrating contrast-enhanced mass diffusely spread over the liver. Thorium is picked up in the CT due to the presence of heterogeneously enhanced attenuation in the liver, perihepatic area, and spleen.

Option A: Cavernous hemangiomas appear as red-blue, soft nodules, usually less than 2 cm in diameter. Their clinical significance is that they might be mistaken radiographically or intraoperatively for metastatic tumors. Peripheral filling at the delayed phase of the contrast administration is a typical finding in this condition as the tumor is more in the periphery of the liver.

Option B: Metastatic tumor of the liver can be differentiated from primary HCC on a CECT. There is no enhancement or enhancement less than the surrounding liver following contrast.

Option D: Primary hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) has a delayed arterial filling phase and washes out rapidly in a CECT. It also shows a wedge-shaped perfusion abnormality in the CT due to arterioportal shunts. 

Related Pearl: Liver tumors - commons

  • Most common tumor overall: Metastatic tumor
  • Most common primary benign tumor: Cavernous hemangioma
  • Most common primary malignant tumor: Hepatocellular carcinoma
  • Most common primary malignant liver tumor of early childhood: Hepatoblastoma
  • Most common tumor associated with arsenic / vinyl chloride: Angiosarcoma
  • Most common tumor associated with oral contraceptive / anabolic steroid: Hepatic adenoma
  • Most common tumor rupture spontaneously causing hemoperitoneum: Hepatic adenoma

questions.text: Given below is a dissected compartment of the leg. The nerve supplying these muscles does not give articular branches to?
questions.solution:
The deep peroneal nerve does not give articular branches to the 2nd metatarsophalangeal joint. 

The above image shows the anterior compartment of the leg. The deep peroneal nerve is the nerve of the anterior compartment of the leg and the dorsum of the foot. It is one of the two terminal branches of the common peroneal nerve arising between the neck of the fibula and peroneus longus.   • Extensor digitorium  longus

The 2nd metatarsophalangeal joint is supplied by the medial plantar nerve.

questions.text: A woman with HIV was brought in to the emergency ward after an episode of generalized tonic-clonic seizures. An MRI  revealed multiple enhancing lesions. A stereotactic biopsy of the lesion was done and the image is given below. Which of the following test can be used for the diagnosis of the organism?
questions.solution:
The above image (showing lymphocytes, macrophages, and eosinophils surrounding the toxoplasmosis bradyzoites encased in cysts with a cyst wall) and the case scenario suggest that the most likely diagnosis is cerebral toxoplasmosis. Sabin Feldman dye test is a serological test done for the detection of antibodies against Toxoplasma.

Cerebral toxoplasmosis is an opportunistic infection commonly found in the setting of HIV-associated immunosuppression and usually occurs in patients with CD4+ T cell counts <200/μL. Toxoplasmosis of the CNS produces brain abscesses, which are found most often in the cerebral cortex (near the grey-white junction) and deep grey nuclei.

  • Acute lesions exhibit central necrosis, petechial hemorrhages surrounded by acute and chronic inflammation, macrophage infiltration, and vascular proliferation. Both free tachyzoites and encysted bradyzoites may be found at the periphery of the necrotic foci.
  • Chronic lesions consist of small cystic spaces containing scattered lipid and hemosiderin-laden macrophages that are surrounded by the gliotic brain.

Sabin Feldman dye test is a serological test done for the detection of antibodies against Toxoplasma. IIF, IHA, and CFT (component fixation test) are also used for the diagnosis of toxoplasmosis. The dye test remains positive throughout life, while CFT becomes negative soon after acute infection. ELISA is most commonly used and IgM and IgG antibodies are estimated separately.

Standard treatment is sulfadiazine/pyrimethamine & leucovorin for a minimum of 4–6 weeks.

Primary Prophylaxis:

  • Prior toxoplasmic encephalitis and CD4+ T cell count <200/μL: Sulfadiazine/pyrimethamine and leucovorin
  • TOXO IgG antibody positive and CD4+ T cell count <100/μL : Trimethoprim/sulfamethoxazole (TMP/SMX)
  • The drug of choice for toxoplasmosis in pregnancy is spiramycin.

Other options:

Option A: Casoni’s test is used for Hydatid cysts.

Option B: Bachman test is used for Trichinellosis.

Option D: Montenegro test is used for Leishmaniasis.

questions.text: A young man, who is a known alcoholic, complains of difficulty maintaining balance while turning. On examination, you note an abnormal gait, as shown below. What is the cause for this abnormality?
questions.solution:
Cerebellar ataxia, otherwise known as cerebellar gait ataxia, is the likely cause of this abnormality. Here, the patient is seen attempting tandem walking and displays improper heel-toe coordination, erratic foot placement, and truncal swaying.

Cerebellar gait ataxia leads to walking with a wide base of support, lurching strides, lateral instability of the trunk, and erratic foot placement. There is a loss of balance when attempting to walk on a narrow base. A difficulty to maintain balance when turning occurs as an early feature. Falling occurs as a late feature.

Causes of cerebellar ataxia include stroke, alcohol, trauma, tumor, hereditary cerebellar degeneration, Wilson's disease, and neurodegenerative disorders like multiple-system atrophy (MSA). 

Other options:

Option A: Patients with sensory ataxia walk unsteadily with multiple falls, on a narrow base, and tend to look down while walking. They lose balance on walking with their eyes closed or in the dark. Joint sense and vibration sense are diminished. Dorsal column lesions of the spinal cord result in sensory ataxia. Vitamin B12 deficiency is a treatable cause of sensory ataxia.

Option C: Frontal gait is a shuffling, freezing gait that includes a wide base of support, a short stride, shuffling along the floor, and difficulty with starts and turns. Many patients exhibit difficulty with gait initiation which is descriptively characterized as the “slipping clutch” syndrome or gait ignition failure. It is commonly seen in the elderly.

Option D: Spastic gait is characterized by stiffness in the legs, and a tendency to circumduct and scuff the feet. It is associated with an imbalance in muscle tone. Upper motor neuron signs can also be seen. Lesions in the corticospinal tract result in spastic gait.

questions.text: A middle-aged male patient is posted for an inguinal hernia operation. The anesthetist intends to use a regional anesthesia technique that blocks the nerves in the anterior abdominal wall. Between which of the following structures would the anesthetist be injecting the drug mixture?

choices.text: Between internal oblique and external oblique
Between internal oblique and rectus abdominis
Between internal oblique and transversus abdominis

questions.solution:
The local anesthetic is injected between the internal oblique and transversus abdominis muscles in the anterior abdominal wall. This is because the neurovascular plane of the abdominal wall lies between these two muscles.

The transversus abdominis plane (TAP) block is a regional anesthetic technique for abdominal surgery. 

The neurovascular plane of the abdominal wall lies between the internal oblique and transversus abdominis in the anterior abdominal wall.

The plane contains:

  • Lower 6 thoracic nerves (T7-12)
  • Iliohypogastric nerves
  • Posterior intercostal and subcostal vessels
  • Anastomosis between superior and inferior epigastric arteries

questions.text: A 32-year-old male patient is brought to the emergency room with symptoms of confusion, visual changes, palpitations, and diaphoresis. His family recounts that he has had similar episodes that subside after consuming chocolates. Further workup shows the histopathological finding below. Which of the following is true about this patient's condition?

choices.text: C-peptide levels will be low in this patient
Amyloid deposition is a characteristic feature

questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette describes an insulinoma and amyloid deposition is a characteristic feature of this condition.

This patient presents with characteristic neuroglycopenic (confusion, visual change, and unusual behavior) and sympatho-adrenergic symptoms (palpitations, diaphoresis, and tremulousness) of hypoglycemia. The image shows neoplastic cells that are monotonous with minimal pleomorphic or mitotic activity. Deposition of amyloid is a characteristic feature of insulinomas.

β-cell tumors (insulinomas) are the most common pancreatic endocrine neoplasms. These are usually benign and often cause symptomatic hypoglycemia. Hypoglycemic symptoms appear when blood glucose levels fall below 50mg/dl. The symptoms usually develop after fasting or exertion and improve after glucose intake.

The most reliable test for diagnosis is a supervised 72-hr fasting test. Blood examinations reveal increased insulin-to-glucose ratio, high circulating levels of insulin, and c-peptides. Insulinomas may occur in association with gastrinomas in patients with MEN 1 syndrome.

Histopathological examination shows giant islets, with preservation of the regular cords of monotonous cells with minimal pleomorphism. Malignant tumors are also well-differentiated. Amyloid deposition is a characteristic feature of many insulinomas.

Surgery is the mainstay of treatment. Medical treatment includes frequent meals and diazoxide or octreotide.

Islet hyperplasia (previously known as nesidioblastosis) is seen in maternal diabetes, Beckwith–Wiedemann syndrome , and rare mutations in the β-cell K+-channel protein or sulfonylurea receptor.

In maternal diabetes, the fetal islets respond to hyperglycemia by increasing their size and number. In the postnatal period, these hyperactive islets may be responsible for serious episodes of hypoglycemia.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with lower abdominal pain, increased frequency of micturition, and pain during sex that extends to the vulva and vagina. The pain increases when the bladder is full. Cystoscopy shows fissures and punctate hemorrhages in the bladder mucosa as shown in the image below and marked submucosal edema of the bladder. Biopsy reveals mucosal ulceration and increased numbers of mucosal mast cells. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features are characteristic of interstitial cystitis or chronic pelvic pain syndrome.

Interstitial cystitis is a rare idiopathic condition that occurs most frequently in women presenting as intermittent severe suprapubic pain, urinary frequency, urgency, hematuria, and dysuria. Hunner ulcers are characteristic ulcers seen in interstitial cystitis. It is characterized by marked submucosal edema of the bladder with mucosal ulceration, seen in the late phase of interstitial cystitis.

Cystoscopic findings show fissures and punctate hemorrhages (glomerulations) in the bladder mucosa. Microscopically, mucosal ulceration is covered by fibrin, necrotic material, and increased numbers of mucosal mast cells. The pathologic findings are nonspecific, and the main role of biopsy is to rule out carcinoma in situ, which may mimic interstitial cystitis clinically. Late in the course, transmural fibrosis may appear, leading to a contracted bladder.

Other options:

Option A: Malakoplakia is an inflammatory reaction caused by defects in phagocyte function. It occurs during chronic bacterial infections. On cystoscopy, it appears as soft, yellow, raised mucosal plaques 3-4cm in diameter with large aggregates of foamy macrophages.

Option B: Transitional cell carcinoma of the bladder or urothelial neoplasms are the most common bladder tumors. Morphological variants include papillary, nodular, or flat lesions. 

Option C: Follicular cystitis is characterized by multiple lymphoid follicles in the bladder mucosa or underlying wall.

questions.text:
An 82-year-old man complains of increased fatigue, low-grade fevers, and night sweats. Physical examination reveals several small, rubbery, mobile supraclavicular lymph nodes. They are non-tender. A lymph node biopsy shows findings as shown in the image below. Which of the following are true regarding this condition?
  1. It is a neoplasm of B-cell origin
  2. HIV infection is a risk factor
  3. It is rare in the younger population
  4. The first line of treatment is the ABVD regimen 
  5. The first line of treatment is CHOP regimen
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette with the lymph node biopsy showing a classical Reed-Sternberg cell is suggestive of a diagnosis of Hodgkin's lymphoma. Statements 1,2 and 4 are correct regarding Hodgkin's lymphoma.

Reed Sternberg cell: It is a giant cell. It has a classic owl-eyed appearance due to the presence of a symmetric or mirror image bilobed nucleus with prominent nucleoli surrounded by a clear space.

Hodgkin's lymphoma -

  • It is of B-cell origin (Statement 1)
  • It has a bimodal distribution of age at diagnosis, with one incidence in young adults in their twenties and another incidence in older patients in their eighties. (Statement 3)
  • Typical presentation involves lymphadenopathy/mass with B symptoms which include fever, night sweats, and weight loss
  • HIV infection is a risk factor. Another virus that has been implicated in the pathogenesis of Hodgkin's lymphoma is the Epstein-Barr virus (EBV). Further EBV can be detected in almost all cases of HIV-associated Hodgkin's lymphoma. (Statement 2)
  • Majority of the patients can be treated with chemotherapy and radiotherapy or chemotherapy alone. The most widely used chemotherapy regimen in Hodgkin's lymphoma is the ABVD regimen (Doxorubicin (Adriamycin), Bleomycin, Vinblastine, and Dacarbazine). (Statement 4)

Note: R-CHOP (Rituximab + Cyclophosphamide, Doxorubicin, Vincristine (Oncovin), and Prednisone) regimen is used in the treatment of Non-Hodgkin's lymphoma.

Related Pearl: Important Features of the Different Types of Hodgkin's Lymphoma (HL)

Classic subtypes

  • Nodular sclerosis 
  • Mixed cellularity 
  • Lymphocyte-rich
  • Lymphocyte depletion

Non-Classical subtype

  • Lymphocyte predominant

Note: Mixed cellularity is most commonly associated with HIV due to its high incidence.

questions.text:
A young man brings his mother with complaints that she is not speaking to anyone for the past two days. She was diagnosed with a major depressive disorder 5 months before and is undergoing treatment. During the interrogation, you notice that the patient is not replying to your questions. She is not even moving her arms or limbs. However, she has kept her right hand raised with palms facing the ceiling and is maintaining that posture during the interrogation. What are the findings found in this patient?
  1. Stereotypy
  2. Stupor
  3. Mutism
  4. Posturing
  5. Catalepsy
questions.solution:
The clinical features are diagnostic of catatonia in this patient. The patient has the features of stupor, mutism, and posturing.

Catatonia is a clinical syndrome characterized by striking behavioral abnormalities that may include motoric immobility or excitement, profound negativism, or echolalia (mimicry of speech), or echopraxia (mimicry of movement).

Causes of catatonia- Several psychiatric illnesses, medical conditions, and medications can cause catatonia. Important ones are:

  • Mood disorders- Major depressive disorder
  • Schizophrenia
  • Medical conditions- nonconvulsive status epilepticus, encephalitis 
  • Metabolic abnormalities- hepatic encephalopathy, hyponatremia, and hypercalcemia 
  • Medications- corticosteroids, immunosuppressants, and antipsychotic drugs

The clinical features of catatonia are:

  • Stupor -no psychomotor activity
  • Catalepsy- passive induction of a posture held against gravity. Eg. if the examiner changes the position of a limb, the patient stays in that position for a long time.
  • Waxy flexibility- slight, even resistance to positioning by the examiner
  • Mutism- no, or very little, a verbal response to instructions or external stimuli
  • Negativism- opposition or no response to instructions or external stimuli
  • Posturing- spontaneous and active maintenance of a posture against gravity. Patient themselves maintain that position.
  • Mannerism- odd, circumstantial caricature of normal actions
  • Stereotypy- repetitive, abnormally frequent, non-goal-directed movements
  • Agitation, not influenced by external stimuli
  • Grimacing
  • Echolalia-mimicking another's speech
  • Echopraxia- mimicking another's movement

The presence of three or more of these features is required for a diagnosis of catatonia.

Treatment- The primary treatment of catatonia is to identify the underlying cause and treat it. Benzodiazepines like lorazepam can be used in the treatment. Electroconvulsive therapy can be used in the management of life-threatening catatonia.

questions.text: The risk of which complication of suction evacuation is reduced by the usage of these plastic instruments?
questions.solution:
Karman’s type suction cannulas made of plastic, reduce the risk of uterine perforation during suction evacuation procedures.

There are different sizes of the Karman's suction cannula. The size to be used depends on the duration of the pregnancy in weeks. Size 4-7 mm can be used for 4-6 week period of gestation, size 5-10 mm can be used for 7-9 weeks, and 8-12 mm can be used for 9-12 weeks. The plastic cannula allows visualization of the products being evacuated.

Suction evacuation is a procedure by means of which products of conception are sucked out of the uterus with a cannula attached to a suction apparatus. 

Indications:  

  • 1st-trimester medical termination of pregnancy 
  • Inevitable abortion 
  • Recent incomplete abortion 
  • Hydatidiform mole 

Procedure: 

  1. Vaginal examination is done to assess the size and position of the uterus and the state of the cervix
  2. Posterior vaginal speculum held by an assistant
  3. Grasp the anterior lip of the cervix with an Allis forceps
  4. Introduce a uterine sound to determine the length of the cavity and position of the uterus
  5. Dilate the cervix if required until one size less than that of the suction cannula
  6. Administer intravenous methergine 0.2mg
  7. Insert suction cannula with the tip in the middle of the uterine cavity
  8. Increase the pressure to 400-600mmHg. Move the cannula up and down and rotate it 360 degrees with the pressure on. 
  9. Inspect the suction bottle of products of conception and blood loss.
  10. Regulate the suction with a finger over the hole at the base of the cannula
  11. Break the vacuum before withdrawing the cannula
  12. Curette the uterus at the end of the suction and reintroduce the cannula to remove remnants. 

Suction is stopped when no more material is sucked out, there is gripping of the cannula by the uterus, a grating sensation, or appearance of bubbles in the cannula. 

Complications of suction evacuation:

Immediate:

  • Excessive hemorrhage due to incomplete evacuation or atonic uterus.
  • Injury due to cervical lacerations of varying degree which may lead to the formation of a broad ligament hematoma and uterine perforation. 
  • Shock due to excessive blood loss, anesthesia complications, or cervical shock—vasovagal syncope due to cervical stimulation. 
  • Perforation—injury to major blood vessels, bowel or bladder
  • Sepsis—endometritis, myometritis, pelvic peritonitis. 
  • Hematometra 
  • Increased morbidity
  • Continuation of pregnancy (failure) – 1%.

Late: 

  • Pelvic inflammation 
  • Infertility 
  • Cervical incompetence 
  • Uterine synechiae
  • Subsequent pregnancy risks- preterm labor, ectopic pregnancy.

Related Pearl: Instruments in OBG

questions.text:
A patient presents with erythematous streak-like lesions on the trunk, as shown in the image given below. What is the most likely etiology for his presenting complaints?

IKBKG - Inhibitor of nuclear factor kappa B kinase regulatory subunit gamma

NEMO - Nuclear factor-kappa B essential modulator

choices.text: Mutation in IKBKG gene encoding NEMO

questions.solution:
The image in the clinical scenario above shows flagellate erythema. It is seen as a side effect of bleomycin chemotherapy. 

Flagellate erythema is characterized by multiple red, macular streaks of erythema on the trunk and limbs. The streaks are aligned in a criss‐cross pattern, giving a whip-like or flagellate appearance. They may be sore or pruritic. 

Flagellate erythema is seen in

  • A side effect of bleomycin chemotherapy
  • The toxic effect after consumption of shitake mushrooms
  • Dermatomyositis
  • Adult-onset Still’s disease
  • Docetaxel therapy

It is self-limiting and usually resolves within a few days to weeks. Topical steroids and oral antihistamines can be given to relieve the associated pruritis.

Other options:

Option A: Chemotherapy with doxorubicin causes hyperpigmentation. Although erythematous streaks may occur at the site of infusion, generalized flagellate erythema is usually not seen. Cardiotoxicity is the most significant side effect of doxorubicin chemotherapy.

Option C: Burrowing of hookworm larvae in the skin causes a creeping eruption characterized by linear twisting and winding lesions mainly on the feet and hands as shown in the image given below.

Option D: Mutation in IKBKG gene encoding NEMO is responsible for incontinentia pigmenti. It follows 4 stages of cutaneous lesions—erythematous vesicular rash, verrucous lesions, hyperpigmented whorls, and atrophic streaks. Lesions are seen along the lines of Blaschko. 

The image given below shows the hyperpigmented whorl stage (stage 3).

questions.text: An 80-year-old woman with a background of moderate aortic stenosis presents with a 2-week history of fatigue, weight loss, and night sweats. She gives a history of nausea and altered bowel habits. Blood tests reveal a Hb level of 9.9 g/dL, white cell count of 16.0 × 10^9 /L and CRP level of 187 mg/L. Blood cultures were taken on admission and she was started on empirical antibiotics. TTE demonstrated aortic valve vegetations. Blood cultures revealed Streptococcus gallolyticus. What other investigations must be done considering the culture results?
questions.solution:
Colonoscopy must be done in this patient.

questions.text: A middle-aged man is diagnosed with primary open-angle glaucoma and is started on latanoprost. It lowers the intraocular pressure mainly by which of the following mechanisms?
questions.solution:
Latanoprost is a prostaglandin analogue. It lowers intraocular pressure (IOP) mainly by increasing the uveoscleral outflow. 

Prostaglandin analogs are the preferred drugs used in the management of primary open-angle glaucoma. They have largely replaced beta blockers because of fewer systemic side effects (like an exaggeration of bronchoconstriction in asthma), once-daily dosing, and increased potency in lowering the IOP. Commonly used prostaglandin analogs are latanoprost,travoprost, bimatoprost, and tafluprost. 

The common ocular side effects are conjunctival hyperemia, eyelash thickening, and iris hyperpigmentation. They can increase the incidence of cystoid macular edema following cataract surgery. They can aggravate anterior uveitis and herpetic keratitis.

Alpha receptor agonists like epinephrine, apraclonidine, and brimonidine also increase the uveoscleral outflow.

Other options:

Option A: Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors, alpha-receptor stimulators, and beta-blockers reduce IOP by decreasing aqueous production. 

Options C and D: Cholinergic agonists cause the contraction of the ciliary muscles, which increases the trabecular outflow by releasing the pupillary block. In angle-closure glaucoma, cholinergic agents open the angle by contraction of the sphincter pupillae pulling the iris away from the trabecula (releasing the pupillary block).

Related Pearl: Antiglaucoma drugs: Mechanism of lowering intraocular pressure (IOP) at a glance

Drugs that increase trabecular outflow

  • Miotics (e.g., pilocarpine)
  • Epinephrine, dipivefrine
  • Bimatoprost
  • Rho-kinase inhibitor (Netarsudil)

Drugs that increase uveoscleral outflow

  • Prostaglandins (latanoprost)
  • Epinephrine, dipivefrine
  • Brimonidine
  • Apraclonidine

Drugs that decrease aqueous production

  • Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors (e.g., acetazolamide, dorzolamide)
  • Alpha receptor stimulators in ciliary process (e.g., epinephrine, dipivefrine, clonidine, brimonidine, apraclonidine)
  • Beta-blockers

Hyperosmotic agents - (e.g., glycerol, mannitol, urea)

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman presents to the emergency room with complaints of watery diarrhea for the last 5 days. She recently finished a course of antibiotics for cellulitis. Diagnosis is made based on stool antigen testing and she is started on vancomycin to treat her condition. Her symptoms resolve but she presents 3 weeks later with recurrence of the same symptoms and the recurrence is diagnosed again with antigen testing. Which of the following can be used to manage this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette describing a case of watery diarrhea after recent use of antibiotics with resolution after treatment with vancomycin indicates a diagnosis of Clostridioides(formerly Clostridium) difficile colitis. The management for the first recurrence is a tapered oral vancomycin regimen.

Clostridioides difficile(C. diff) colitis:

Clinical features can range from asymptomatic carriage to fulminant colitis. 

  • Nonsevere disease - Watery diarrhea (≥3 loose stools in 24 hours) is the cardinal symptom. Other manifestations include lower abdominal pain and cramping, low-grade fever, nausea, anorexia, mucus, or occult blood in the stool. Physical examination may demonstrate lower abdominal tenderness. Unexplained leukocytosis in hospitalized patients (even in the absence of diarrhea) may reflect underlying CDI
  • Severe colitis - Clinical manifestations of severe colitis include diarrhea, lower quadrant or diffuse abdominal pain, abdominal distention, fever, hypovolemia, lactic acidosis, hypoalbuminemia, elevated creatinine, and marked leukocytosis.
  • Fulminant colitis - Characterized by hypotension or shock, ileus, or megacolon.
  • Recurrent disease - resolution of CDI followed by recurrence of symptoms within two to eight weeks after treatment has been stopped 

Either a positive nucleic acid amplification test (NAAT) for C. difficile toxin B gene or a positive stool test for C. difficile toxin(s) are used for diagnosis of both primary and recurrent infections. An X-ray may be needed in cases of severe diseases and endoscopic examination may be warranted where direct visualization is needed where other diagnoses are suspected. 

Management of nonsevere to severe initial disease:

Nonsevere disease

Supportive clinical data: White blood cell count ≤15,000 cells/mL and serum creatinine <1.5 mg/dL
  • Vancomycin 125 mg orally 4 times daily for 10 days, OR
  • Fidaxomicin 200 mg orally twice daily for 10 days
  • If above agents are unavailable: Metronidazole 500 mg orally 3 times daily for 10 days

Severe disease

Supportive clinical data: White blood cell count >15,000 cells/mL and/or serum creatinine ≥1.5 mg/dL		  
  • Vancomycin 125 mg orally 4 times daily for 10 days, OR
  • Fidaxomicin 200 mg orally twice daily for 10 days

Management of recurrent disease:

First recurrence
  • If vancomycin was used for the initial episode: Vancomycin pulsed-tapered regimen:
    • 125 mg orally 4 times daily for 10 to 14 days, then
    • 125 mg orally twice daily for 7 days, then
    • 125 mg orally once daily for 7 days, then
    • 125 mg orally every 2 or 3 days for 2 to 8 weeks, OR
    • Fidaxomicin 200 mg orally twice daily for 10 days
  • If fidaxomicin or metronidazole was used for the initial episode: Vancomycin 125 mg orally 4 times daily for 10 days
Second or subsequent recurrence  
  • Vancomycin pulsed-tapered regimen (outlined above), OR
  • Fidaxomicin 200 mg orally twice daily for 10 days, OR
  • Vancomycin followed by rifaximin:
    • Vancomycin 125 mg orally 4 times per day for 10 days, then
    • Rifaximin 400 mg 3 times daily for 20 days, OR
  • FMT

Management of fulminant disease - 

Initial episode
  • Enteric vancomycin plus parenteral metronidazole:
    • Vancomycin 500 mg orally or via nasogastric tube 4 times daily, AND
    • Metronidazole 500 mg intravenously every 8 hours
  • If ileus is present, additional considerations include:
    • FMT (administered rectally)
    • Rectal vancomycin (administered as a retention enema 500 mg in 100 mL normal saline per rectum; retained for as long as possible and readministered every 6 hours)
Recurrent episode  
  • Antibiotics as for initial fulminant episode above
  • Some favor FMT in the context of a first or second recurrence that presents as a fulminant episode

NOTE: IV Vancomycin is not recommended in the treatment of C. difficle. Oral Vancomycin or vancomycin enema are the preferred routes of administration as Vancomycin is not absorbed by the intestinal mucosa and is available to act directly at the site of infection.

questions.text: A 33-year-old lady comes with a history of  7 weeks of amenorrhea, severe left-sided pelvic pain, and spotting PV. She gives a history of an IUCD inserted 3 years back, after her first pregnancy. A urine pregnancy test is weakly positive.  The findings of ultrasound and Doppler studies are shown below. What is true about the patient's condition?

choices.text: Salphingitis isthmica nodosa is associated with a higher incidence of the condition
Passage of a decidual cast rules out the given condition
The only treatment for it is surgical management
Doubling of beta-HCG values in 48 hours is highly suggestive of the condition

questions.solution:
Salpingitis isthmica nodosa is associated with a higher incidence of ectopic pregnancy.

This is a case of ectopic pregnancy, with the ultrasound color Doppler showing the ring-of-fire appearance in tubal ectopic pregnancy.   

Salpingitis isthmica nodosa is an inflammatory condition of the fallopian tube, characterized by nodular thickening of its isthmic portion. Histologically, the proliferation of smooth muscle and diverticula of tubal epithelium contribute to this thickening. This condition typically develops bilaterally. Since the tubal anatomy is altered, there is an increase in the risk of ectopic pregnancy.

The passage of a decidual cast is suggestive of ectopic pregnancy (Option B). The decidual cast has a smooth glistening inner surface and a shaggy maternal surface. The chorionic villi are absent.

Beta-HCG doubles every 2 days in a normal pregnancy (Option D). If the level does not rise or rises by less than 66% from the previous reading, it is suggestive of ectopic pregnancy. Beta-HCG in the urine and serum, empty uterus, adnexal mass, and free fluid in the peritoneal cavity is pathognomonic of an ectopic pregnancy. The ring of fire can be seen with color doppler imaging placental blood flow within the periphery of an ectopic pregnancy. 

Ectopic pregnancy can be managed with the following interventions: (Option C)

  • Expectant management: Ectopic pregnancies measuring <3 cm and with declining beta-hCG levels initially <1500 mIU/mL may resolve without inter­vention and can be managed expectantly. 
  • Medical management with single or multiple-dose methotrexate. Methotrexate(MTX) can be given as a single IM or as a multiple-dose regimen on days 1, 3, 5, and 7.
  • Surgical management for indicated cases is done with salpingectomy or salpingostomy.

Related Pearl: Beta hCG in pregnancy

The pattern of beta hCG :

First detectable in plasma 7 to 9 days post-LH surge
          ⇓
Doubles every 2 days
          ⇓
Peaks at 8 to 10 weeks of gestation(~100 IU/mL)
          ⇓
Begins to decline at 10 to 12 weeks
          ⇓
Plateau at 16 weeks till term
 
  • Higher maternal plasma hCG levels- Multifetal pregnancy, erythroblastosis fetalis, gestational trophoblastic disease, Down syndrome.
  • Lower hCG plasma levels -early pregnancy wastage and ectopic pregnancy.

questions.text: A 62-year-old male came with the ocular finding as shown in the given image. Which of the following is responsible for the disease process in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given condition is Band-shaped keratopathy and is due to the calcium deposition on the cornea.

The deposition is seen on the Bowman's layer, epithelial basement membrane, and the anterior stroma.

Causes:

  • Ocular
    • Chronic anterior uveitis (particularly in children)
    • Phthisis bulbi
    • Silicone oil in the anterior chamber
    • Chronic corneal oedema 
    • Severe chronic keratitis
  • Metabolic (metastatic calcification). This is rare and includes increased serum calcium and phosphorus, hyperuricemia, and chronic renal failure.
  • Hereditary causes include familial cases and ichthyosis.

Treatment

  • Chelation using topical ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid (EDTA) 1.5–3.0% until all calcium has been removed.
  • Photorefractive keratectomy (PRK) using excimer laser.

questions.text:
Observe the following image and choose the correct statements about the drug X.
  1. It is metabolized by butyrylcholinesterase 
  2. Patients with multiple sclerosis who are administered this drug will experience hyperkalemia
  3. Tachycardia is a common cardiac dysrhythmia seen in children
  4. History of malignant hyperthermia is a contraindication to its use
  5. Sugammadex reverses the effect of this drug
questions.solution:
Statements 1, 2, and 4 are correct regarding the above image. The image shows the train-of-four stimulation (TOF). The image shows that following the administration of a muscle relaxant, the amplitude of all four twitches has declined to a similar extent. This is the pattern of depolarizing muscular block, which is seen characteristically in succinylcholine. 

TOF is a pattern of nerve stimulation used to monitor neuromuscular blockade. It consists of four supramaximal stimuli delivered no more than 10 seconds apart. It is calculated by dividing the amplitude of the fourth response by the amplitude of the first response and requires an objective measure of the response to stimulation. The TOF count denotes the number of detectable evoked responses, and it correlates to the degree of neuromuscular block

With depolarizing block, as in SCh, phase 1 will show a decrease in amplitude in all four twitches simultaneously, but no progressive decline in amplitude. If repeated doses or a prolonged infusion is given, phase 2 blockade with progressive decline in amplitude will be seen.

Succinylcholine is a depolarizing muscle relaxant. It acts by depolarizing the muscle similar to the action of acetylcholine. However, compared to acetylcholine, it acts for a longer duration and causes flaccid paralysis. It has a faster onset and shortest duration. It is administered intravenously. If there is no access to veins, it can also be administered intramuscularly.

It is metabolized by butyrylcholinesterase (also known as pseudocholinesterase or plasma cholinesterase). In patients with deficiency of this enzyme, the recovery from this agent may be delayed.

It is extensively used in the clinical setting for rapid sequence intubation due to its short onset of action

Important side effects of these drugs are malignant hyperthermia, rhabdomyolysis, fasciculations, bradycardia, and hyperkalemia. Conditions like neuromuscular diseases involving denervation like multiple sclerosis, muscular dystrophy, stroke, rhabdomyolysis, burns, and pre-existing hyperkalemia can further aggravate hyperkalemia.

Succinylcholine is absolutely contraindicated in patients with a history of malignant hyperthermia. 

Sugammadex does not reverses the effect of succinylcholine.

Related Pearl: Types of muscle relaxants

There are 2 types of muscle relaxants: depolarizing and non-depolarizing.

Depolarizing Muscle Relaxant- Succinylcholine

Non-Depolarizing Muscle Relaxants:

  • Ultra short-acting (<10 minutes) - Gantacurium
  • Short-acting (10-20 minutes) - Mivacurium
  • Intermediate-acting (20-50 minutes)
    • Atracurium
    • Cisatracurium
    • Vecuronium
    • Rocuronium
  • Long-acting (>50 minutes)
    • Pancuronium
    • Doxacurium
    • Pipecuronium

Related Pearl: Side effects of succinyl choline

The following are the side effects of succinyl choline:

  • Cardiovascular effects:
    • Sinus bradycardia
    • Junctional rhythms
    • Ventricular dysrhythmias
  • Hyperkalemia
  • Myalgia
  • Masseter spasm: Succinyl choline can trigger malignant hyperthermia
  • Increased intracranial pressure: Succinylcholine may lead to an activation of the EEG and slight increases in CBF and ICP in some patients.
  • Increased intraocular pressure
  • Increased intragastric pressure

A 20-year-old primigravida has conceived recently. She is anxious about this pregnancy and is eager to educate herself with regards to proper antenatal care and wants to keep herself informed of the precautions and health concerns during her pregnancy. Her primary care physician enrolled her in a program where she would receive a pre-recorded interactive voice response to her phone call helping her with information about pregnancy and her routine antenatal care. Given below are five statements with regards to the scheme. Pick out the incorrect statements.
  1. This service is named Pregnancy tracker.
  2. It is a pre-recorded interactive voice response delivered from the date the patient registers herself.
  3. Each interaction call is for 5 minutes.
  4. This service is available in five languages and the patient can opt for their preferred dialect and language in which they are comfortable.
  5. This service comes under the newer initiatives of the RCH program.
questions.solution:
The incorrect statements include 1, 2, 3, 4, 5. 

Kilkari Scheme:

  • It is a new initiative under the National Rural Health Mission (NRHM).
  • It is an Interactive pre-recorded Voice Response (IVR), which gives information to pregnant women about pregnancy and child health-care, covering the expected events beginning from the 4th month of conception till the child is one year-old.
  • Each call is for 2 minutes.
  • Services are available in all states in their regional dialects.

Pregnancy Tracking:

It is a new initiative under the Reproductive and Child Health Program (RCH- Phase II). It allows screening of all pregnant women and focuses on reducing mortality rates.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old businessman comes to the emergency room with fever, cough, and shortness of breath one week after he returned from a Mediterranean cruise where he dined on board and used the swimming pools and hot tubs for over 7 days. He also complains of abdominal pain and diarrhea. The patient has a 15 pack-year smoking history. Physical examination reveals bronchial breath sounds in the left lower lung fields. Which of the following is the gold-standard for diagnosis in this patient?
Vital Signs  
Temperature 99°F
Pulse Rate 90/minute
Respiratory Rate 17/minute
Blood Pressure 140/90 mm Hg
SpO2 98% on room air

 

Laboratory investigation Values Normal Range
Sodium (mEq/L) 125 135-145
Aspartate aminotransferase (U/L) 75 8-48
Alanine aminotransferase (U/L) 90 7-55

choices.text: Direct flouroscent antibody staining of sputum

questions.solution:
This clinical vignette describes a case of Legionnaire's disease caused by Legionella pneumophila and the gold standard for diagnosis is culture and sensitivity.

Clinical presentations:

  • Pneumonia caused by Legionella is clinically similar to pneumonia caused by other organisms
  • Patients typically present with fever, cough, and shortness of breath
  • Symptoms occur about 2-10 days after the exposure to contaminated water or soil (as in this patient on the cruise ship)
  • Patients may also have abdominal symptoms such as diarrhea and abdominal pain
  • A physical examination will show bronchial breath sounds, rales, and other signs of consolidation
  • Labs will show hyponatremia and elevated hepatic transaminases

Risk factors for this condition:

  • Contamination of water supplies in large facilities such as hospitals, hotels, or apartment buildings
  • Contaminated water sources such as hot tubs, birthing pools, and fountains
  • Patient factors such as old age, smoking, chronic lung, cardiovascular or renal disease, impaired cell-mediated immunity
  • Failure to respond to beta-lactam antibiotics

Diagnosis:

 

Culture and Sensitivity - Isolation and culture of Legionella organisms from respiratory secretions is the gold standard of diagnosis. The use of multiple selective BCYE medium provides maximum sensitivity. Antibiotics added to the medium suppress the growth of competing flora from nonsterile sites and helps in choosing the appropriate sensitive antibiotic for treatment.

Urinary antigen testing is fast, reliable, cost-effective, and highly specific for Legionella pneumophilia serotype 1. It is recommended to be performed in all patients with community-acquired pneumonia suspected of having Legionnaire's disease. However, it is limited as it is not reliable for the other serotypes.

Antibody serology is not specific for Legionnaire's pneumonia due to cross-reactivity between the various serotypes and certain gram-negative bacteria. It is useful in confirming Legionnaire's disease in cases where isolation of specimen is difficult.

The Direct Fluorescent Antibody (DFA) stain is rapid and highly specific. However, it is less sensitive than culture because large numbers of organisms are required for microscopic visualization. This test is more likely to be positive in advanced than in early disease.

questions.text: 40-year-old man goes on a camping vacation with his family. Two days after swimming in a freshwater lake near the campsite, he develops nausea and vomiting and starts to behave irrationally. His family takes him to the emergency department, where blood samples are taken and a spinal tap is performed. He is diagnosed with a rapidly progressing meningoencephalitis and dies shortly thereafter. Which of the following was most likely the cause of the man’s illness?
questions.solution:
This clinical vignette is strongly suggestive of primary amoebic meningoencephalitis (PAM) is most likely due to the organism Naegleria fowleri, a pathogenic free-living amoeba. 

It mostly affects previously healthy young adults or children. The infection sets in acutely following swimming or diving in ponds or other warm, freshwater bodies. The incubation period varies from 2 days to 2 weeks.

They are free-living amoeba and exist in three forms - cyst, ameboid trophozoite form, and flagellate trophozoite form.

The amoeba invades the nasal mucosa and passes through the olfactory nerve branches in the cribriform plate into the meninges and brain to initiate acute purulent meningitis and encephalitis or primary amoebic meningoencephalitis (PAM).

Clinically, patients present with anosmia during the incubation period. Following this, the disease advances rapidly, causing fever, headache, vomiting, neck stiffness, ataxia, seizures, and coma. It is fatal in the majority of cases and death usually occurs within one week.

Microscopic analysis of CSF will reveal motile amoeboid trophozoites.

Treatment is with intravenous amphotericin B, which is the drug of choice. 

Other options-

Option B: Acanthamoeba is also a free-living amoeba. These organisms may also cause granulomatous amebic encephalitis, an infection of the brain and spinal cord. It usually occurs in immunocompromised patients and the incubation period and course of illness are typically slow. These features are in contrast to this patient's acute presentation and rapid deterioration, thereby suggesting another diagnosis.

Option C: Cryptosporidium species are implicated in causing traveler's diarrhea in immunocompromised patients. 

Option D: Entamoeba Histolytica is intestinal amoebae that are transmitted feco-orally. They are implicated in amoebic colitis and amoebic liver abscess.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female patient experienced a complete loss of vision following a functional endoscopic sinus surgery for chronic ethmoidal sinusitis. Which of the following air cells are in close anatomical proximity to the structure most likely injured in this patient?
questions.solution:
The structure most likely injured in this patient is the optic nerve and the Onodi cell is in close proximity to it.

Onodi cell is an anatomical variant, in which the posterior ethmoidal cells enlarge and extend into the sphenoid bone laterally and superior to the sphenoid sinus. The sphenoid sinus is in close relation to the optic nerve and sometimes the carotid artery. Therefore, while removing posterior ethmoidal cells during endoscopic surgery, the presence of Onodi cells increases the risk to the optic nerve.

Ethmoidal sinuses are air-containing cavities that are present in the lateral mass of the ethmoid bone. They are bound medially by the lateral nasal wall, laterally by a thin plate of bone called the lamina papyracea, and superiorly by an extension of the orbital plate of the frontal bone. 

The ethmoid sinusoidal air cells range from 3 to 18 in number and are divided into anterior and posterior groups by a basal lamina.

  • Anterior cells- They open into the middle meatus. They contain-
    • Agger nasi cells - Present in the agger nasi ridge
    • Ethmoid bulla - Forms the posterior boundary of hiatus semilunaris
    • Supraorbital cells
    • Frontoethmoid cells- In the area of the frontal recess
    • Haller cells - In the floor of the orbit. Lies in the roof of the maxillary sinus, and enlargement may prevent drainage of the maxillary sinus.
  • Posterior cells - They open into the superior or the supreme meatus. Occasionally, they may also open directly into the sphenoid sinus. They contain about 1-7 cells, the most important one being the Onodi cells. Onodi cells extend as far back as 1.5 centimetres from their anterior wall.

The image shown below shows the location of the Onodi cell or the sphenoethmoidal cell.

Haller cell (infraorbital ethmoidal air cell) which is an anterior ethmoidal air cell that pneumatizes into the roof of maxillary sinus or orbital floor above the maxillary sinus ostium.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy presents with the passage of blood-colored urine, pain during micturition, and increased frequency of urination for the last 2 days. After further investigations, he is diagnosed with acute hemorrhagic cystitis caused by adenovirus. Which of the following characteristics correctly describes this causative agent?
questions.solution:
This is a case of acute hemorrhagic cystitis, which is caused by adenovirus—a naked double-stranded DNA virus. 

Acute hemorrhagic cystitis is a viral urinary tract infection. It presents with cystitis and gross hematuria. 

Adenovirus types 7, 11, 34, and 35 are the common serotypes associated with this disease and can be recovered from the blood and urine of patients with hemorrhagic cystitis.
