questions.text:
Identify the condition in which the given findings are seen.

Platelet counts-Normal

BT-Increased

questions.solution:
The given findings of increased BT and normal PT, aPTT is suggestive of Platelet aggregation disorders. Decreased CD41 and CD61 (Glycoprotein IIb/IIIa) is suggestive of Glanzmann Thrombasthenia.

Glanzmann thrombasthenia is an autosomal recessive disease which occurs due to inherited deficiency of GpIIb-IIIa. There is normal platelet morphology and normal platelet count, prolonged bleeding time, absent or decreased clot retraction, and normal platelet aggregation in the presence of ristocetin. Acquired GT is seen with platelet transfusions, immune thrombocytopenic purpura, non-Hodgkin’s lymphoma, multiple myeloma, myelodysplastic syndrome, hairy cell leukaemia, and acute lymphoblastic leukaemia.

questions.text:
Which of the following are components of the P-SPIKES protocol for communicating bad news to the patient?
  1. Assess the family's perception of her current medical status and her cancer diagnosis.
  2. Empathize with the family's feelings and provide them emotional support.
  3. Prepare yourself mentally to discuss and break the news.
  4. Schedule a follow-up meeting in a day to re-assess their needs and to provide them with additional information on the developments in the case.
  5. Prepare an appropriate setting for discussion.
questions.solution:
The correct answer is 1, 2, 3, 4, 5.

P -SPIKES protocol is for breaking bad news.

Each letter represents a phase in the six-step sequence.

  • P - Preparation - mentally preparing yourself for the interaction
  • S - setting
  • P - perception
  • I - invitation or information
  • K - knowledge
  • E - empathy
  • S - summarizing or strategize (includes scheduling follow-up visits when needed)

Key components of the SPIKES strategy include demonstrating empathy, acknowledging and validating the patient's feelings, exploring the patient's understanding and acceptance of the bad news, and providing information about possible interventions.

questions.text:
A 40-year-old injection drug user is admitted to the hospital after several weeks of fever and dizziness. He is found to have cellulitis in his right arm, on which a large area is inflamed and oozing. The cardiac evaluation demonstrates an abnormal EKG and systolic murmur. Cultures reveal gram-positive cocci in pairs and short chains which form non-hemolytic colonies on sheep blood agar containing 6.5% NaCl. Which of the following is correct about the bacterium responsible for the systolic murmur?

Statement A- The isolate is bacitracin sensitive

Statement B- The isolate is coagulase-positive

Statement C- The isolate is PYR positive

Statement D- The organism shows growth in 40% bile

Statement E- The isolate is Optochin sensitive

choices.text: Statements A, B, C and D are correct
Statements B, C, D and E are correct
Statements B, C and D are correct
Statements C and D are correct

questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette and the organism described as gram positive cocci in pairs and short chains that grows in 6.5% NaCl is strongly suggestive of endocarditis due to enterococcus. They belong to the streptococcaceae family. Among the given options, statements C and D are correct.

They belong to Lancefield group D and can cause urinary tract infections, endocarditis (as in this patient), and suppurative infections. Features of enterococci include-

  • They typically appear as pairs of oval cocci
  • They are usually non-hemolytic, though some strains may show alpha or beta hemolysis
  • On MacConkey medium, they produce tiny magenta pink colonies
  • They are catalase-negative
  • They are PYR positive
  • They are relatively heat-resistant, surviving at 60°C for 30 minutes
  • They can grow in the presence of 40% bile
  • They can grow in 6.5% sodium chloride
  • They can withstand a pH of 9.6
  • They can grown in 0.1% methylene blue milk.

Staphylococcal species such as Staphylococcus aureus is coagulase-positive.

Streptococcus pneumoniae is optochin sensitive.

questions.text: A 38-year-old G3P2L2 presents at 9 weeks of amenorrhea. She was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus 6 months ago. You inform her about the importance of blood sugar control and about the fetal anomalies that can occur due to diabetes. Which of the following is true about this disease?

choices.text: Poor glycemic control can cause spontaneous abortions in 1st trimester
Diabetic complications cannot be avoided by better glycemic control
Neonatal hypoglycemia is not seen in these cases
Microsomia incidence increases when blood glucose is elevated

questions.solution:
This patient who was diagnosed with diabetes mellitus 6 months before her pregnancy has pregestational diabetes mellitus. Poor glycemic control can lead to 1st-trimester abortions. Women with HbA1c >12% and/or fasting blood sugars of >120mg/dl have an elevated risk of early pregnancy loss.   

Overt diabetes in pregnancy is defined as hyperglycemia that was first recognized during pregnancy that meets the thresholds of diabetes in non-pregnant adults. Pregestational diabetes is diagnosed when women are known to have diabetes before pregnancy. Gestational diabetes is when women are diagnosed to have diabetes during pregnancy that is not clearly overt. 

Poorly controlled diabetes mellitus during pregnancy can lead to complications in the fetus and mother. These include: 

  • Fetal effects: 
    • Spontaneous abortions
    • Preterm delivery
    • Malformations
    • Altered fetal growth
    • Unexplained fetal demise
    • Hydramnios
  • Neonatal effects: 
    • Respiratory distress syndrome
    • Hypoglycemia
    • Hypocalcemia
    • Hyperbilirubinemia and polycythemia
    • Cardiomyopathy
    • Long term cognitive development
    • Increased risk to develop diabetes
  • Maternal effects: 
    • Preeclampsia
    • Diabetic nephropathy
    • Diabetic retinopathy
    • Diabetic neuropathy
    • Diabetic ketoacidosis
    • Infections

Many complications of pregestational diabetes that occur in pregnancy can be prevented by periconceptional glycemic control. It is advisable to get the blood sugars under control before planning pregnancy as the risk of complications can be markedly reduced.  The complication risk is also related to the degree of underlying cardiac and renal disease.   

Poorly controlled overt diabetes, preconceptionally and during early pregnancy, is responsible for elevated fetal malformation risk. This risk is higher than in gestational diabetes which causes high sugars later in the pregnancy. Fetal macrosomia is seen with gestational diabetes, risk of malformations is quite low.

Neonatal hypoglycemia is seen in both overt and gestational diabetes mellitus. Chronic maternal hyperglycemia can cause hyperplasia of fetal beta-islet cells causing hyperinsulinemia and hypoglycemia.  

Note: Macrosomia is seen in infants of diabetic mothers, not microsomia.

questions.text:
Match the lupus nephritis lesions with their treatments.
1. Focal Lupus Nephritis a. Only supportive treatment, no specific therapy
2. Membranous Lupus Nephritis b. A short course of high-dose corticosteroids
3. Mesangial Proliferative Lupus Nephritis c. Hemodialysis
4. Advanced Sclerosing Lupus Nephritis d. Corticosteroids+ Immunosuppressants +/- ACEs/ARBs
questions.solution:
The correctly matched pairs are 1-b, 2-d, 3-a, 4-c.

Lupus nephritis is a serious complication of systemic lupus erythematosus, seen in about 30-50% of patients with SLE. Renal involvement may be in the form of glomerulonephritis or tubulointerstitial nephritis. Glomerular lesions develop due to the deposition of the circulating immune complexes on the glomerular basement membrane, mesangium, and/or throughout the glomerulus.

Management of lupus nephritis:

  • Class I (minimal mesangial) and II lesions (mesangial proliferative): They are associated with minimal or no symptoms and have an excellent prognosis. They do not require any therapy. 
  • Class III lesions (focal lupus nephritis): They are associated with few symptoms and a good prognosis. Management includes the administration of a short course of high-dose corticosteroids or other immunosuppressive agents.
  • Class IV lesions (diffuse lupus nephritis): Manifestations include hematuria, nephrotic-range proteinuria, and renal casts. Treatment includes the administration of high-dose steroids combined with either cyclophosphamide or mycophenolate mofetil for 2–6 months. It is followed by maintenance therapy with lower doses of steroids and mycophenolate mofetil or azathioprine.
  • Class V lesions (membranous lupus nephritis): They are associated with severe manifestations and a poor prognosis. Management includes the administration of steroids in combination with other immunosuppressive agents. Inhibitors of the renin-angiotensin system may be administered to attenuate proteinuria.
  • Class VI lesions (advanced sclerosing lupus nephritis): They present with end-stage renal disease (ESRD) and require hemodialysis.

questions.text: A 6-month-old baby was brought to the clinic with failure to thrive. On examination,  generalized hypotonia and hepatomegaly were present. A chest X-ray image shows massive cardiomegaly. Microscopy of a muscle biopsy shows vacuolations. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Type II (Pompe's disease) glycogen storage disease is the most probable diagnosis from the above-given clinical scenario.

The clinical symptoms are hypotonia (floppy infant), hepatomegaly, hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, and chest X-ray image shows cardiomegaly, which is characteristically seen in Pompe's disease. The muscle biopsy showing vacuoles further aids the diagnosis. 

Pompe disease (glycogen storage disease type II) is due to the deficiency of the enzyme lysosomal acid alpha-glucosidase. The affected child usually dies around the age of 2 years due to heart failure.

The enzyme replacement therapy (ERT) for Pompe disease is the recombinant enzyme a-glucosidase alfa (Myozyme).

questions.text:
A 3-year-old female child is brought to the pediatrician for evaluation of regressing developmental milestones. Genetic studies show mutations in the MECP2 gene. Choose the correct statements about this patient's progressive neurologic developmental disorder from those below.
  1. This disorder is inherited in an X-linked recessive manner
  2. Abnormal respiration with periods of hyperventilation is characteristic
  3. There will be a progressive increase in head circumference
  4. Occurs predominantly in females
  5. Most patients will have a history of perinatal birth trauma
questions.solution:
Statements 2 and 4 are correct.

Mutations in the MECP2 gene are associated with Rett's syndrome. This disorder occurs almost exclusively in females and abnormal respiration with periods of hyperventilation are characteristic. 

Features of Rett Syndrome:

  • Apparently normal prenatal and perinatal period and apparently normal psychomotor development through the first 5 months and normal head circumference at birth
  • Deceleration of head growth between 5 months and 4 years and loss of acquired purposeful hand skills between 5 and 30 months of age
  • Most cases are caused by mutations in the MECP2, which maps to Xp28 and is inherited in an X-linked dominant
  • The typical manifestations include loss of spoken language (communication via eye gaze, body language, and facial expressions), motor dysfunction (stereotypic hand movements and gait disturbance). The stereotypic hand movements include opposition of hands, finger kneading, rubbing, twisting, and pill-rolling. The gait is broad-based, clumsy, and ataxic. These patients also have scoliosis, growth failure with the deceleration of head growth, feeding impairment, epilepsy, cardiac abnormalities, bone mineral deficit, autonomic dysfunction, disorders of respiratory control (episodes of hyperventilation with concomitant hypocapnia alternating with hypoventilation and/or apnea), sleep disturbance
  • The exclusion criteria include brain injury secondary to trauma (perinatal or postnatal), neurometabolic, or severe infection that causes neurologic problems and grossly abnormal psychomotor development in the first six months of life

 

Under DSM-V, Rett Syndrome is diagnosed as an autism spectrum disorder. World Autism Awareness Day is observed annually on April 2nd to highlight the need to help improve the quality of life of those with autism so they can lead meaningful lives as an integral part of society and also to address stigmatization and discrimination.

questions.text: A young boy was noticed to have the following finding on general examination. Which among the following conditions is it most likely associated with?
questions.solution:
The lesion seen in the picture is that of the Shagreen patch. It is seen in Tuberous sclerosis.

Skin lesions in Tuberous sclerosis:

  • Shagreen patches are characteristic of tuberous sclerosis and consist of a roughened, raised lesions. They have an orange-peel consistency and are located primarily in the lumbosacral region
  • The typical hypomelanotic ash leaf–type macules on the trunk and extremities are seen in 90% of the patients (visualized by the use of a wood ultraviolet lamp).
  • Facial angiofibromas (adenoma sebaceum) develop between 4 and 6 years of age. They are tiny red nodules present over the nose and cheeks and are sometimes confused with acne. They can enlarge and coalesce to give a fleshy appearance.
  • Periungual fibromas are small fibromas or nodules of skin, which form around fingernails or toenails in some adolescent patients.
  • Confetti skin lesions are seen less commonly as a minor feature of tuberous sclerosis (confetti=small pieces of paper used to throw at celebrations).

questions.text:
A male child presents with poor growth. Examination reveals bowing of legs, frontal bossing, and pectus carinatum. The X-ray is shown below. Laboratory investigations reveal that the disease is due to decreased dietary intake. Which of the following would not be seen in this patient?

PTH - Parathyroid Hormone

ALP - Alkaline phosphatase
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette is suggestive of rickets and decreased serum PTH would not be seen in this patient. PTH is elevated in rickets.

The clinical vignette describing a child with bowing of legs, frontal bossing, poor growth, pectus carinatum, and x-ray findings showing cupping and fraying of the bilateral distal metaphysis of radius and ulna with growth plate widening are suggestive of rickets. The laboratory findings on rickets would be:

  • Normal/decreased serum calcium
  • Decreased phosphorous
  • Elevated PTH, and
  • Increased ALP levels

Rickets occurs due to a nutritional deficiency in vitamin D. Decreased vitamin D leads to decreased calcium and phosphate due to reduced absorption. The decreased calcium stimulates increased PTH production. ALP level is increased as it is involved in bone mineralization.

Clinical features of rickets include general features such as malnourishment, abdominal distension, proximal muscle weakness, etc.

Head-

  • Softening of the skull bones, called craniotabes. 
  • Delayed closure of fontanells.

Chest-

  • Typical rachitic rosary i.e. widening of the costochondral junctions that give the feeling of rosary beads on palpation.
  • Harrison's groove, a horizontal groove in the lower chest, may appear from the inward pull of the softened ribs by the diaphragm during respiration.

Other bony abnormalities-

  • Vertebral column abnormalities like scoliosis, kyphosis, and lordosis can also appear
  • In the distal extremities- widening of the wrists and ankles, varus/ valgus deformities, windswept deformity (valgus on the side and varus on the contralateral side), anterior tibial bowing, etc

  • Cupping of metaphysis: normally metaphysis meets epiphysis as a smooth line of sclerosis. But in rickets the line is absent and the metaphyseal ends appear irregular and the cartilage accumulating in the growth plate creates a depression in the metaphysis causing cupping.
  • Fraying: indistinct margins of the metaphysis

  • Wrist: especially the ulna

questions.text: A 30-year-old lady presents with fever, oral ulcers, photosensitivity, and a rash on her face, as seen below. Anti-dsDNA and anti-Smith antibodies are positive. Which of the following is deficient in this patient?
questions.solution:
The diagnosis based on the given clinical scenario and image is systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). C1, C2, and C4 complements are deficient in SLE patients.

The rash seen in the image is a malar rash (classically seen in SLE); it is characterized by a well-demarcated erythematous butterfly rash over the malar eminences, with sparing of the nasolabial folds. Anti-dsDNA and anti-Smith antibodies are specific for SLE.

Clinical syndromes associated with genetic deficiencies of various complement components:

  • C1 inhibitor deficiency - Hereditary angioedema
  • C1, C2, C4 deficiency - SLE and other collagen vascular disorders
  • C5-C8 deficiency - Toxoplasmosis, bacteremia with gram-negative diplococci 
  • C3 and its regulatory protein or C3b inactivator deficiency - Severe recurrent pyogenic infections

questions.text: A police officer while investigating a case of infantile homicide asks a forensic expert to estimate the age of the dead infant. The forensic expert estimates the age as 3 months by counting the number of cross striations in the enamel of teeth. Which of the following methods has been used by the forensic expert for age estimation?
questions.solution:
The given scenario suggests that Boyde’s method is being used by the forensic expert for estimating the age of the dead infant.

Boyde’s method method is based on counting the number of cross striations in the enamel of teeth (incremental lines) from the neonatal line onwards. The neonatal line is formed soon after birth and can be seen in about 3 weeks or by electron microscopy 1–2 days after birth. This method is applicable mainly to estimate the age of dead infants.

Other options:

Option B- Stack’s method: Determination of age is done from the weight of the erupting teeth of the fetus/ infant. It can be used on both deciduous and permanent teeth in their erupting phase.

Option C- Miles' method: Age estimation is made on the basis of a comparison of the amount of wear on all three permanent molars with the baseline. It is used to determine the age beyond 25 years. 

Option D- Gustafson’s Method: It is based on physiological changes in teeth. It is used to determine the age between 25-60 years. Gustafson’s criteria include:

  • Attrition: Wear and tear changes of the occlusal surface.
  • Periodontosis: Regression of gums surrounding the tooth resulting in loosening of the tooth and falling.
  • Secondary dentin: Deposition of dentin in the pulp cavity.
  • Cementum apposition: Deposition of cementum in the root forming incremental lines.
  • Root resorption: Involves both cementum and dentin.
  • Transparency of the root: This is the most reliable criterion. Canals in dentin get filled with minerals and they become less transparent.

Note: Amino acid racemization is considered the most reliable destructive method of dental age estimation.

questions.text:
An elderly woman is rushed to the emergency room following an episode of syncope. Her caretaker reports that the patient had multiple episodes of loose stools and vomiting for the past 2 days. Her blood investigations and ECG are given below. What is the next best step in the management of this patient?

Serum sodium: 140 mEq/L
Serum potassium: 7.1 mEq/L
Serum chloride: 100 mEq/L
Blood urea nitrogen creatinine ratio: 26.9
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with the ECG showing tall T waves in all the leads and the laboratory investigations showing serum potassium of 7.1 mEq/L are suggestive of hyperkalemia. The next best step in the management is intravenous calcium gluconate.

This patient has acute kidney injury resulting from dehydration. Her BUN: Creatinine ratio is 26.9 which is >20:1 which suggests prerenal azotemia. Acute kidney injury results in impaired excretion of potassium resulting in hyperkalemia.

Although ECG changes are not specific and hyperkalemia may occur without significant ECG changes, the typical changes seen in ECG due to hyperkalemia are sequential and include:

  • Peaking of the T waves
  • ST-segment depression
  • Widening of the PR and QRS intervals
  • Sine waves
  • Ventricular fibrillation and asystole

The presence of cardiac toxicity is a serious manifestation of hyperkalemia and requires immediate cardiac stabilization with intravenous calcium gluconate. Calcium gluconate should also be initiated in all patients with serum potassium >6.5 mEq/L and patients with muscular weakness.

The recommended dose is 10 mL of 10% calcium gluconate infused intravenously over 2–3 min with cardiac monitoring. The dose should be repeated if there is no change in ECG findings or if findings recur after stabilization.

Treatment of hyperkalemia involves the following:

  1. Administer intravenous calcium gluconate, which raises the threshold and reduces excitability. It is cardioprotective.
  2. Administer regular insulin with dextrose. The insulin will reduce the serum potassium concentration by causing an intracellular shift. The dextrose will counteract the hypoglycemic effects of insulin.
  3. Provide salbutamol nebulization, which will also shift potassium inside the cell.
  4. Remove potassium with calcium-based resins, diuretics, or hemodialysis.

Other options:

Option A: Patiromer is a potassium-binding drug that can be used in chronic hyperkalemia. It doesn't play a role in acute hyperkalemia due to acute kidney injury like in this patient. Sodium zirconium cyclosili­cate and sodium polystyrene are other potassium-binding agents.

Option C: Hemodialysis may be needed in patients with acute or chronic renal failure to remove excess potassium, especially in patients who are oliguric. However, it should be undertaken after cardiac stabilization.

questions.text: A 34-year-old man with HIV presented with fever, hepatosplenomegaly, and generalized, painless, erythematous nodules scattered all over the body and face as shown below. Biopsy of the lesions revealed capillary proliferation and cuboidal endothelial cells protruding into the vascular lumen. There were epithelioid histiocytes surrounded by a fibromyxoid matrix. A Warthin-Starry stain shows organisms that confirm the diagnosis. Which of the following is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
This clinical vignette of fever, hepatosplenomegaly, and painless erythematous nodules over the body with Warthin-Starry stain used for diagnosis is strongly suggestive of bacillary angiomatosis caused by Bartonella henselae, a gram-negative intracellular rod. The Warthin-Starry stain is a silver impregnation staining technique that would stain and reveal the tangled intracellular bacilli in the lesions. 

Clinically, bacillary angiomatosis would present as single or multiple violaceous papulonodular lesions. They are usually well-circumscribed and may be surrounded by scaling and erythema. Hepatosplenomegaly may be present due to the infiltration of the liver and splenic parenchyma by these nodules. Non-specific constitutional features such as fever, weight loss, and fatigue may be present. 

Pathologically, these papules and nodules are characterized by the presence of proliferation of capillaries with cuboidal endothelial cells protruding into the vascular lumen. There is an infiltration with epithelioid histiocytes in the subendothelial tissue. On using special silver stains such as the Warthin-Starry stain, the bacilli may be visualized. Lesions in the liver are characterized by vascular proliferation with cystic blood-filled spaces surrounded by a fibro-myxoid matrix containing the bacteria. This is known as Peliosis hepatis. 

Diagnosis can be established by biopsies of lesions and special staining with silver impregnation techniques. Detection of Bartonella b in tissue specimens by polymerase chain reaction (PCR) or demonstration of Bartonella antigens by immunohistochemical methods can also be used. They may also be cultured in the laboratory on chocolate agar and heart infusion agar with 5% rabbit blood.

Bacillary angiomatosis responds well to antibiotic therapy. The drug of choice for the treatment of bacillary angiomatosis is erythromycin for 3 months. Doxycycline may also be used. 

Image of Warthin-Starry stained lesion showing tangled pleomorphic bacilli- 

Other options-

Option B: Human Herpes Virus 8 is the causative organism of Kaposi Sarcoma, which is an important differential diagnosis for bacillary angiomatosis in an immunocompromised patient such as this patient with HIV. However, a Warthin-Starry stain would not reveal the organism—Human Herpesvirus 8. 

Option C: Pasteurella multocida may cause cellulitis and severe wound infection with purulent drainage and adenitis. It may also cause systemic infections including meningitis, and osteomyelitis in the immunocompromised. It is associated with dog and cat bites. However, it can also be spread by the inhalational route through infected respiratory droplets from animals. 

Option D: Epstein Barr virus causes several lymphoproliferative disorders including infectious mononucleosis, hairy cell leukoplakia, Burkitt lymphoma, and Hodgkin and non-Hodgkin lymphomas. However, they are not implicated in Bacillary angiomatosis.

questions.text: An eight-year-old girl presents with a red and pruritic rash on the sun-exposed areas of the body along with a history of wide-based, unsteady gait. On examination, serum electrolytes are normal and urine is positive for neutral amino acids. The pattern of inheritance of the disease is given in the image below.  What is the cause of this condition?
questions.solution:
The above clinical history of pellagra-like symptoms with autosomal recessive inheritance as shown in the image is suggestive of Hartnup disease. It is due to a tryptophan transport defect.

Hartnup disease is an autosomal recessive condition caused due to a single defect in renal and intestinal transport of tryptophan due to a mutation of the SLC6A19 gene on Chromosome 5. This results in decreased availability of tryptophan for niacin synthesis. Thus, manifesting as pellagra-like symptoms.

Clinical features include intermittent, reversible episodes affecting the skin and nervous system that are aggravated by sunlight, febrile illness, stress and nutritional deficiency. Skin manifestations present after sun exposure and include erythematous, scaly patches, similar to pellagra. Neurologic manifestations include ataxia(wide-based unsteady gait), tremors, mood disorder, depression, convulsions, and psychosis.

Diagnosis is made by demonstrating the presence of neutral amino acids in the urine, distinguishing it from pellagra. Indican can also be present in the urine, produced as a by-product of tryptophan metabolism. 

Treatment involves supplementation with nicotinic acid or nicotinamide and a high-protein diet.  

Other options :

Option B: Uroporphyrinogen I synthase defect is seen in acute intermittent porphyria, which is inherited as an autosomal dominant trait. It presents with abdominal pain and neuropsychiatric symptoms. There will be elevated aminolevulinic acid and porphobilinogen in the urine and plasma.

Option C: Methylcobalamin formation defect results in methylmalonic acidemia, which follows autosomal recessive inheritance. The clinical manifestations would include vomiting, dehydration, failure to thrive, lethargy, hypotonia, and seizures. 

Option D: Tyrosine aminotransferase deficiency results in tyrosinemia type II or Richner-Hanhart syndrome. It is an autosomal recessive disorder. Patients present with corneal inflammation, painful palmoplantar hyperkeratosis, and mental retardation.

questions.text: A 25-year-old obese female presents with a  2-year history of long periods of amenorrhea, followed by menorrhagia, along with excessive acne and increased facial, axillary, and pubic hair growth. Her prime concern is menstrual irregularity, for which she wants immediate resolution. On further questioning, she also mentions that she wants to have children after a few years. Which of the following will not be an appropriate treatment option for her condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a lady in the menstrual age group who is obese and hirsute, with acne and irregular cycles suggests a diagnosis of polycystic ovarian disease/syndrome (PCOD/ PCOS). Ormeloxifene is not used as a treatment for polycystic ovarian disease.

Ormeloxifene (a selective estrogen receptor modulator), also known as centchroman, is a nonsteroidal contraceptive taken twice weekly as a 30 mg tablet for 12 weeks and weekly thereafter. It acts by preventing implantation. It can also be used in AUB due to its anti-estrogenic effects. It is contraindicated in PCOS.  

PCOS is a multisystem, metabolic, endocrine dysfunction that commonly occurs among women in the reproductive age group. It has multifactorial causation, such as lifestyle changes, stress, diet, obesity, and hyperinsulinemic states. CYP21 mutation and X-linked dominant inheritance patterns have been implicated in familial cases. 

It is characterized by:

Symptoms Signs 
Early adrenarche Obesity at the waistline, BMI>25
Early menarche  Goiter
Initially, normal menstruation followed by oligomenorrhea or periods of amenorrhea followed by menorrhagia  Hirsutism, acne
Infertility due to anovulation  Hypertension in obesity 
Pregnancy loss or high-risk pregnancies  Acanthosis nigricans 
Hyperandrogenism Acne, hirsutism, scalp baldness 

Rotterdam criteria are used to diagnose PCOS. The presence of any two of the three components of this criteria establishes the diagnosis of PCOS.

  • Clinical/biochemical hyperandrogenism (hirsutism, acne)
  • Oligo/amenorrhea, anovulation, infertility
  • Polycystic ovaries (USG findings)

USG findings of PCOS

  • Enlarged ovaries, volume >10 mm3
  • 12 or more follicles of 2–9 mm each placed peripherally (a string of pearls appearance)
  • Endometrial hyperplasia may be present

The image below shows a string-of-pearls appearance on USG indicative of PCOS.

Management:

  • Weight reduction alone is beneficial in mild hirsutism and lifestyle changes (like smoking cessation) are advised in the management of PCOS.
  • Oral contraceptive pills (OCP), preferably fourth-generation pills with 30 mcg E2 and 2-3 mg drospirenone are used to treat menstrual abnormalities. It also reduces acne and further hirsutism.
  • Anti-androgens are useful in treating hirsutism. OCP with cyproterone acetate is prescribed for PCOS patients with hirsutism. 
  • Patients with PCOD are more prone to developing insulin resistance which can be controlled with metformin. Acarbose can be used if metformin is contraindicated
  • Patients presenting with infertility are treated by inducing ovulation using clomiphene as a first-line drug, along with dexamethasone and letrozole.

Surgical options include laparoscopic ovarian drilling or puncture of not more than four cysts in each ovary. This is done either by laser or by unipolar electrocautery. It restores endocrine levels and improves fertility.

Surgery is indicated only if

  • Medical therapy fails
  • Hyperstimulation occurs
  • Infertile women
  • Previous pregnancy losses

Other options:

Option A: Ethinyl Estradiol + Drospirenone is a 4th generation combined oral contraceptive pill given for PCOD with androgenic features.

Option B: Metformin is an insulin sensitizer, thereby it decreases hyperinsulinemia. It also reduces the free and total testosterone and increases the sex hormone-binding globulin. It rectifies the root cause of the endocrine disturbance to restore ovulation and thereby improves the fertility rate. 

Option C: Spironolactone 100 mg to 200 mg daily has antiandrogenic effects and can be used in the treatment of androgenic features like severe hirsutism. Combination therapy with an oral contraceptive will be helpful in patients with PCOS.

Note: Letrozole is as effective as Clomiphene in treating infertility in PCOD with fewer side effects. However, it's pending FDA approval and is used off-label.

  2. LH level is raised over 10 IU/mL. FSH level remains normal to low, but FSH/LH ratio falls.
  3. Testosterone and epi-androstenedione levels rise.
    • Testosterone elevated but < 200 ng/dL (normal range 20 -80 ng/dL)
    • Testosterone > 200 ng/dL suggests androgen-secreting ovarian tumor
    • DHEA-S values may be normal or slightly elevated
    • DHEA >700 ng/mL suggests adrenal tumour
  4. Serum SHBG is reduced.
  5. Triglyceride level >150 mg/dL-hyperlipidaemia HDL <50 mg/dL.
  6. Fasting blood glucose/fasting insulin <4.5 suggests insulin resistance
  7. Prolactin is mildly raised in 15% cases
  8. Fasting insulin is more than 10 mIU/L in PCOS in 50–70%cases
  9. Thyroid function tests may be abnormal (hypothyroidism)
  10. 17-a-hydroxyprogesterone in the follicular phase >300 ng/dL suggests adrenal hyperplasia due to 21-hydroxylase deficiency.
  11. Urinary cortisol <50 μg/24 h.

questions.text: A prospective study is being conducted to study the effect of alcohol on the development of lung cancer. However, individuals who drink alcohol are more likely to smoke. So, smoking is also associated with exposure. Also, smoking is an independent causative factor for lung cancer. This problem can be tackled by all of the following methods except:
questions.solution:
This problem can be tackled by all of the following methods except blinding. The problem refers to a confounding factor, ie smoking. Confounding factors can be prevented or eliminated by randomization, matching, and restriction. 
 
A confounding factor is defined as the one associated with both exposure and disease and is distributed unequally in study and control groups. For example, a prospective study is being conducted to know the effect of alcohol on the development of lung cancer. However, individuals who drink alcohol are most likely to smoke. So, smoking is associated with the exposure. Also, smoking is an independent causative factor for lung cancer. Thus, smoking is a confounding factor.
 
In the above example, if the study is conducted without eliminating the confounding factor, then the result may falsely suggest that alcohol is a causative factor for lung cancer.  
 
Techniques to eliminate confounding factors include:
  • Randomization
  • Matching
  • Stratified randomization
  • Restriction
Randomization is the random allocation of the participants in experimental studies (Ex.randomized control trial) into the study group and control group.
 
Matching, which is usually done in analytical studies (for example, case-control and cohort studies), is the process where the participants in two groups are matched based on factors such as age, gender, race, smoking status, etc. to eliminate the potential confounders.
 
Stratified randomization, which is also known as pre-stratification or blocking, is the process that combines both randomization and matching techniques. In this method, the participants are first grouped into subgroups that internally match with potential confounding factors such as age, race, gender, etc. An equal number of participants from each subgroup are then allocated to the study and control groups.
 
Restriction: This method restricts the study to only those participants with particular characteristics. For example, a study can be restricted to participants of only one gender, race, age group, geographical area, disease severity, etc., thus eliminating the potential confounders.
 
Other options:
 
Blinding does not eliminate confounding factors. Blinding is done to eliminate the bias (such as subject bias, observer bias, or investigator bias).

questions.text: False statement regarding carotid body tumours is -

choices.text: The chief cells stain for CD56
They are composed of nests of cells
The stromal cells are positive for S-100

questions.solution:
Carotid body tumors are parasympathetic paragangliomas.

The carotid body tumors are usually less than 6 cm in diameter and arise around the bifurcation of the common carotid artery. The tumor is red-pink to brown colored, and the microscopic features show nests (zellballen), of round to oval chief cells with abundant, clear or granular, eosinophilic cytoplasm and uniform, round to ovoid nuclei, surrounded by delicate vascular septae. There is scanty cellular pleomorphism and mitoses. The chief cells stain positive for chromogranin, synaptophysin, neuron-specific enolase, CD56, and CD57. There is a supporting network of spindle-shaped stromal cells called sustentacular cells that stain positive for S-100. Electron microscopy shows well-demarcated neuroendocrine granules.

Paragangliomas are neuroendocrine cell tumors arising from sympathetic or parasympathetic ganglia. Sympathetic paraganglioma secretes catecholamines whilst parasympathetic are silent. Adrenal medullary pheochromocytomas are the most common paraganglioma. Around 70% of extra-adrenal paragangliomas occur in the head and neck. 

Paragangliomas typically develop in two locations. Paravertebral paraganglia (organ of Zuckerkandl) have sympathetic connections and stain positively for chromaffin, as they produce catecholamines whereas Paraganglia related to the great vessels of the head and neck, especially the aorticopulmonary chain, including the carotid bodies (carotid body tumor), aortic bodies, jugulotympanic ganglia ( glomus tympanicum or jugulare), the vagus nerve, and clusters located around the oral cavity, nose, nasopharynx, larynx, and orbit. These have parasympathetic innervation and do not usually produce catecholamines.

questions.text: A  farmer was presented with a suppurative wound on his arm and respiratory symptoms. Later he was diagnosed with melioidosis. The causative organism of this disease belongs to which category of bioterrorism agents as classified by CDC?
questions.solution:
Melioidosis is caused by burkholderia pseudomallei and it belongs to category B agent of bioterrorism as classified by CDC.

Melioidosis is also known as Whitmore's disease. The incubation period can be as short as 2–3 days,  months, or years. A suppurative wound infection can occur at the inoculation site which may lead to sepsis and multi-organ involvement. It is presented as fever with leukocytosis. Chest x-ray shows upper lobe consolidation. Gram staining with Wright's or methylene blue shows a gram-negative organism.

questions.text: You are conducting a meta-analysis of studies on the effects of statin drugs and the risk of developing ventricular arrhythmias in patients with cardiomyopathy. The analysis is presented as the following plot. Which among the given statements is incorrect regarding the interpretation of these plots?

choices.text: The diamond shows the overall pooled results
Each rectangle depicts a single study
The vertical dashed line is the “line of no effect"
The size of the rectangle denotes the sample size

questions.solution:
The given plot for the meta-analysis is a forest plot. The vertical solid line is the “line of no effect", signifying no difference between the intervention and the placebo (i.e., a risk ratio of 1)

The vertical dashed line represents the overall pooled estimate which represents the meta-analyzed measure of effect.

Forest plots allow the results to be seen at a glance with the identification of the outliers.

Interpretation of the graph given in the image: 

  • Each rectangle represents a single study. 
    - ex: Smith et al, Jones et al 
  • The size of the rectangle represents the sample size
    - ex: Smith et al 1999 had a small sample size whereas Chu et al 2009 had a large sample size
  • The horizontal line on either side represents the confidence interval, the longer the lines, the wider the confidential interval, the less reliable the study results
    - ex: Ng et al 2004 has a small confidence interval and is more reliable than Jones et al 1993 as it has longer confidence intervals
  • The vertical solid line- the “line of no effect", no difference between the intervention and the placebo (i.e., a risk ratio of 1) 
    -the location of the result depicts whether it favours the intervention (the statin drug) or not. Any study line which crosses the line of null effect does not illustrate a statistically significant result.
  • A diamond represents the overall pooled result of the meta-analysis where all the individual studies are combined together and averaged. 
  • Lateral corners of the diamond represent the confidence interval, if these corners do not cross 'the line of no effect', then there is an overall statistically significant effect. If the diamond touches the vertical line, the overall result is not statistically significant.
 

Related Pearl: Forest Plot

  • A forest plot is used to present the results of a meta-analysis.
  • It is also called blobbogram.

Interpretation of forest plots: 

  • The rectangles represent the single studies
  • The size of the rectangle is proportional to the sample size
  • The horizontal line on either side - confidence interval, the longer the lines, the wider the confidential interval, the less reliable the study results
  • The vertical solid line - the “line of no effect", which represents the odds ratio or relative risk. If it is the odds ratio, then the vertical line would be at 1. No difference between the intervention and the placebo (i.e., a risk ratio of 1). 
  • The location of the result - whether it favours the intervention (the statin drug) or not
  • A diamond shows the overall pooled result where all the individual studies are combined together and averaged
  • Lateral corners of the diamond represent the confidence interval, if these corners do not cross 'the line of no effect', then there is an overall statistically significant effect. If the diamond touches the vertical line, the overall result is not statistically significant.
  • The vertical dashed line represents the overall pooled estimate which represents the meta-analysed measure of effect.

Let's understand with an example - 

  • For study A- it has a wide horizontal line that crosses the line of null effect with a black box that is to the right of the vertical line. This most likely demonstrates a small scale study with few participants where the point estimate result favours the control used in the study. But because the study contains the null value in its 95% confidence interval, it is likely to have a p-value >0.05 and not be statistically significant.
  • For study B- it has quite a narrow line that does not cross the line of null effect with a black box that is to the left of the vertical line and is bigger than study A. This most likely demonstrates a larger study with more participants compared to study A, where the result favours the intervention used. Because the 95% confidence interval does not contain the null value, this study is likely to have a p-value <0.05 and hence the differences observed in the study can be regarded as statistically significant.

questions.text:
The histological images of four brain tumours are given below. Pick out the correct match.
  1. Schwannoma
  2. Oligodendroglioma
  3. Glioblastoma multiforme
  4. Medulloblastoma
questions.solution:
The correct option is C: A-2, B-1, C-3, D-4

Image A -

The histological image shows fried egg appearance of cells is seen in oligodendroglioma.

  • These are infiltrating gliomas comprised of cells that resemble oligodendrocytes.
  • Common in the fourth and fifth decades.
  • The lesions are found mostly in the cerebral hemispheres, with a pre­dilection for white matter.
  • The tumors are composed of sheets of regular cells with spherical nuclei containing finely granular chromatin (similar to normal oligodendrocytes) surrounded by a clear halo of vacuolated cytoplasm giving a fried egg appearance. Tumor cells infiltrating the cerebral cortex often collect around neurons (perineuronal satellitosis).

Image B - 

The image shows verocay bodies which are seen in schwannoma. These are nuclear-free zones that lie between nuclear palisading.

It consists of dense areas called Antoni A area, and loose areas called Antoni B area.

  • The dense eosinophilic Antoni A areas contain spindle cells that are arranged into cellular intersecting fascicles. Palisading of nuclei is seen, with the nuclear-free zones between them, called Verocay bodies.
  • The Antoni B areas contain spindle-shaped cells that are loosely arranged and separated by prominent myxoid extracellular matrix.

Image C - 

The image shows pleomorphic cells characteristic of glioblastoma multiforme.

Grossly, glioblastomas are found infiltrating the brain tissue and are poorly delineated. They have grayish tumor cells with central yellowish necrosis and multiple areas of hemorrhages.

  • They are composed of poorly differentiated pleomorphic astrocytic cells with nuclear atypia and high mitotic activity.
  • Necrosis and florid microvascular proliferation are characteristic.
  • They exhibit pseudopalisading—dense arrangement of tumor cells lining up around the foci of tumor necrosis, which is characteristically seen in this image above

Image D -

The image shows a densely cellular medulloblastoma

  • These tumors will have sheets of anaplastic cells. The individual cells are small, with scant cytoplasm and hyperchromatic nuclei that are frequently elongated or crescent-shaped
  • Mitosis is abundant and markers of cellular proliferation are abundant
  • The tumour may express neuronal (neurosecretory) granules, form Homer-Wright rosettes and express glial markers (GFAP)
  • There are two variants - nodular desmoplastic and the large cell variant. The nodular desmoplastic variant has areas of stromal response, marked by collagen and reticulin deposition and nodules forming pale islands. The large cell variant has irregular vesicular nuclei, prominent nucleoli and apoptotic cells 

 

Note:

Fried eggs in pathology:

  • Oligodendroglioma on histopathology
  • Hairy cell leukemia on bone marrow biopsy
  • Seminoma/Dysgerminoma on light microscopy
  • Mycoplasma pneumonia fried egg colonies on Eaton agar

questions.text: A 35-year-old G2P1 at 38 weeks of gestation came to the labor room with complaints of decreased fetal movements.  A non-stress test was done and variable decelerations are noted.  It indicates ______
questions.solution:
Variable deceleration indicates Umbilical cord compression.

Deceleration: Decrease in fetal heart rate below the baseline by 15 bpm for more than 15s.

Related Pearl: Deceleration patterns on cardiotocography (CTG)

Early deceleration: seen in head compression

 

Late deceleration: Seen in uteroplacental insufficiency, foetal hypoxia

 

Variable deceleration: Seen in umbilical cord compression

questions.text: A 30-year-old male patient presented with painful genital ulcers for the past two weeks. Examination revealed multiple, bleeding, soft ulcers that are exquisitely tender and bleed easily. The inguinal lymph nodes are tender and fluctuant. Which of the following would be a suitable culture medium for the suspected organism?
questions.solution:
This clinical vignette is strongly suggestive of chancroid caused by Haemophilus ducreyi. Among the given options, chocolate agar with IsoVitaleX is the most suitable culture media for isolating the organism. 

H. ducreyi are gram-negative bacilli. On staining, they are sometimes seen arranged in a characteristic 'school of fish' or 'railroad track' appearance. 

Clinically, patients develop an H. ducreyi infection from sexual contact with an infected person. Following this, they develop a papule that progresses to a pustule and finally a circumscribed ulcer. This is called chancroid or 'soft sore' and it may be single or multiple, very painful, bleeds easily, and is non-indurated. The infection then spreads to the lymph nodes which become tender, inflamed, and then suppurated. 

Diagnosis is established by isolating the organism on culture. The specimen may include scrapings from the ulcer base and aspirate from the suppurated lymph node. Culture is difficult but they can be grown on chocolate agar enriched with IsoVitaleX and vancomycin, fresh clotted rabbit blood, or on the chorioallantoic membrane of the chick embryo. H. ducreyi requires media enriched with the X factor, but not the V factor for growth. 

Treatment is with a single oral dose of 1g of azithromycin. Other options include oral ciprofloxacin, IM ceftriaxone, and oral erythromycin. Sexual contacts of these patients must be treated regardless of whether they are symptomatic or not. 

Other options-

Option A - Thayer Martin medium is used for the isolation of Neisseria species. Neisseria meningitidis causes meningitis and meningococcemia presenting as acute fever with chills, malaise, and prostration. Neisseria gonorrhea causes urethritis, proctitis, vulvovaginitis, conjunctivitis, and disseminated gonococcal infection. 

Option B - Tellurite blood agar is used for the isolation of Corynebacterium species. Corynebacterium diphtheria causes diphtheria with variable presentation. It can lead to asphyxia, circulatory failure, toxemia and local necrotic changes. 

Option D - Ashdown's medium is used for the isolation of Burkholderia pseudomallei species. This bacteria causes melioidosis. It may be acute presenting as acute septicemia and typhoid or pneumonia-like disease. In the chronic form, it presents with multiple caseous or suppurative foci.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old woman presents to the OPD with amenorrhea for the last 8 months. She complains of a loss of libido and problems with intercourse with her partner. There is a previous history of chronic radiation exposure. Investigations are given below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

FSH: 55 IU/L 
Prolactin: 20 ng/mL 
Pregnancy test: Negative
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, a history of amenorrhea and loss of libido with chronic radiation exposure and elevated FSH levels (> 40 IU/L) in a 35-year-old female point toward the diagnosis of premature ovarian failure.

Premature ovarian failure is defined as ovarian failure occurring before the age of 40 years. Clinically, it presents as secondary amenorrhoea for at least 3 months with raised FSH, raised FSH/LH ratio, and low estrogen.

Causes of POF

  • Migration of germ cells from the yolk sac.
  • Germ cell apoptosis.
    • Chromosomal abnormalities
    • Autoimmune diseases - hypothyroidism, Addison's disease, etc
    • Genital TB
    • Smoking
    • Radiation and chemotherapy
    • Hysterectomy
    • Prolonged GnRH therapy
    • Induction of multiple ovulation.

Clinical features include amenorrhea, hot flashes, sweating, diminished libido, vaginal dryness, and urinary symptoms.

Management:

  • Treatment of cause
  • If not interested in pregnancy:
    • Hormone replacement therapy (HRT) - Libido improves with estrogen therapy
  • If interested in pregnancy:
    • Ovulation induction (if an ovarian reserve is present) or donor eggs for in vitro fertilization.

Other options:

Option B: Patients with androgen insensitivity syndrome would have presented with primary amenorrhea. Karyotyping would reveal a 46XY karyotype. LH is raised, but FSH is normal. 

Option C: A prolactinoma would present with elevated prolactin levels.

Option D: In polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS), there are features like menstrual abnormalities, obesity, and hyperandrogenism. LH level is raised, FSH level remains normal, but FSH/LH ratio falls. Estrogen levels increase.

questions.text: A 45-year-old, non diabetic and normotensive man comes with complaints of pain over the heel that is most severe while taking the first step in the morning and aggravated on dorsiflexion. The appropriate diagnosis would be:
questions.solution:
The above given complaints are suggestive of plantar fasciitis.

The pain is often worse when first getting up in the morning, with typical hobbling downstairs, or when first getting up from a period of sitting – the typical start-up pain and stiffness.

In Achilles tendonitis pain is increased with activity.

In calcaneal stress fractures there may be a history of unaccustomed and repetitive activity or one of a strenuous physical exercise programme. A common sequence of events is: pain after exercise – pain during exercise – pain without exercise.

In tarsal tunnel syndrome, there is pain and sensory disturbance in the medial part of the forefoot, unrelated to weight bearing, may be due to compression of the posterior tibial nerve behind and below the medial malleolus. The pain is often worse at night and the patient may seek relief by walking around or stamping the foot.

questions.text: A 26-year old woman with complaints of heartburn and dyspepsia was diagnosed with H.pylori gastritis after a positive urea breath test and started on the first-line regimen for H.pylori. It has now been 4 weeks since the completion of the regimen. Which of the following is not a reliable test in evaluating the treatment success in this patient?
questions.solution:
Testing for specific antibodies to H.pylori (serology) is not suitable to determine the success after 4 weeks of treatment as the fall in H.pylori specific antibody titer is too slow to be of practical use.

The urea breath test, stool antigen test, and biopsy-based tests can all be used to assess the success of treatment. The first-line treatment for H.pylori is the triple-drug regimen with Omeprazole, Clarithromycin, and Metronidazole.

Testing for H.pylori after an initial regimen is usually advised after 4 weeks of treatment completion, as these tests depend on the H.pylori load and may yield a false negative test of treatment success. There may be regrowth weeks after a negative result. It is also advised not to test for H.pylori within 4 weeks of intermittent treatment with antibiotics/bismuth compounds or 2 weeks of PPIs.

Non-invasive tests like urea breath test and stool antigen test are normally preferred in assessment of treatment success. However, history of gastric ulcer necessitates endoscopy and biopsy of samples to ensure healing and rule out progression to gastric carcinoma.

questions.text: Which of the following flaps involves the isolation of blood supply, disconnection, and finally reconnection using microsurgery?
questions.solution:
Free flaps involve isolation of blood supply, disconnection, and then reconnection using microsurgery at the new site. 

Flaps are tissues that bring vascularity as they are transferred with their blood supply. Different types of flaps are: 

  1. Random flaps have no specific relationship to where the blood supply enters. It is basically three sides of a rectangle, and the length-to-breadth ratio is less than 1.5:1. 'Delaying the flap' is a process in which cuts are partially made and the flap is partly lifted at a first operation. It is then replaced, thus ‘training’ the blood supply from a single border of the rectangle. A second procedure is conducted where it is raised further and finally transferred.
  2. Axial flaps - These are longer flaps. They are based on known blood vessels supplying the skin. This technique enables many long thin flaps to be safely moved across large distances.
  3. Pedicled/islanded flaps - They can be swung around on a stalk or even fully ‘islanded’ because of the axial blood supply. The business end of the skin being transferred can hence have the pedicle buried.
  4. Free flaps - In this case the blood supply is isolated, disconnected, and then reconnected using microsurgery at the new site 
  5. Composite flaps - Often skin with bone or muscle is transferred with the flap (osseocutaneous or myocutaneous flaps, respectively).
  6. Perforator flaps - Tissues are isolated on small perforating vessels that run from more major blood vessels to supply the surface. It is a subgroup of an axial flap.

Skin-bearing flaps are also classified based on -

  • Composition: Refers to the tissue contained within the flap, such as cutaneous, musculocutaneous, fasciocutaneous etc
  • Method of movement:
    • Local transfer, eg. advancement or rotation flaps
    • Distant transfer, eg. pedicle flaps from the abdomen to the perineum or micro-vascular free flaps.
  • Blood supply:
    • Musculocutaneous arteries travel perpendicularly through muscle to the overlying skin.
    • Septocutaneous arteries travel with intermuscular fascial septa to supply the overlying skin.

questions.text:
Which of the following are true regarding the intraocular lens given below:
  1. It is designed to be placed in the posterior chamber
  2. It is designed to be placed in the anterior chamber
  3. The most ideal method of fixation is in the capsular bag
  4. Scleral fixation is the best-advised method of fixation
  5. Also called Singh and Worst's lens
questions.solution:
The above image depicts a modified C-loop type of posterior chamber intraocular lens (PCIOL).

The central part overlying the optic axis is called the optic. The peripheral arms used for placement and stabilization are the haptics.

Posterior Chamber IOL:

  • The IOL is best placed in the posterior chamber.
  • PCIOLs rest entirely behind the iris.
  • They may be supported and fixed as
    • Capsular bag fixation of PCIOL (most ideal method)
    • Ciliary sulcus fixation
    • Sclera fixation

Anterior Chamber IOL:

  • Lie entirely in front of the iris and are supported in the angle of the anterior chamber
  • Are associated with a higher incidence of bullous keratopathy
  • Kelman multiflex type of anterior chamber intraocular lens (ACIOL) is the most commonly used ACIOL (image below)

Singh and Worst’s is a type of iris-claw lens.

  • The iris-supported lens is fixed with the help of sutures, loops, or claws.
  • These lenses are associated with a high incidence of postoperative complications.

questions.text: The image illustrated below represents the shape of congenital renal anomaly seen in a 10-year-old child. Radiological investigations indicate that both the renal units are low lying. Which of the following arteries most likely prevents the ascent of the kidney in this child?
questions.solution:
The given image shows horseshoe kidney. Inferior mesenteric artery prevents the ascent of the horseshoe kidney.

Horseshoe kidney is the most common congenital anomaly of the kidneys.

Horseshoe kidney is caused due to the fusion of lower poles of the kidney. Horseshoe kidneys are prone to reflux,obstruction and stone formation.

The common associations of horseshoe kidney are:

  • Vesicoureteral Reflux
  • Wilms Tumor (4 times more common in children with horseshoe kidneys than in the general population)
  • Multicystic Dysplastic Kidney
  • Turner’s Syndrome

questions.text: In metal factories, the temperature is measured by the Kelvin scale. It is an example of ____ type of data measurement.
questions.solution:
Kelvin temperature measurement is an example of Ratio scale data.

Ratio scales are similar to interval scales but additionally, there is an absolute zero and therefore meaningful ratios do exist.

Kelvin scale is the only scale of temperature where the zero actually indicates an absolute absence of heat. 

Related Pearl: Scales of data measurement

Data can be quantitative (numerical values) or qualitative (types, labels).

Quantitative data can be discrete variables or continuous variables.

 

Description

Example

Discrete data

Can take certain values and none in between

Number of cancer patients in a hospital. 

Continuous data

Can take any value usually in between limits or a range. 

Most biomedical data is continuous.

Height, weight, blood pressure, etc.

 

Data always forms one of four scales of measurement – nominal, ordinal, interval, or ratio scales (mnemonic: NOIR):

 

Nominal Scale Data

Ordinal Scale Data

Interval Scale Data

Ratio Scale Data

Example

Male/female; red/green; sub-urban/rural

Students ranked 1st/2nd/3rd in their class. 

A customer feedback survey using terms like very good, good, poor and very poor or the Likert Scale.

Severity of a disease as mild, moderate, severe

 

 Measurements on the celsius scale. Pulse rate; 

Notes

Have no quantitative value.

They have no order or ratio. 

Arranged in a meaningful order.

No size interval is defined

Arranged in a meaningful order with a well defined size interval.

Example: Temperature in Celsius. If temperature in A is 40 deg Celsius and that in B is 20 deg Celsius, then A is 20 deg Celsius hotter than B (taking difference)

Does not have an absolute zero.

For example, Celsius scale has no such thing as “no temperature”. So the value cannot be zero.

Arranged in a meaningful order with a well defined size interval.

Eg: A pulse rate has well defined intervals and is meaningful in comparison. A 100/min pulse is exactly twice of 50 beats/min.

 

Has an absolute zero.

Eg: There can be a value of zero for pulse.

Type

Qualitative

Qualitative

Quantitative

Quantitative

questions.text: A 3-year-old baby with a large head was found to have persistent Blake's pouch leading to cystic obstruction of the median outlet from the fourth ventricle. Perforation of this membrane structure normally occurs at ____ week of fetal development, failure of which has led to this presentation.
questions.solution:
Blake's pouch normally perforates at 9th week of fetal development.

Blake's pouch cyst is caused due to the non perforation of the foramen of Magendie.

The roof of the fourth ventricle communicates posteriorly with the cisterna magna through a median aperture called the foramen of Magendie. During fetal development, the roof of IV ventricle is formed by the anterior and posterior membranous area (AMA, PMA). Blake's pouch is a temporary finger-like growth of the PMA which communicates with the IV ventricle. During the 9th week of the development, Blake's pouch perforates to form foramen Magendie. The persistence of Blake's pouch leads to a condition called Blake's pouch cyst.

Communications of the ventricular system:

  • Lateral ventricle to the third ventricle: Foramen of Monro
  • III ventricle to IV ventricle: Cerebral aqueduct of Sylvius
  • IV ventricle to subarachnoid space
    • Cisterna magna: Foramen of Magendie (midline)
    • Subarachnoid space: Foramina of Luschka (laterally)

Clinical note:

  • The outflow of CSF from the IV ventricle is via the medial outlet. This is covered by a membrane in the fetus which perforates later. The persistence of this membrane causes cystic obstruction. 
  • In Dandy-Walker malformation, there is the presence of many posterior fossa anomalies such as cystic dilation of the fourth ventricle,  hydrocephalus, hypoplasia of the cerebellar vermis, and an enlarged posterior fossa.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy who was treated for acute otitis media 2 weeks back presents with fever,  and pain behind his right ear. On examination, tenderness is present over the mastoid and the pinna is pushed anteriorly suggesting acute mastoiditis. A fluctuant swelling is present between the tip of the mastoid and the angle of the jaw. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario along is most likely suggestive of the diagnosis of Bezold's abscess.

Bezold abscess is defined as a complication of acute coalescent mastoiditis and is formed when pus breaks inferiorly, through the thin medial aspect of the tip of the mastoid and collects in the upper part of the neck, most commonly into the sheath of the sternocleidomastoid muscle. The abscess can also take any of the following locations: 

  • Deep to the sternocleidomastoid
  • Along the posterior belly of the digastric presenting as a swelling in the tip of the mastoid or the angle of the jaw
  • The upper part of the posterior triangle
  • Parapharyngeal space
  • Along with the carotid vessels.


Treatment:

  1. Cortical mastoidectomy for coalescent mastoiditis
  2. Drainage of the abscess in the neck with insertion of a drain through a separate incision
  3. IV antibiotics

Other options:

Option A: Zygomatic abscess forms due to infection of the zygomatic air cells. It is situated at the posterior root of the zygoma.  Patients present with swelling in front and above the pinna with associated edema over the upper eyelid. Here the pus collects either superficial or deep to the temporalis muscle.

Option C: Luc abscess is defined as a subperiosteal temporal abscess. It develops following the spread of infection from the middle ear along the external auditory meatus, directly, to the temporal region. Swelling is present in the deep part of the bony meatus. 

Option D: Citelli’s abscess is formed posterior to the mastoid, occupying a position more towards the occipital bone. It is also considered an abscess of the digastric triangle. In any case, a diagnosis of Bezold abscess is more appropriate for this patient owing to the location of the abscess.

questions.text:
A 30-year-old male presents to the ER after a road traffic accident. He is hypotensive and pale. The FAST scan reveals massive intraabdominal bleeding. He receives 4 units of packed red blood cell transfusion in the next hour. Which of the following complications can be expected in this patient?
  1. Hypercalcemia
  2. Hyperkalemia
  3. Hypokalemia
  4. Hypermagnesemia
  5. Metabolic alkalosis
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette describing a patient who received 4 units of packed red blood cell transfusion(pRBCs) in 1 hour indicates massive blood transfusion. The expected electrolyte abnormalities in a massive blood transfusion are -

  • Hypocalcemia
  • Hyperkalemia
  • Hypokalemia
  • Hypomagnesemia
  • Metabolic acidosis
  • Metabolic alkalosis
  • Hypothermia
  • Coagulopathy

Related Pearl: Complications of a Massive Transfusion

Massive transfusion (MT) is defined as the replacement by transfusion of 10 units of pRBCs in 24 hours or more than 4 units of pRBCs in one hour.

Complications from massive transfusion include:

Complication Mechanism
Hypothermia As blood products are normally stored between 1°C and 6°C
Coagulopathy

MT with PRBCs alone causes a dilutional coagulopathy (vs consumptive coagulopathy caused by massive hemorrhage)

Can be prevented by starting early transfusion of FFP, platelets, pRBCs in a 1:1:1 ratio
Acidosis/ Alkalosis

Mild acidosis - increased CO2 levels in stored blood by 21-35 days

Metabolic alkalosis - citrate gets metabolized to bicarbonate

Metabolic acidosis - due to tissue hypoperfusion
Hyperkalemia/ Hypokalemia

Initially - Hyperkalemia, as stored blood has high K+ levels due to inactivated Na/K/ATPase pump

Later - Hypokalemia, due to intracellular potassium uptake and metabolic alkalosis
Hypocalcemia Stored blood is anticoagulated with citrate, which binds calcium.
Hypomagnesemia Infusion of large volumes of magnesium-poor fluids and binding of magnesium to citrate
Impaired O2-carrying capacity of hemoglobin Decreased 2, 3 DPG
Volume overload Due to massive transfusion

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient presents with unilateral scrotal swelling. On examination, the swelling shows transillumination and the testis is palpable separate from the swelling. The fluid aspirated from the swelling resembles barley water in appearance. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a patient presenting with a unilateral scrotal swelling, which shows transillumination, and fluid aspirated from the swelling showing a barley water appearance is suggestive of a spermatocele.

A spermatocele is an unilocular retention cyst derived from the epididymis. It is a cystic lesion that transilluminates. When aspirated, the fluid has a characteristic barley water appearance due to the presence of spermatozoa.

Transillumination can be present in swelling caused by spermatoceles or an epididymal cyst. Differences between a spermatocele and an epididymal cyst are demonstrated in the table below:

Spermatocele Epididymal cyst
Unilocular retention cyst Multiple, multilocular (bunch of grapes on palpation)

Present at the epididymal head, above and behind the upper pole of testes

 Posterior to testis
Barley water fluid appearance on aspiration Aspiration is usually ineffective as the cyst is multilocular
Treatment: Excision Treatment: Excision


Hydrocele is a scrotal swelling caused by the accumulation of serous fluid in the processus vaginalis. Clinically, a hydrocele encloses the testis and the epididymis. Hence, the testis will not be palpable separately from the swelling.

questions.text: A patient with diagnosed peptic ulcer disease develops sudden intense abdominal pain and distension. A plain supine x-ray of his abdomen is shown below. What is the characteristic sign seen in the given x-ray?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and x-ray image are suggestive of pneumoperitoneum, and the characteristic sign seen in the x-ray is Rigler's sign or double-wall sign. The inner mucosal and outer serosal layers of the bowel wall are enhanced due to the presence of air on both sides of the bowel lumen. 

Pneumoperitoneum refers to air within the peritoneal cavity. Radiological signs include:

  • Bowel related signs
    • Double-wall sign (also known as Rigler's sign): Both the outer and inner walls of the bowel are visible.
    • Telltale triangle sign (also known as triangle sign): A radiolucent triangle of gas between three loops of bowel or between two loops of bowel and the abdominal wall.
  • Peritoneal ligament related signs
    • Football sign -the abdominal cavity is outlined by gas from a perforated viscus, seen in massive pneumoperitoneum.
    • Falciform ligament sign - Falciform or medial umbilical ligaments may be seen due to free gas on either side of the ligaments. 
    • Lateral umbilical ligament sign (also known as inverted "V" sign) - Free gas routines the lateral umbilical ligament.
  • Right upper quadrant signs
    • Morison's pouch sign - a triangular area of gas in the right upper quadrant, usually bound by the 11th rib in the right upper quadrant in the area of Morrison's pouch.
    • Cupola sign - Gas under the right and left hemidiaphragm joining in the midline. Seen on chest X-ray.

Other options:

Option A - The spinnaker-sail sign (or angel wing sign) is characteristic of a pneumomediastinum in neonates. Both the lobes of the thymus are lifted and displaced laterally due to the air in the mediastinum. A wedge-shaped opacity is created extending into the superior mediastinum. 

Option B - Cupola sign is also seen in pneumoperitoneum. It refers to the gas accumulated under the diaphragm in the midline underneath the central tendon. It is seen in supine films of abdominal x-ray. 

Option D - Stepladder sign (or concertina effect) is seen in small intestinal obstruction. It represents the gas-fluid distended loops stacked upon each other, best appreciated in erect abdomen x-ray.

questions.text: A 4-year-old child presented with a 7-day history of a generalized pruritic rash, which started around the neck, without a history of cough, fever, or rhinorrhea. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image shows a large number of minute thin-walled vesicles on the trunk, consistent with a diagnosis of miliaria.

Other options:

Option A: Folliculitis would involve specific inflammation in the pilosebaceous units.

Option B:  Infantile acne would have characteristic comedones, papules, and pustules. Moreover, the question states the boy is 4 years old. 

Option D: Candidal infections usually occur as macerated erythematous lesions in the intertriginous areas.  

Note: Milia, conversely, are tiny keratin‐filled, epithelial‐lined cysts that are not connected to the overlying skin.

Related Pearl: Different types of miliaria

Miliaria is a common acute or subacute skin condition that arises due to the occlusion or disruption of eccrine sweat ducts in hot humid conditions.

Based on the level of blockade it is differentiated into

  • Miliaria Crystallina- Stratum corneum
  • Miliaria Rubra - Malpighian Layer
  • Miliaria profunda - Dermoepidermal junction

Pathophysiology:

  • The first event may be an increase in the skin flora, perhaps with Staphylococcus epidermidis being responsible for producing an extracellular polysaccharide substance or slime that blocks the lumen of the sweat duct.
  • The parakeratotic plugs, a notable feature of the later stages of the disease, are not the primary cause of the obstruction but arise in the repair process, and further aggravate the obstruction.
  • Leakage of sweat into the epidermis is responsible for the final production of the lesions, and for their further aggravation.
  • Miliaria crystallina occurs commonly in infants due to a delay in the development of patency in the sweat ducts.

Clinical features:

  • Miliaria crystallina: Clear, thin‐walled vesicles, 1–2 mm in diameter without an inflammatory areola, are usually symptomless and develop in crops, mainly on the trunk. In persistent febrile illnesses, recurrent crops may occur. The vesicles soon rupture and are followed by superficial, branny desquamation.

 

  • Miliaria rubra: Typical lesions develop on the body, especially in areas of friction with clothing, and in flexures. The lesions are uniformly minute erythematous papules, which may be present in very large numbers. Characteristically, the lesions produce intense discomfort in the form of an unbearable pricking sensation. Relief is often instantaneous when the stimulus to sweating is abolished by a cool shower. In infants, lesions commonly appear on the occluded skin of the neck, groins and axillae, but also occur elsewhere.

 

 

  • Miliaria profunda: This nearly always follows repeated attacks of miliaria rubra, and is common only in the tropics. The lesions are easily missed. The affected skin is covered with pale, firm papules 1–3 mm across, especially on the body, but sometimes also on the limbs. There is no itching or discomfort from the lesions.

 

Treatment:

  • First line
    • Control local environment (remove excess bedding, fans, air
    conditioning)
    • Cool the skin (damp compresses, cool showers)
    • Avoid tight or excessive clothing
  • Second line
    • Menthol (e.g. 0.5% menthol in aqueous cream)
    • Topical antibiotics if there is secondary infection
    • Mild topical steroids
  • Third line
    • Removal to cooler climate
    • Prophylactic oral vitamin C

questions.text: A 45-year-old businessman presents to your OPD with complaints of insomnia. His job requires frequent travel to foreign countries and he always has a jet lag issue. Which of the following drugs would be the most appropriate for his treatment?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette describes transient sleep disorder which includes jet lag and shift work transition. The best and most effective pharmacological agent against this situation is ramelteon. 

Ramelteon:

Ramelteon is a melatonin receptor agonist acting directly on MT1 and MT2 mediated G-protein coupled receptors and induces sleep. It is considered to be more effective than melatonin. It is safer than melatonin as it has no addiction liability. It is less effective than benzodiazipines. It has a half-life of 5 hours.

Ramelteon is metabolized by CYP450 enzyme system and should not be taken along with drugs or substances inhibiting CYPA12 enzyme (ciprofloxacin, zileuton, and fluvoxamine) and Flucanazole (CYP2C9). It should be cautiously used with rifampin, an enzyme inducer. This can lead on to decreased function.

Side effects include dizziness, fatigue, somnalesence, and an increase in prolactin levels. Ramelteon undergoes extensive first pass metabolism its bioavailability is less than 2%.

Its congener family includes: 

  • Tasimelteon used for treatment of chronic sleep disorders like the non 24-hours sleep wake disorder. It is also used to treat insomnia in blind people. 
  • Agomelatine along with MT1 and MT2 agonistic activity has 5HT2c antagonistic activity and thus is approved for treatment of major depressive disorder with insomnia. 

Other options:

Option A: Zolpidem belongs to novel benzodiazepine receptor agonists called Z compounds. It binds to the BZD receptor present on the GABA receptor chloride channel complex.

Option B: Modafinil (wakefulness-promoting drug) is the drug of choice in narcolepsy which is characterized by the tetrad of: 

  • Excessive daytime sleepiness
  • Cataplexy (sudden loss of muscle tone)
  • Hypnagogic hallucinations
  • Sleep paralysis
