questions.text: A 40-year-old man was treated for a high-grade soft-tissue sarcoma with radiotherapy. Since he was not responding, he was shifted to chemotherapy. After initiating chemotherapy, he developed erythematous rashes over the areas where radiotherapy was administered earlier. Which of the following drugs is likely to cause this condition?
questions.solution:
Doxorubicin can result in a radiation recall reaction where erythema and desquamation of skin are observed at sites of previous radiation injury. 

Radiation recall syndrome is an acute inflammatory response confined to the areas that are previously irradiated, which can be triggered by the administration of chemotherapeutic agents. Studies show that the common drugs causing this phenomenon are:

  • Doxorubicin
  • Docetaxel and paclitaxel
  • Gemcitabine and capecitabine

Radiation sensitization - This is more common than radiation recall. This is a period of enhanced sensitivity in the days after irradiation when the reaction to systemically administered drugs and the time interval between the end of radiation and chemotherapy is <7 days. Such reactions can be considered radiation enhancement or sensitization. 

Radiation recall - This is less common than radiation sensitization. When the time interval between the end of radiation and chemotherapy is >7 days, months, or even years.

The major side effects of doxorubicin are: 

  • Myelosuppression 
  • Cardiomyopathy.

questions.text: A 16-year-old female is brought to the clinic for evaluation of primary amenorrhea. She complains of mild chest pain and cold extremities on exertion. Physical examination reveals a short-statured teenager, with a webbed neck and absence of secondary sexual characteristics. Blood pressure is 150/90 mm Hg in bilateral upper extremities. There is a brachial-femoral delay. Which of the following findings is unlikely to be seen in this patient?

choices.text: A continuous murmur in the interscapular region

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario describes a case of coarctation of the aorta in a patient with Turner's syndrome who presents with primary amenorrhea. Patients with Turner's syndrome predominantly have elevated FSH levels and in some cases, the levels may be normal. But low FSH is not seen in these patients. 

Coarctation of the aorta is a condition where there is a narrowing of the descending aorta, which is located usually at the insertion of the ductus arteriosus just distal to the left subclavian artery. Children present with chest pain, cold extremities, and claudication with exertion. A physical examination will reveal hypertension in the upper extremities and a brachial-femoral delay. The blood pressure in the lower extremities may be unobtainable.

The first and second heart sounds are usually normal. P2 will be loud if there is associated pulmonary hypertension. Ejection systolic click and systolic ejection murmur may be heard in patients with a bicuspid aortic valve which is a common association. Systolic ejection murmurs and continuous murmurs may be heard in the interscapular regions. The diagnosis is confirmed by echocardiography. A chest x-ray will show inferior rib-notching and a barium swallow will show a "reverse 3" appearance

 

Turner's syndrome (Hypergonadotrophic hypogonadism):

Primary amenorrhea refers to the failure of onset of menstruation, beyond the age of 16 years regardless of the development of secondary sexual characteristics. This patient's clinical picture of amenorrhea, short stature, webbed neck, low hairline at the back of the neck, widely spaced nipples, and lack of secondary sexual characteristics is seen in Turner's syndrome. Turner's syndrome is a chromosomal abnormality with partial or complete monosomy of the X chromosome (45+XO).

In Turner's syndrome, gonadal dysgenesis causes primary ovarian failure that is hypogonadism. The levels of Follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH), and luteinizing hormone (LH) are indicative of the cause of hypogonadism. Increased levels of FSH and LH as seen in this patient are indicative of hypergonadotropic hypogonadism. Hypergonadotropic hypogonadism is defined as 1) a decrease or absence in ovarian function and 2) due to absent negative sex-steroid feedback. 

The pathophysiology in Turner's syndrome is primary hypergonadotropic hypogonadism where there is oocyte atresia and the replacement of ovaries by fibrous streaks. This causes a decrease in serum estrogen levels which by negative feedback to cause a rise in Gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH), FSH, and LH (gonadotropic hormones) as seen in this patient. Hypogonadism with a rise in gonadotropic hormones is known as hypergonadotropic hypogonadism.

questions.text:
Match the following:
  1. First-degree heart block
  2. Mobitz type 1 heart block
  3. Mobitz type 2 heart block
  4. Complete heart block
questions.solution:
The correctly matched pairs are 1-c, 2-a, 3-d, and 4-b.

The different types of heart blocks are:

First Degree Heart Block: It occurs due to slowing of conduction through the AV junction. It is characterized by prolonged PR > 0.2s and equal RR intervals.

Second Degree Heart Block: It occurs due to the intermittent failure of electrical impulse conduction from the atrium to the ventricle. It is characterized by a missed QRS. It is of two types:

  • Mobitz type 1 (Wenckebach) occurs due to the decremental conduction of electrical impulses in the AV node. It is characterized by a progressive PR elongation leading to an eventual drop in the QRS complex. This may be seen in young athletes.
  • Mobitz type 2 occurs in the distal or infra-His conduction system and is often associated with intraventricular conduction delays. It is characterized by an intermittent failure of conduction of the p wave without any change in the preceding impulses. On ECG, there is a fixed PR interval and missed QRS.

Third Degree Heart Block/Complete Heart Block: It occurs when none of the impulses from the atria are conducted to the ventricles. It is characterized by

  • Escape rhythm
  • RR equal, PP equal
  • P waves > QRS waves
  • No relationship between P & QRS

questions.text: A 34-year-old male who was newly diagnosed with HIV is being evaluated prior to initiation of antiretroviral therapy. Which of the following techniques is used to determine the CD4+ cell count in his peripheral blood?
questions.solution:
Flow cytometry is used to determine the CD4 count in the peripheral blood.

Flow cytometry is a laser based method which analyzes the cells and cell components based on the presence of certain cell surface molecules which are named as per cluster of differentiation (CD) nomenclature.

There are about 300 types of CD molecules. Monoclonal antibodies against specific CD molecules are tagged with fluorescent labels. Incubation of the cells with a variety of different CD labeled antibodies allows the flow cytometric analysis of distinct populations of cells in the mixture.

Flow cytometry is routinely used in identifying CD4-positive cells, CD8-positive cells, B cells, macrophages, and cells expressing a variety of cytokines.

Related Pearl: NACO ART Guidelines- 2021

ART regimen

First-line for:

Tenofovir + Lamivudine + Dolutegravir

  • Those with HIV-TB and HIV hepatitis co-infections
  • Pregnant women, pregnant women presenting in active labour and breastfeeding women

Abacavir + Lamivudine + Efavirenz

Tenofovir + Lamivudine + Efavirenz /Lopinavir /Ritonavir
  • Women of childbearing age group who do not wish to take Dolutegravir

questions.text:
A 32-year-old woman came with throat pain radiating to the jaw, fever, tremors, palpitations, and heat intolerance for the past 3 weeks. She had an upper respiratory tract infection a few days before these symptoms. Examination reveals a slightly enlarged, extremely tender thyroid gland. Radioiodine uptake scan with scintigraphy will show:

TSH level: 0.04 mIU/L

free T4 level: 2.8 ng/dL

Erythrocyte sedimentation rate: Elevated

Total WBC count: normal
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and elevated ESR are suggestive of the thyrotoxic phase of subacute thyroiditis. It shows reduced uptake of radioiodine on scintigraphy.

Subacute (painful) thyroiditis is also known as de Quervain’s thyroiditis, granulomatous thyroiditis, or viral thyroiditis. It is usually precipitated due to a viral infection, but may also be seen in periods of stress.

They are predominantly seen in the age group of 30-50 years with a female preponderance. 

Patients with subacute thyroiditis usually present with a sore throat, referred pain to neck or ear, history of upper respiratory tract infection. Examination reveals enlarged tender thyroid. 

Thyroid function tests evolve through three distinct phases:

  • In the initial thyrotoxic phase, T4 and T3 are elevated and TSH is suppressed. It is confirmed by high ESR and low radioiodine uptake
  • Hypothyroid phase
  • Later recovery phase

The initial phase of follicular destruction releases thyroid hormones leading to increased circulating T4 and T3 and suppression of TSH.

Treatment is aimed at symptomatic relief. NSAIDs are often effective for mild-to-moderate disease, but glucocorticoids may be necessary for more severe or refractory pain. Anti-thyroid drugs are not effective for the thyrotoxic phase.  Levothyroxine can be given in the prolonged hypothyroid phase. 

Other conditions in which the radioactive iodine uptake is low are:

  • postpartum thyroiditis
  • thyrotoxicosis factitia
  • excessive circulating exogenous iodine (contrast dyes)

Other options:

Option B: Increased patchy uptake is seen in toxic multinodular goiter.

Option C: Increased diffuse uptake is seen in Graves' disease.

questions.text: A 3-year-old girl is being evaluated for congenital ptosis. On examination, there is retraction of the ptotic lid when she is asked to move her jaw from side to side. It is inferred that there is a misdirection of the nerve supplying the jaw muscles to the levator palpebrae muscle. Identify the misdirected nerve.
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario describes Marcus–Gunn jaw-winking syndrome. The misdirected cranial nerve supplying the jaw muscles is the mandibular division of the trigeminal nerve labeled as '4'.

Trigeminal nerve

The trigeminal nerve leaves the anterior aspect of the pons as a small motor root and a large sensory root. The nerve passes forward out of the posterior cranial fossa and rests on the upper surface of the apex of the petrous part of the temporal bone in the middle cranial fossa. The large sensory root now expands to form the crescent-shaped trigeminal ganglion, which lies within a pouch of dura mater called the trigeminal or Meckel cave. The ophthalmic, maxillary, and mandibular nerves arise from the anterior border of the ganglion.

Branches of the trigeminal nerve

  • The ophthalmic nerve (V1)
    • Leaves the skull through the superior orbital fissure to enter the orbital cavity.
    • Contains only sensory fibers
      • Cornea
      • Skin of forehead, scalp, eyelids, and nose
      • Mucous membrane of paranasal sinuses and nasal cavity
  • The maxillary nerve (V2)
    • Leaves the skull through the foramen rotundum.
    • Contains only sensory fibers from
      • Teeth of upper jaw
      • Skin of face over maxilla
      • Mucous membrane of nose, the maxillary sinus, and palate
  • The mandibular nerve (V3)
    • Leaves the skull through the foramen ovale.
    • Contains both sensory and motor fibers.
    • Sensory from
      • Skin of cheek, over mandible and side of head
      • Teeth of lower jaw and temporomandibular joint
      • Mucous membrane of mouth and anterior part of tongue
    • Motor to
      • Muscles of mastication (pterygoids, masseter and temporalis)
      • Tensor tympani
      • Anterior belly of digastric
      • Mylohyoid

Marcus–Gunn jaw-winking syndrome:

  • About 5% of all cases of congenital ptosis are associated with the Marcus–Gunn jaw-winking phenomenon.
  • The vast majority are unilateral.
  • Etiology: a branch of the mandibular division of the fifth cranial nerve is misdirected to the levator muscle.
  • Signs
    • Retraction of the ptotic lid in conjunction with stimulation of the ipsilateral pterygoid muscles by chewing, sucking, opening the mouth, or contralateral jaw movement.
    • Less common stimuli to winking include jaw protrusion, smiling, swallowing, and clenching of teeth.
    • Jaw-winking does not improve with age although patients may learn to mask it.

Image: The woman cannot control her eyelids while drinking.

Image: showing the anterior surface of pons and the cranial nerves.

questions.text:
Which of the following represents the correct match among the following types of shock and their corresponding characteristics?
  Cardiac output Venous pressure Vascular resistance
A Low Low High
B Low High High
C Low High High
D High Low Low

choices.text: A - Obstructive; B - Hypovolaemic; C - Distributive; D - Cardiogenic
A - Hypovolaemic; B - Obstructive; C - Cardiogenic; D - Distributive
A - Obstructive; B - Cardiogenic; C - Hypovolaemic; D - Distributive
A - Distributive; B - Cardiogenic; C - Obstructive; D - Hypovolaemic

questions.solution:
The correct match is as below:

  Cardiac output Venous pressure Vascular resistance Mixed venous saturation Base deficit
Hypovolemic Low Low High Low High
Obstructive Low High High Low High
Cardiogenic Low High High Low High
Distributive High Low Low High High

Hypovolemic shock - 
It is due to reduced circulating volume. Causes include hemorrhage, dehydration, vomiting, third spacing.

Obstructive Shock -
Leads to a reduction in preload due to mechanical obstruction of cardiac filling. Causes include cardiac tamponade, tension pneumothorax, massive pulmonary embolus, or air embolus.

Cardiogenic shock - 
Due to the failure of the heart to pump blood to tissues. Causes include myocardial infarction, cardiac dysrhythmias, valvular heart disease, blunt myocardial injury, and cardiomyopathy

Distributive shock - 
Distributive shock is the condition of reduced oxygen delivery where the primary physiologic disturbance is a reduction in systemic vascular resistance leading to vasodilation. It is unique among the types of shock in that there is a compensatory increase in cardiac output. Causes include spinal shock, anaphylaxis, and septic shock.

questions.text: A 42-year-old man who was under home isolation after testing positive for COVID-19, develops breathing difficulty and is brought to the ER. The patient is alert and responsive, but is breathing rapidly. SpO2 is measured to be 86%. He is administered oxygen via a face mask with a reservoir bag with a flow rate of 10 L/min. After a trial of one hour, his SpO2 is 88%. What is the next step in management?
questions.solution:
This patient has persistent hypoxia after an adequate trial of standard oxygen therapy and should be started on high-flow nasal cannula oxygen therapy. 

When respiratory distress and/or hypoxemia of the patient cannot be alleviated after receiving standard oxygen therapy, high–flow nasal cannula oxygen therapy (HFNO), or non–invasive ventilation can be considered. Compared to standard oxygen therapy, HFNO reduces the need for intubation.

Patients on HFNO should be closely monitored, and endotracheal intubation should be done if the patient acutely deteriorates or does not improve after a short trial (about 1 hr).

Patients with hypercapnia (exacerbation of COPD), hemodynamic instability, multi-organ failure, or abnormal mental status should not receive HFNO.

Note: If a high flow nasal cannula (HFNC) or simple nasal cannula is used to administer O2, an N95 mask should be applied over it.

Some of the benefits of HFNC are

  • It can deliver oxygen at 40L/min, 37°C, and 99.9% relative humidity.
  • The high-flow oxygen is delivered directly to the nasopharynx. This produces FiO2 equal to that delivered by traditional mask devices.
  • It also reduces the work of breathing, improves gas exchange by nasopharyngeal dead-space washout, and decreases energy required to humidify and heat respiratory gases.

The HFNC equipment shown in the image below uses a heated humidifier (named PMH200), a nasal cannula (no. 2), and a ventilator (brand: vivo30).

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy is brought to the clinic for evaluation of persistent pallor, recurrent bruising, and bone pain. Physical examination reveals a low-grade fever and generalized lymphadenopathy. Further workup demonstrates positive TdT and a translocation, t(12;21). Which of the following is incorrect about the findings in this patient?

choices.text: There will be scant cytoplasm and absence of granules
Starry sky appearance maybe seen due to macrophages ingesting apoptotic cells
The nuclei of tumor cells will be much smaller than small lymphocytes

questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette describes a case of acute lymphoblastic leukemia in a young male patient with persistent anemia, fever, lymphadenopathy, and frequent bruising. Patients with ALL will be positive for TdT in more than 95% of the cases. Translocation, t(12;21) if present in patients with ALL, is a good prognostic factor. The nuclei of these tumor cells is larger than the small lymphocytes.

Histopathology of ALL:

  • The marrow is hypercellular and packed with lymphoblasts. These cells replace the normal marrow.
  • The tumor cells have a basophilic cytoplasm. The nuclei of these cells is larger than the small lymphocytes. The nucleoli are usually small.
  • The nuclear chromatin is delicate and finely stippled, and nucleoli are small and demarcated by a rim of condensed chromatin
  • The nuclear membrane is deeply subdivided and gives a convoluted appearance
  • The macrophages engulfing the apoptotic tumor cells might give it a starry sky appearance as in other rapidly growing tumors.
  • The Ki-67 or mitotic index will be high in these cells
  • Lymphoblasts have scant cytoplasm with no granulations. They are myeloperoxidase negative and contain PAS-positive cytoplasmic material

Cytogenetics and immunophenotype:

  • 95% of cases express TdT
  • Immature B-ALLs do not express CD10. Late pre-B-ALLs express CD10, CD19 and CD20
  • T-ALLs are positive for CD1, CD2, CD5 and CD7

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman complains of difficulty in swallowing for the past few months. She also complains of bluish discoloration of fingers on exposure to cold for the past 5 years. On examination, she is found to have thickening of the skin of the hands and multiple dilated capillaries over the face. Which of the following is most specific for this disease?
questions.solution:
This patient's clinical features are suggestive of CREST syndrome / limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis, and anti-centromere antibodies are most specific for this disease.

CREST syndrome consists of :

  • Calcinosis cutis
  • Raynaud’s phenomenon
  • Esophageal dysmotility
  • Sclerodactyly
  • Telangiectasia

Systemic sclerosis (SSc) is a chronic autoimmune disease. Progressive fibrosis due to the deposition of extracellular matrix components in different tissue and organs is the prominent feature of SSc. 

The characteristic features of SSc are vascular damage, inflammation, and the presence of specific autoantibodies. 

SSc is classified into two based on the extent of skin involvement.

  • Limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis / CREST syndrome
  • Diffuse cutaneous systemic sclerosis

In limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis (lcSSc), fibrosis in the skin of acral parts of the body, like the face and limbs (distal to elbow and knee) takes place. 

Skin fibrosis in limited type has a slow progression but microcirculation disturbances like Raynaud's phenomenon start long before the skin symptoms and are associated with the involvement of the lungs and esophagus. 

Since it has late and slow organ involvement, it is associated with a good prognosis with a 10-year survival of over 90%. 

Antinuclear antibodies (ANA) are present in 90 - 95% of cases with SSc.

Autoantibodies specific to Limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis include,

  • Anti- centromere
  • Anti-Th/To
  • Anti-U1-RNP
  • Anti-hUBF

Management is based on disease-modifying and organ-specific drugs. For peripheral vasculopathy and digital ulcers, calcium channel blockers like nifedipine, amlodipine is used and for refractory cases, phosphodiesterase 5 inhibitors are recommended.

Intravenous prostanoids are used for the healing process of digital ulcers and the improvement of microcirculation. The commonly used immunosuppressants for skin fibrosis are methotrexate, cyclophosphamide, and mycophenolate mofetil. When these drugs are ineffective or contraindicated, low-dose glucocorticosteroids or rituximab (anti-CD20) are used. 

Other options:

Options A and C- Anti-ds DNA antibodies and  Anti-Sm antibodies are specific for SLE.

Option D- Anti-SRP antibodies are characteristically seen in necrotizing myopathies.

questions.text: A 28-year-old male who has been extensively smoking for the past 5 years, presents to the ED with a sudden onset of fever with hemoptysis and hematuria. On examination, he is dyspneic and pale. A panel of blood investigations done on him shows anemia with deranged renal function. The nephrologist suspects him to have antibodies against α3 NC1 domain of collagen IV and proceeds to perform an urgent renal biopsy. Which of the following histological pattern is expected to be present in this case?
questions.solution:
The clinical features, lab investigations, and suspicion of having antibodies against the α3 NC1 domain of collagen IV narrows down the diagnosis to Goodpasture’s syndrome. The expected histologic pattern in this patient is the presence of crescents in the glomeruli, as seen in image B.

Patients who develop antibodies against glomerular basement antigens frequently develop glomerulonephritis termed anti-glomerular basement membrane (anti-GBM) disease. When glomerulonephritis is combined with lung haemorrhage, as seen in our case, it is termed Goodpasture’s syndrome.

Certain features of the anti-GBM disease

  • The autoantibodies are directed against the α3 NC1 domain of collagen IV and predominantly belong to the IgG group.
  • The clinical presentation can occur in two groups
    •  Younger men in their late twenties
      • They present in an explosive manner with hemoptysis, a sudden fall in hemoglobin, fever, dyspnoea, and hematuria
      • Lung haemorrhage is a usual presentation in smokers, but surprisingly they do better than the other group
    • Older men and women in their sixties and seventies
      • These geriatric populations run a prolonged, asymptomatic course and end up with chronic renal failure with oliguria, and the prognosis is usually worse.

Characteristic histological pattern progresses as given below

  • Focal or segmental necrosis
  • Crescent formation (due to the destruction of capillaries by excessive cellular proliferation)
  • Interstitial nephritis with fibrosis and tubular atrophy

Immunofluorescent staining shows a linear pattern for IgG.

Other images

Image A shows a normal glomerulus

Image C shows segmental sclerosis of the glomeruli

Image D shows diffuse thickening of the basement membrane

questions.text:
Match the following:
a. Pilocarpine 1. Mydriasis without cycloplegia
b. Atropine 2. Decongestant
c. Phenylephrine 3. Mydriasis with cycloplegia
d. Naphazoline 4. Miosis
questions.solution:
The correct option is a-4, b-3, c- 1, d-2.

Pilocarpine is a cholinergic agonist and is used to induce miosis during surgery.

Atropine is a muscarinic antagonist and has both mydriatic and cycloplegic action, required for refraction testing. 

Phenylephrine is an alpha-adrenergic agonist which produces mydriasis but without cycloplegia. Cycloplegia occurs when the ciliary muscles are blocked. Phenylephrine acts on the radial muscle (dilator pupillae) of the iris and causes mydriasis. It has no cycloplegic action because sympathetic receptors are present only on the iris and not on the ciliary body. 

Naphazoline is also an alpha-adrenergic agonist, which is used as an ocular decongestant.

Note: Phenylephrine also causes ocular decongestion, but is used off-label.

questions.text: A 25-year-old primigravida presented at term with a USG report suggesting fetus in breech position and on per vaginal examination, toes of the foot can be felt. What is the next step in management?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, the fetus is in a footling breech position at term, which is an indication for the cesarean section.

In footling breech, one or both legs are extended at the hip, so that the foot is the presenting part.

A major complication of breech presentation is cord prolapse. In the cord prolapse, the umbilical cord drops down below the presenting part of the baby and becomes compressed.

Factors favoring cesarean delivery of the breech fetus:

  • Large fetus: > 3800 to 4000 g
  • Apparently healthy and viable preterm fetus either with active labor or with indicated delivery
  • Severe IUGR
  • Footling presentation (due to risk of cord prolapse)
  • Hyperextended head
  • Contracted pelvis
  • Prior cesarean delivery
  • Preterm breech
  • Primi with breech
  • Twins, with the first baby in the breech

questions.text: A 30-year-old nulliparous woman comes to the infertility clinic with complaints of chronic pelvic pain and irregular menstruation. An endometrial biopsy was taken and the findings are shown in the image below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the image showing caseating granulomas suggest a diagnosis of endometrial tuberculosis. 

The endometrium is involved in 50–60% of all cases of genital tuberculosis. It can appear grossly normal due to cyclical shedding. The diagnosis is made by histopathological examination, which shows the above findings. 

It occurs as a descending infection from the fallopian tubes due to anatomical proximity and continuity. Hematogenous spread is thought to be the process by which the tubercle bacilli implant into the mucosa of the fallopian tubes and subsequently affect the endometrium by direct extension. There is a reinfection every month due to shedding off of the endometrium during menstruation 

Findings:

  • Ulcerative, granular, or fungating lesions may be seen occasionally
  • Shrunken cavity due to fibrosis
  • Golf-ball ostia of fallopian tubes 
  • Extensive fibrosis can also close the internal os causing pyometra 
  • Intrauterine adhesions - Asherman syndrome 

Genital tract tuberculosis is among the commonest causes of infertility. They often present with a history of infertility, irregular menstruation, and vaginal discharge.

Treatment includes standard anti-tubercular therapy based on drug sensitivity patterns.

The below histology image of endometrial tuberculosis shows Langhans cells, caseating granulomas, and epithelioid cells in the background of endometrial glands and an image of hysterosalpingogram showing endometrial tuberculosis.

  • If all the above procedures fail or not feasible go for IVF/GIFT

  • Poly-Drug Resistant (PDR): A TB patient, who is resistant to more than one 1st line anti-TB drug, other than Rifampicin and isoniazid.

questions.text: A 38-year-old laborer presents to the district hospital with gradually progressive spastic paralysis of the lower limbs. It began as an abnormal gait with short jerky steps, and soon, he was dependent on crutches. His younger brother has developed a similar gait. They have been consuming an inexpensive dal that resembles red gram for the past 2 years. Which of the following compounds is responsible for this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of neurolathyrism and beta-oxalyl amino-alanine (BOAA) is the toxic compound causing lathyrism.

It is due to the consumption of khesari dal (Lathyrus sativus). It has a characteristic triangular shape and grey color. When the husk is removed, it looks similar to red gram dal or Bengal gram dal.

Lathyrism is a paralyzing disease of humans and animals.

In humans, it is referred to as neurolathyrism because it affects the nervous system. It is characterized by gradually developing spastic paralysis of the lower limbs. In animals, it is referred to as osteolathyrism/odoratism because the pathological changes in the bones lead to skeletal deformities.

It usually affects young males aged 15-45 years, and it is manifested in stages: 

  • Latent stage
  • No-stick stage
  • One-stick stage
  • Two-stick stage
  • Crawler stage

BOAA is the toxic compound causing lathyrism. The water-soluble property of the toxin is used in removing it from the pulses by soaking it in hot water and rejecting the soaked water. Although it is considered irreversible, vitamin C in doses of 500–1000 mg can be used for the prevention and treatment of lathyrism.

The Prevention of Food Adulteration Act in India has banned Lathyrus sativus in all forms (whole/ split/ flour).

questions.text: The radiograph shown below is done for better assessment of the frontal sinus. What is the common name of this view?
questions.solution:
The frontal sinus is best seen in Caldwell's view (occipitofrontal view or nose-forehead position).

The structures seen in Caldwell's view include:

  • Frontal sinuses (seen best)
  • Ethmoid sinuses
  • Maxillary sinuses
  • Frontal process of the zygoma and the zygomatic process of the frontal bone
  • Superior margin of the orbit and lamina papyracea
  • Superior orbital fissure
  • Foramen rotundum (inferolateral to superior orbital fissure)

The nose and forehead are touching the X-ray film and the X-ray beam is projected 15 degrees caudally in Caldwell's view.

Other options:

Option A: Water's view (occipitomental view or nose-chin position) is a radiographic view where an X-ray beam is angled at 45 degrees to the orbitomeatal line. Structures seen are the maxillary sinus (best seen), sphenoid sinus (if the film is taken with an open mouth), frontal sinus, zygoma, zygomatic arch, nasal bone, and infratemporal fossa. 

Option C: Pierre's view is the occipitomental with an open mouth. It helps in visualizing the sphenoid sinus as well, in addition to the sinuses that can be seen in water's view.

Option D: Towne's view is an angled anteroposterior radiograph of the skull. Structures seen are the petrous part of the pyramids, arcuate eminence, superior semicircular canal, mastoid antrum, internal auditory canal, tympanic cavity, cochlea, and external auditory canal. This view is taken for acoustic neuroma and apical petrositis.

questions.text:
Sequentially arrange the following chest radiograph findings according to the respective grades of sarcoidosis, in increasing order.

A. Pulmonary fibrosis

B. Lung parenchymal infiltrates and bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy

questions.solution:
The chest radiograph is the preferred tool used to stage sarcoidosis.

Stage 1

 Bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy (usually symmetrical); right paratracheal nodes often enlarged

questions.text: A person is having opioid-induced bradycardia. Which of the following muscle relaxants can be used to counteract opioid-induced bradycardia?
questions.solution:
Pancuronium is vagolytic (resulting from blockade of M2 receptors) leading to increased heart rate and hence can be used to counteract opioid-induced bradycardia.

Pancuronium-induced tachycardia has been attributed to the following:

  • Vagolytic action: Inhibition of M2 receptors
  • Sympathetic stimulation: Direct by blockade of neuronal uptake of norepinephrine and indirectly by release of norepinephrine from adrenergic nerve endings.

Other options: Vecuronium, cisatracurium, and atracurium are nonvagolytic relaxants

questions.text: A 25-year-old young female came to the Dermatology OPD with non-acantholytic blisters. She was advised to get a histopathological examination of the lesion done which revealed the pathology shown in the image. The most likely diagnosis is ________
questions.solution:
Bullous Pemphigoid is characterized by subepidermal (as shown in the image) non-acantholytic blisters.

As the antibodies in bullous pemphigoid are directed against BPAg2 and BPAg1 present in the basement membrane zone, intercellular junctions are intact and acantholysis is not seen. Hence the blisters that form are non-acantholytic.

Acantholysis is the loss of intercellular connections, such as desmosomes, leading to the loss of cohesion between keratinocytes. This results in the formation of intraepidermal clefts, vesicles, and bullae.

Acantholysis may be classified as:

Primary acantholysis: Due to direct injury to or defects seen in desmosomes, separation of keratinocytes occurs, resulting in circular acantholytic cells. Acantholysis is the primary event causing intraepidermal cavities. It is seen in conditions such as:

  • Pemphigus and its variants (Options C and D)
  • Acantholytic dermatosis
  • Darier's disease
  • Hailey Hailey disease
  • Warty dyskeratoma

Secondary acantholysis: Due to the damage or alteration to the keratinocytes, leading to the dissolution of desmosomes. This results in acantholysis that is seen in:

  • Viral disorders like herpes simplex infections (HSV 1 and 2), varicella zoster infections (chicken pox and shingles) (Option A)
  • Bullous impetigo
  • Solar keratoses
  • Squamous cell carcinoma - some forms like adenoid
  • Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome 

Other options:

Option A: Varicella has intraepidermal blisters.

Option C: Pemphigus Vulgaris is characterized by intraepidermal acantholytic blisters.

Option D: Pemphigus foliaceus is characterized by subcorneal acantholytic blisters.

questions.text:
Which among the following are commonly caused by HPV 6 and 11?
  1. Condyloma accuminata
  2. Myrmecia 
  3. Verruca vulgaris 
  4. Buschke–Löwenstein tumour 
  5. Benign nasal inverted papilloma
questions.solution:
Condyloma accuminata, Buschke–Löwenstein tumor, and Benign nasal inverted papilloma are caused by HPV 6 and 11. Myrmecia is caused by HPV 1 and Verruca Vulgaris is usually caused by HPV 2.

  • Anogenital warts (Condyloma Accuminata)
    • It may be asymptomatic, but can also discomfort discharge, or bleeding.
    • Appear as soft, pink, elongated, filiform, or pedunculated.
    • Usually found on moist surfaces - commonest sites include frenulum, corona, and glans in men, and the posterior fourchette in women.
    • Most commonly caused by HPV‐6 and HPV‐11. HPV‐1 and HPV‐2 may also occur in genital warts.
  • Nasal inverted papillomas (inverted papilloma, Schneiderian papilloma) -
    • most commonly caused by HPV‐6/11(Benign), ‐16/18(Malignant), and 57.
  • Buschke–Löwenstein tumour (also called giant condyloma acuminatum or verrucous carcinoma)  -
    • It is a slow-growing, invasive, exophytic tumor
    • seen in the anogenital region. 
    • Most commonly caused by HPV‐6 and ‐11, however, HPV‐16 and ‐18 can also be detected 

Other options:

Skin warts are benign, well-defined hyperkeratotic tumors caused by infection with HPV. They can present clinically as:

  • Verruca vulgaris (Common warts)
    • Firm papules with a rough horny surface.
    • Usually on the backs of the hands and fingers
    • Caused by HPV 2 mainly, but also by HPV 27, 57, 1, and 4.
  • Plantar warts -
    • Small shining sago-grain-like papules which progress to rough keratotic lesions.
    • Usually on the heel or metatarsal heads
    • Caused by HPV‐1, ‐2, ‐4, ‐27, or ‐57.
    • Myrmecia (Deep plantar warts) are smooth-surfaced, deep, tender papules or plaques caused by HPV 1. 
  • Verruca plana (Plane warts) - 
    • Smooth, flat, or slightly elevated skin-colored or greyish yellow.
    • Usually on the back of hand, face, shins.
    • Caused by: HPV‐3 and ‐10.

questions.text:
A 6-year-old boy is brought to the clinic with the findings below. The patient's mother gives a history of a fever the previous week along with bilateral conjunctival injection. She took the child to a clinic nearby and he was given some medications. Physical examination also reveals the presence of cervical lymphadenopathy. From the option below, choose the correct statements about his patient's diagnosis.
  1. Bilateral exudative conjunctivitis is a diagnostic feature of this condition
  2. The extremity changes seen in this patient are characteristic of the acute phase of illness
  3. Elevated acute phase reactants aids in the diagnosis
  4. Discrete oral lesions and tonsillar exudate are highly suggestive of the diagnosis
  5. Untreated cases result in long term complications
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette describes a case of Kawasaki disease (KD). Elevated acute phase reactants aid in the diagnosis and untreated patients develop long-term cardiovascular complications that could potentially be fatal.

KD is the most common vasculitis in the pediatric age group. The condition reflects widespread inflammation of the medium-sized arteries. It is a self-limited condition and the acute-phase inflammation usually lasts about 12 days without therapy.

Clinical features:

  • Fever is the most consistent manifestation of KD. It remains above 101.3F during most of the illness and is minimally responsive to antipyretics
  • Bilateral nonexudative conjunctivitis which begins within days of onset of fever is seen in the majority of these patients. It starts as a bulbar injection that appears as brilliant erythema that characteristically spares the limbus
  • Cracked red lips and a strawberry tongue is seen. It is a result of the sloughing of papillae on the tongue
  • A polymorphous rash, which starts as perineal erythema and desquamation, followed by macular, morbilliform, or targetoid skin lesions of the trunk and extremities. The rash may be confused with that of scarlet fever.
  • Changes in the extremities include swelling of the hands and feet which occurs during the acute phase of the illness and desquamation of the hands and feet (as seen in this patient) which are seen in the convalescent phase.
  • Cervical lymphadenopathy is seen in some patients but is not a consistent finding
  • The presence of distinct oral lesions and tonsillar exudate suggests and alternative diagnosis
  • Other nonspecific findings include arthritis, cardiovascular manifestations, diarrhea, irritability, cough, and decreased intake

Labs:

  • Elevated acute-phase reactants (ESR, CRP, ferritin, and reactive thrombocytosis)
  • Normocytic normochromic anemia
  • Pyuria
  • Hyponatremia
  • Abnormalities in the lipid profile

Diagnosis:

Requires the presence of fever and four of five clinical findings (conjunctivitis, mucosal changes, rash, extremity changes, and cervical lymphadenopathy) 

In addition, ECHO should be performed in all patients to rule out complications

Treatment:

  • Aspirin
  • IVIG to prevent complications

Complications:

20% of untreated patients develop cardiovascular sequelae, ranging from asymptomatic coronary arteritis to coronary artery ectasia, to giant coronary artery aneurysms (7 to 8 mm) leading to rupture or thrombosis, myocardial infarction, and sudden death.

questions.text: A 63-year-old male patient with a history of chronic hepatitis C is brought to the clinic for evaluation of the lesions shown below on his lower limbs. The lesions are non-blanching. Further workup reveals the diagnosis to be leukocytoclastic vasculitis. Which of the following is likely to be seen on biopsy of these lesions?

choices.text: Granulomas with areas of central necrosis and surrounding vasculitis in small vessels
Segmental transmural necrotising inflammation of the medium sized vessels
Granulomatous inflammation of the media with giant cells in large vessels
Segmental fibrinoid necrosis of the media without granulomatous inflammation in small vessels

questions.solution:
Segmental fibrinoid necrosis of the media without granulomatous inflammation in small vessels is likely to be seen on biopsy in this patient with microscopic polyangiitis/ leukocytoclastic vasculitis. 

Microscopic polyangiitis/hypersensitivity vasculitis is a necrotizing vasculitis that affects the capillaries, small arterioles, and venules. It is associated with the presence of MPO-ANCA. The skin, mucous membrane, lung, brain, heart, kidneys, and muscle can all be affected. It is a feature of many immune disorders such as essential mixed cryoglobulinemia, Henoch-Schonlein purpura, and vasculitis in connective tissue disorders. The pathogenesis involves immune complex deposition, recruitment, and activation of neutrophils within the affected vascular beds

Biopsy findings:

  • Segmental fibrinoid necrosis of the media and focal transmural necrotizing lesions.
  • Granulomatous inflammation is absent.
  • Postcapillary venules typically show the presence of infiltrating neutrophils that are undergoing apoptosis.
  • Early skin lesions demonstrate immunoglobulins and complement components, most late lesions show no evidence of these findings.

Other options:

Option A: Granulomas with areas of central necrosis and surrounding vasculitis in small vessels is a feature of Churg-Strauss syndrome

Option B: Segmental transmural necrotizing inflammation of the medium-sized vessels is seen in polyarteritis nodosa

Option C: Granulomatous inflammation of the media with giant cells in large vessels is a feature of Takayasu's arteritis

questions.text:
Which of the following statements is true about escitalopram?
  1. It belongs to the class of tricyclic antidepressants
  2. It inhibits the uptake of serotonin
  3. It has a very poor oral bioavailability
  4. It does not act on the acetylcholine muscarinic receptor
  5. It is the D enantiomer of citalopram
questions.solution:
The correct option is D: Statements 2 and 4 are true about Escitalopram.

Escitalopram belongs to the class of selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRI) and inhibits the uptake of serotonin. It has fewer antimuscarinic side effects.

It is the S enantiomer of citalopram. It is well absorbed orally and the half-life is 27-32 hours. They do not have any action on muscarinic receptors, α adrenoceptors, β adrenoceptors, histamine receptors, or the norepinephrine transporter. 

The usual therapeutic dose of escitalopram is 10-30mg per day. SSRIs are used in the treatment of the major depressive disorder, anxiety disorders, and premenstrual dysphoric disorders. 

System Side effects of SSRIs
Sexual Anorgasmia , decreased libido
Gastrointestinal nausea, diarrhea, anorexia, vomiting, flatulence, and dyspepsia
Nervous system anxiety, insomnia/sedation, extremely vivid dreams or nightmares,  seizures, emotional blunting, headache
Cardiovascular drug-induced long QT syndrome
Hematological easy bruising
Endocrine mammoplasia, galactorrhea

 Sexual dysfunction is the most common side effect of SSRI with long-term treatment. Escitalopram also interferes more with sleep compared to citalopram.

Drug interactions: Of the SSRIs, the likelihood of drug-drug interaction is highest with fluoxetine, paroxetine, and fluvoxamine. The specific interactions of these medications and medications commonly used in the elderly (eg, certain antibiotics, warfarin) are well established. The SSRIs that offer a lower likelihood of drug-drug interactions include escitalopram, citalopram, and sertraline.

questions.text: You have been asked to evaluate a 32-year-old HIV positive female who presented with headache and nuchal stiffness to the Emergency Medicine department. You have sent samples for routine investigations as well as a CSF sample for microscopic examination with India-ink staining. The life cycle of the causative organism is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of torulosis or Cryptococcosis which is caused by Cryptococcus neoformans. It is an opportunistic fungus that is found worldwide as a saprophyte in soil enriched with pigeon droppings.

It may cause infection in immune-competent persons, resulting in a flu-like illness with complete recovery.

Infection of persons with T cell immune suppression, such as AIDS patients or patients with hematological malignancies, most commonly leads to meningoencephalitis.

 The given life cycle is of Cryptococcus species – Cryptococcus neoformans (common) and Cryptococcus gattii.

Clinical correlate:

  • In immunocompromised patients, both species cause cryptococcosis by inhalation of yeast cells or spores. From the lungs, these yeasts migrate to the CNS and other organs.
  • Cryptococcal meningitis is an AIDS-defining opportunistic fungal CNS infection that generally occurs in untreated patients, with CD4+ T cell counts <100/μL.
  • The CSF profile may show modest elevations in WBC or protein levels and a decrease in glucose. The CSF opening pressure is usually elevated.
  • The diagnosis is made by the identification of yeast cells in CSF with India ink stain or by the detection of Cryptococcal antigen using latex agglutination(CrAg).

Treatment:

  • Induction: IV or Liposomal Amphotericin B with Flucytosine for at least 2 weeks, continuing with amphotericin alone ideally until the CSF culture turns negative.
  • Maintenance: Oral Fluconazole until the CD4+ T cell count has increased to >200 cells/μL for 6 months in response to cART.
  • Primary prophylaxis: Oral Fluconazole when CD4+ T cell count is <100/μL.

Other options:

Primary amoebic meningoencephalitis caused by Naegleria fowleri, which is a Facultative parasite. The infection usually follows swimming in the freshwater rivers or ponds. Naegleria fowleri invades the nasal mucosa and passes through the olfactory nerve branches in the cribriform plate into the meninges.

Tularemia is transmitted by hard ticks.

questions.text:
A 16-year-old boy presents to your clinic with complaints of itchy rashes on his body for the past two weeks. He lives in a school hostel room. After obtaining a thorough history, you perform microscopy of the skin scraping from the interdigital web space, findings of which are shown below. Which of the following statement/s are incorrect regarding the suspected diagnosis?

1- The burrows are made by the gravid female mite 

2- The pruritus is due to an immune reaction to the excreta of the mite 

3- It typically involves the face, scalp, palms, and soles

4- It can be treated using topical permethrin 

5- Treatment of close contacts is not required
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette is strongly suggestive of scabies. It is caused by the itch mite also called Sarcoptes scabiei. Among the given options, statements 3 and 5 are incorrect. 

The pathogenesis of scabies includes infestation by Sarcoptes scabiei. They are obligate human ectoparasites as they die within a day if they do not find a suitable host. On finding a suitable host, gravid female mites burrow into the superficial epidermis and lay eggs. These eggs hatch into six-legged larvae that evolve into eight-legged nymphs. The symptoms such as rash and itching are due to immune reactions to the excretory products of the mites in the skin. 

Scabies is transmitted by direct skin-to-skin contact and less frequently via contaminated clothes and bedding. They are seen more commonly in overcrowded areas, hostels, and schools, especially in unhygienic environments. 

Clinically, these patients present with superficial excoriated papules or vesicles that are intensely pruritic. They are usually present on the volar surface of the wrists, interdigital spaces, penis, scrotum, navel, and skin folds and creases in the axillae, buttocks, and thigh regions. Burrows may be visualized in the superficial dermis in the abovementioned regions. Pruritis is typically intense and increases after showers and during the night. 

Immunodeficient individuals may develop a widespread form known as crusted scabies or Norwegian scabies. Although they may be infected with thousands of mites, they might not have intense pruritis due to muted immune response. Characteristic burrows are typically absent, instead, they present with thick keratotic crusts and scaly plaques. 

Diagnosis is established considering the characteristic history and by dermatoscopic imaging or microscopy of the skin scrapings or cellophane tape lifted from lesions. 

Permethrin cream - 5% is the treatment of choice. It is preferred over 1% lindane preparation and ivermectin. These preparations are applied once, all over the body below the jawline, following a bath. It should be washed off with soap and water after 8-14 hours. Oral ivermectin may be given in the dose of 200 μg/kg once in healthy adults and in two doses one-two weeks apart in patients with widespread, crusted scabies. Supportive treatment with antihistamines, calamine lotion, and topical steroids may help treat the associated pruritis. 

It is imperative to treat close contacts simultaneously and wash bedding and clothing to prevent reinfestations.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male patient has been prescribed a drug that catalyzes the enzymatic oxidation of uric acid into allantoin for the treatment of his chronic gout. What is this drug?
questions.solution:
The drug that catalyzes the enzymatic oxidation of uric acid into allantoin for the treatment of chronic gout is pegloticase.

Pegloticase is a pegylated uricase (urate oxidase) that catalyzes the enzymatic oxidation of uric acid into allantoin, which is a more soluble and inactive metabolite. It is used in the treatment of severe, refractory chronic gout or in cases where other urate-lowering therapies are contraindicated. The efficacy of this drug gets lowered if antibodies are produced against the drug, which occurs in many patients. This also increases the risk of infusion reactions. 

Rasburicase is a recombinant uricase. It is indicated for the initial management of elevated plasma uric acid levels in patients with malignancies who are on chemotherapy. The efficacy is limited by the production of antibodies to the drug.

Gout occurs due to the precipitation of urate crystals in the tissues with a subsequent inflammatory response. In an acute episode of gout, there is painful distal monoarthritis which can lead to joint destruction, subcutaneous tophi, and renal calculi. Management of gout includes:

  • Reduction of pain and inflammation: NSAIDs, colchicine, glucocorticoids
  • Inhibition of the formation of urate: Allopurinol, febuxostat
  • Promotion of urate excretion: Probenecid, lesinurad

Other options: 

Option A: Colchicine acts by preventing the polymerization of microtubules by tubulin, this reduces neutrophil recruitment to inflamed tissue and also decreases the secretion of chemotactic factors by activated neutrophils. Overall reducing the inflammatory response.

Option B: Febuxostat is a xanthine oxidase inhibitor approved for the treatment of hyperuricemia in patients with gout.

Option D: Allopurinol by inhibiting the xanthine oxidase enzyme prevents the conversion of xanthine to uric acid.

Related Pearl: Drugs precipitating Gout

Drugs that precipitate gout are-

Cyclosporine or cancer drugs
Aspirin (low dose)
Niacin
Thiazide
Lasix (furosemide)
Ethambutol
Alcohol
Pyrazinamide

Mnemonic for drugs precipitating gout is 'CANT LEAP'

questions.text: A 53-year-old man complains of fatigue, constipation, and weakness in the dorsiflexion of his foot. Laboratory examination reveals anemia, and the peripheral blood smear is shown below. What is the likely cause of his findings?
questions.solution:
The slide shows basophilic stippling (punctate basophilia), seen in chronic lead poisoning (also called plumbism or saturnism). 

The hematological findings that are associated with lead poisoning are anemia, ringed sideroblasts, and basophilic stippling of the RBCs.

Clinical features include:

  • A - Anemia with basophilic stippling
  • B - Burtonian line (blue stippled line on gums)
  • C - Constipation and colic (abdominal pain)
  • D - Drop (wrist and foot drop) due to neuropathy
  • E - Encephalopathy (seen in infants- ataxia, vomiting, stupor, convulsions, and even coma)
  • F - Facial pallor (earliest sign)

Other options-

Option A: Minamata disease resulted from the consumption of fish contaminated with methylmercury. Chronic mercury poisoning would not present with anemia with ringed sideroblasts and basophilic stippling.

Option C: Chronic iron toxicity can be seen in conditions like hemochromatosis, thalassemia (increased absorption due to defective hemoglobin synthesis), or because of excessive oral consumption. Iron overload in various organs can present as liver cirrhosis, hypogonadism, skin pigmentation, diabetes, etc. These patients would have increased serum iron, ferritin, and transferrin saturation. Sideroblastic anemia may present with iron toxicity and how certain similarities to this peripheral smear, but the patient would not present with foot drop.

Option D: Arsenic Poisoning is seen in people working in smelting and ore refineries. Toxicity can present with normocytic normochromic anemia, leukopenia, and thrombocytopenia. Patients would not have basophilic stippling on peripheral smear. Foot drop is also not a feature of arsenic toxicity. Peripheral neuropathy in a glove and stocking pattern may be seen. 

Related Pearl: Lead Poisoning/Plumbism/Saturnism

Adults - Respiratory tract
Mechanism of action
  • Binds to sulfhydryl groups and inhibits
    • ALA dehydratase

  • Inhibits pyrimidine 5' nucleotidase

GI tract, Bone marrow, Peripheral nerves

B - Burtonian line (blue stippled line on gums)

C - Constipation and colic (abdominal pain)

D - Drop (wrist and foot drop) due to neuropathy

questions.text: A retired army officer was advised to undergo a complete health check-up. During an examination, the radiologist identifies a bullet present in the body surrounded by a dense fibrous tissue capsule. What type of bullet is it called?
questions.solution:
The kind of bullet identified by the radiologist as explained in the given scenario is known as souvenir bullet.

Souvenir bullet is the one which has been lodged in the body for a long time with no fresh bleeding around it and surrounded by a dense fibrous tissue capsule. They can be visualized on X-rays. They are usually a result of bullet lodging in an inaccessible space which may result in more damage on attempted retrieval. e.g. Bullet in the spine.

Other options:

Tandem bullet (Piggyback bullet): This is where two bullets come out with a single shot. Seen with unused or locally made weapons. It may cause confusion with the number of entry and exit wounds.

Incendiary bullets: Type of army bullet used to cause fire in the target.

questions.text: An elderly man with a history of hypertension for the past 15 years, presents to the clinic with a history of palpitations for the past 4 hours. The doctor performed an ECG and it showed the presence of an irregularly irregular ventricular rate with the absence of P waves. Which among the following waves will be absent in the jugular venous pressure tracing of this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario describes atrial fibrillation. Wave marked as 1 in jugular venous pressure (JVP) tracing is 'a' wave and this will be absent in this patient.

Atrial fibrillation (AF) characterized by a loss of organized atrial mechanical contraction is commonly seen in elderly people with an underlying cardiac disease. Other risk factors are hypertension, diabetes mellitus, obesity, and sleep apnea. It is diagnosed by ECG which will show the absence of distinct P-waves and an irregular ventricular response. The a wave of the JVP reflecting atrial contraction is absent in this case as there is no organized atrial contraction occurring.

Jugular venous pressure is used to assess central venous pressure. The internal jugular vein is preferred for the measurement because it does not have valves and is directly in line with the superior vena cava and right atrium. Venous pressure is measured as the vertical distance between the top of the jugular venous pulsation and the angle of Louis. A distance >4.5 cm at a 30° elevation is considered abnormal.

Related Pearl: JVP waveform and the abnormalities

1) The a-wave corresponds to atrial contraction.

Abnormality Conditions
Prominent a-waves Pulmonary hypertension, right atrial thrombus/ mass, and tricuspid stenosis
Cannon a-waves

Complete AV block, ventricular tachycardia, and premature atrial/ junctional/ ventricular beats
Absent a-waves Atrial fibrillation

 

2) The c-wave corresponds to the bulging of tricuspid valve into right atrium during ventricular contraction.

 

3) The x-descent corresponds to atrial relaxation during atrial diastole.

Abnormality Conditions
Absent x-descent Severe tricuspid regurgitation
Rapid x-descent Cardiac tamponade

 

4) The v-wave corresponds to the venous filling of right atrium.

Abnormality Conditions
Dominant v-waves Tricuspid regurgitation

 

5) The y-descent corresponds to the passive emptying of the right atrium into right ventricle.

Abnormality Conditions
Prolonged y-descent Tricuspid stenosis
Rapid y-descent

Constrictive pericarditis and isolated severe tricuspid regurgitation
Absent y-descent Cardiac tamponade

questions.text: A teenage girl is brought in for evaluation of truncal asymmetry. The findings of the physical examination and x-ray imaging are shown in the image below. Which of the following radiological signs could be helpful in assessing skeletal maturity in such cases?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario, with the image showing a positive Adams (forward bend) test and lateral curvature of the spine seen on the radiograph, is suggestive of scoliosis. Risser's sign evaluates skeletal maturation using the ossification of the iliac apophysis in the evaluation of scoliosis. 

Risser's sign

The iliac apophysis is divided into four quadrants. Ossification of iliac apophyses normally proceeds from the lateral to the medial side and from the anterior superior iliac spine to the posterior superior iliac spine. The Risser grades correspond to the degree of ossification, ranging from grade 0 (no ossification) to grade 4 (ossification of all four quadrants). When the apophysis has fused completely with the ilium, ossification is graded as Risser grade 5 and the patient is considered skeletally mature. 

Adolescent idiopathic scoliosis (AIS)

AIS is the most common type of scoliosis and develops in children over the age of 10 years until they reach skeletal maturity. It is asymptomatic and usually identified on routine physical examination. The spine may have obviously deviated from the mid-line or a prominence may become apparent when the patient bends forward (the Adams test).

Confirmation of the diagnosis is through full-length lateral and PA x-rays. A Cobb angle of >10° is diagnostic. It is a measure of the degree of curvature using projected lines from the top of the uppermost and bottom of the lowermost vertebral bodies.

Use in scoliosis: Risser's grade 5 (fusion with the ilium) corresponds to the fusion of the apophysis in the vertebral ring. Once this occurs, there is no possibility of further progression of the scoliosis curve.

Other options - 

Option B - Lasegue's sign or straight leg raising test (SLRT) is used to diagnose radicular pain.

Option C - Kanavel's sign comprises the four cardinal signs of flexor tendon sheath infection:

  • Finger held in slight flexion
  • Uniform swelling of the digit
  • Tenderness along the flexor tendon sheath
  • Pain with passive extension of the digit

Option D - Froment's sign is used to test for ulnar nerve palsy. Abnormality is present when there is an inability to hold a piece of paper between the thumb and index finger of the affected hand as the examiner tries to pull it away.

questions.text: The Emsley-Fincham test is performed in a patient who complains of blurred vision and seeing colored halos. The patient reports breaking up of the halo into rotating segments. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Breaking up of coloured halos into rotating segments on performing the Emsley-Fincham test with a stenopaeic slit indicates cataract.

Related Pearl: Fincham’s Test

Also called Emsley–Fincham Test

It used for differentiating between the colored halos due to cataract (lenticular) and those in corneal edema due to glaucoma. It is performed by passing a stenopaic slit across the pupil and observing the halos.

Halos are broken up into segments which revolve as the slit moves → Lenticular halo

Intact halos but the intensity and brightness are diminished → Glaucomatous halo

The image shows a stenopaeic slit.

It causes reduced size of blur circle in the meridian perpendicular to the slit and no change in the blur circle in the meridian coincident with it. So, it can be used to determine the axis of the cylinder in astigmatism.

In cases with corneal opacity, the optimal site for optical iridectomy is determined using a stenopaic slit.

questions.text: An epidemiologist is studying the diseases transmitted by the vector whose life cycle is given below. It is responsible for the transmission of all of the following except __________
questions.solution:
The given in the image above is the life cycle of louse and it can transmit trench fever, epidemic typhus(not endemic typhus), relapsing fever, and is responsible for pediculosis.

The trench fever/quintan fever/5-day fever is caused by Rickettsia Quintana.

Trench fever characterized by sudden onset of fever accompanied by headache, malaise, restlessness, and shin pain. It is an exclusively human disease and no animal reservoir is known. It is transmitted by the body louse.

Related Pearl: Lice

  • There are 3 kinds of lice. They are:
    • Head lice (Pediculus capitis)
    • Body lice (Pediculus corporis)
    • Crab louse (pubic louse – Phthirus pubis).
  • Their morphology consists of a head with a pair of antennae, three pairs of legs attached to the thorax, and a segmented abdomen.
  • The stages in their life cycle are eggs (nits), larva (nymph), and the adult, which live for 30 to 50 days.
  • They are spread by direct or indirect contact.
  • They are vectors for epidemic typhus, relapsing fever, trench fever, and pediculosis.
  • Insecticidal control of lice is mainly by malathion in the form of lotion or powder.
  • There are reports of resistance to DDT and HCH.
  • Personal hygiene is of utmost importance to prevent infestation.
