questions.text: A 35-year-old lady presented with epistaxis and severe menorrhagia. On clinical examination, there was no splenomegaly or organomegaly.  Her Hb= 5g/dL,  platelet count = 18,000/μL and white blood cell count is 2500/μL. She was advised a hematopoietic stem cell transplantation for this condition. Post transplantation, her family is apprehensive of COVID-19 infection which can pose a risk in her condition, and want her to receive the COVID-19 vaccine immediately. What will you advise the attendants regarding the COVID vaccination in this patient?

choices.text: Give COVID-19 vaccine next day after transplant and monitor complete blood counts
COVID-19 Vaccination is absolutely contraindicated in patients with cancer
Patient should receive COVID-19 vaccination at least 3 months after hematopoietic cell transplantation
Give patient COVID-19 vaccine along with vaccination against encapsulated micro-organisms

questions.solution:
The clinical, laboratory, and bone marrow findings are diagnostic of aplastic anemia. The best method of management is hematopoietic stem cell transplantation. The patient should receive COVID-19 Vaccination at least 3 months after Hematopoietic Cell Transplantation (HCT)/Cellular Therapy, according to the NCCN COVID-19 Vaccination Advisory Committee.

Vaccination should be delayed for at least 3 months following hematopoietic cell transplantation (HCT) or engineered cellular therapy (eg, chimeric antigen receptor [CAR] T cells) to maximize vaccine efficacy.

Graft-versus-host disease (GVHD) and immunosuppressive regimens used to treat GVHD (like systemic corticosteroids and targeted agents) can blunt the immune responses to vaccination.

Delay of vaccination until immunosuppressive therapy is reduced and/or based on immunophenotyping of T-cell and B-cell immunity can be considered.
Patients on maintenance therapies (on drugs like rituximab, Bruton tyrosine kinase inhibitors, Janus kinase inhibitors) may have decreased response to vaccination.

Prioritize patients with active cancer on treatment (including hematopoietic and cellular therapy), those planned to start treatment, and those immediately (<6 months) post-treatment, except those receiving only hormonal therapy. 

Consider additional risk factors for such patients and other factors linked to adverse COVID-19 complications including, but not limited to: 

  • Patients with advanced age (eg, ≥65 years of age) 
  • Patients with comorbidities (eg, chronic pulmonary, cardiovascular, or renal disease) 
  • Social and demographic factors

COVID-19 vaccines should be prioritized over other needed vaccines. Fourteen days are recommended between COVID-19 vaccines and other approved vaccines.

Aplastic anemia is pancytopenia with bone marrow hypocellularity. Patients will present with bleeding, anemia, and rarely infections. Bone marrow biopsy will appear hypocellular with fat occupying the majority of the bone marrow. Hematopoietic stem cell transplantation is the best method of management in young patients. Elderly patients and patients without an HLA matched donor are treated with antithymocyte globulin (ATG) in combination with cyclosporine.

questions.text:
A 28-year-old recently married woman committed suicide because of dowry torture by her husband's family. Under which of the following sections is this incident covered?

BNS - BHARATIYA NYAYA SANHITA
questions.solution:
This incident can be considered a dowry death. Dowry death is defined under section 304B IPC.

According to this, if the husband or his relative subjects the woman to cruelty or harassment in demand of dowry within 7 years of marriage; they shall be deemed to have caused her death. The punishment for such cases is imprisonment for not less than 7 years, but may be extended to life imprisonment.

Option A: Section 63 (IPC 375) deals with rape.

Option C: Section 72 (IPC 228A) deals with imprisonment for up to 2 years and a fine for disclosure of the identity of a rape victim.

Option D: Section 100 (IPC 299) deals with culpable homicide.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presents with complete obstruction of his left nostril and a nodule on the dorsum of his nose obscuring his vision as shown in the image. He gives a typical history of foul-smelling purulent nasal discharge with crust formation even before this nodule developed. The histology of the biopsied specimen is given as an image. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical presentation of a nodule on the nose and the given histological image showing Mikulicz cells are suggestive of rhinoscleroma.

Mikulicz cells are large foam cells with a central nucleus and vacuolated cytoplasm containing the causative bacilli. The history of purulent foul-smelling nasal discharge with crusting before the development of nodules corresponds to the atrophic stage of rhinoscleroma. 

Rhinoscleroma is caused by Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis (Frisch bacillus). It has 3 stages:

1. Atrophic stage– Crusting and foul-smelling nasal discharge similar to atrophic rhinitis.

2. Granulomatous stage– Painless, non-ulcerative Granulomatous nodules with subdermal infiltration giving the feel of woody/hebra nose.

3. Cicatricial stage – Fibrosis leading to stenosis of vestibule, pharynx, larynx. The deformity is called a tapir nose.

Treatment: Streptomycin (1g/day) and tetracycline (2g/day) are given together for a period of 4 to 6 weeks. Steroids can be combined with this to reduce fibrosis. Surgical treatment is necessary to restore the airway and correction of the nasal deformity.

Other options:

Option A: Even though the inner canthus of the eye is a common site for the occurrence of basal cell carcinoma, the given histology does not show palisade of the basaloid epithelium, which is very classical of BCC.

Option B: Rhinophyma or potato tumour is due to hypertrophy of sebaceous gland and presents as swelling over tip of the nose.

Option C: Rhinosporidiosis is a granulomatous condition caused by Rhinosporidium seeberi and presents with nasal discharge, epistaxis and nasal obstruction by a polypoidal mass.

questions.text: A 38-year-old P2L2 lady with heavy menstrual bleeding for 8 months did not show a response to hormonal therapy. She asks for information on other treatment options, one of which is shown below. Which of the following is an absolute contraindication to the procedure shown?
questions.solution:
The procedure shown in the image is uterine artery embolization, for which pelvic inflammatory disease is an absolute contraindication.

Uterine artery embolization can be done pre-operatively to a definitive surgery to reduce vascularity and fibroid size. ~90% patients get relief from the menorrhagia and pressure symptoms are relieved in ~70% patients. 

It is best suited for menorrhagia in a multiparous woman. 

Advantages-

  • No major surgery
  • No intraoperative bleeding
  • Shorter hospital stay
  • Less adhesions 
  • Higher patient satisfaction  

Indications-

  • Fibroids 
  • Arteriovenous malformations
  • Increased uterine vascularity 
  • Postpartum hemorrahge 
  • Placenta accreta syndromes 

Complications-

  • Fever, Infection 
  • Vaginal discharge, Bleeding
  • Ischemic pain (indicates success of procedure, but requires analgesia)
  • Pulmonary Embolism
  • Ovarian failure and premature menopause 
  • Reduced fertility 
  • Failure of procedure 
  • Contrast induced complications 
  • Radiation exposure 
  • Femoral site hematoma
  • Extrusion of fibroid into peritoneum 
  • Intraperitoneal adhesions 

Related Pearl: Contraindications to uterine artery embolization

Absolute contraindications:

  • GnRH agonist use
  • Asymptomatic fibroids
  • Pregnancy
  • Pelvic inflammatory disease
  • Uterine malignancy
  • Calcified fibroid

Relative contraindications:

  • Patient desirous of future pregnancy: UAE causes poor uterine perfusion and pelvic adhesions, decreasing fertility. 
  • Postmenopausal women: Fibroids regress naturally, after menopause. Fibroid enlargement post-menopause raises the suspicion of malignancy.
  • Subserosal or submucosal fibroids: Pedunculated subtypes may detach intraperitoneally or within the uterine cavity. This may lead to sterile peritonitis or intrauterine infection.
  • Size or number of fibroids: Large fibroids or a greater number of fibroids can cause large amounts of necrosis following UAE. This may lead to post-op pain or infection. 
  • Contraindications to radiologic contrast agents.

questions.text:
A 40-year-old male patient recently diagnosed with renal vein thrombosis is being evaluated. He had past history of weight gain, generalized edema, and hypertension. Urinary examination shows gross proteinuria and the presence of multiple RBCs with normal morphology and no casts. Anti-PLA2R antibodies are present. Which of the following is likely to be seen on renal biopsy in this patient?

GBM - Glomerular basement membrane

choices.text: Diffuse thickening of the GBM with spike and dome pattern

questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette describes a case of nephrotic syndrome. Anti PLA2R antibodies are seen in membranous nephropathy which is seen as diffuse thickening of the glomerular basement membrane (GBM) on light microscopy examination. On electron microscopy, there are irregular spikes protruding from the GBM.

Membranous nephropathy is characterized by nephrotic syndrome and proteinuria. It occurs due to the accumulation of deposits containing immunoglobulins along the subepithelial portion of the glomerular basement membrane. Most of the cases (75%) are primary and are linked to an autoimmune phenomenon. The remaining are associated with the following: 

  • Drugs - Penicillamine, captopril, gold, nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs
  • Underlying malignancies like carcinoma of the lung, colon, melanoma
  • Systemic lupus erythematosus
  • Infections such as chronic hepatitis B and C, syphilis
  • Autoimmune conditions like thyroiditis

M-type phospholipase A2 receptor (PLA2R) antibodies are seen in the majority of these cases. 

Membranous nephropathy can present with insidious onset of nephrotic syndrome or a hypercoagulable state such as pulmonary embolism, renal vein thrombosis, deep venous thrombosis, and symptoms of heart failure. The hypercoagulable state occurs due to the loss of antithrombin 3 from the urine.

On light microscopy, the glomeruli may be normal or have a uniform, diffuse thickening of the glomerular capillary wall. Electron microscopy will reveal spike and dome patterns. Immunofluorescence microscopy demonstrates that the granular deposits contain both immunoglobulins and complement.

The image below shows the light microscopic findings in membranous nephropathy.

Other options:

Options B and D- Tram-track appearance of the glomerular basement membrane and large and hypercellular glomeruli are seen in membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis. It presents as nephrotic syndrome and along with features of nephritic component manifested by hematuria or as mild proteinuria.

Option C- Mesangial deposition of IgA is seen in IgA nephropathy (Berger disease).

Related Pearl: Nephrotic and nephritic syndromes

 

Nephrotic Syndrome

Nephritic Syndrome (Glomerulonephritis)

Primary pathology

Damage and dysfunction of glomerular filtration barrier, causing significant leakage of plasma proteins without much glomerular inflammation

Significant inflammatory injury of the glomerulus resulting in passage of RBCs, inflammatory cells & plasma proteins

The principal site of glomerular injury

 Visceral epithelial cell (Podocyte) Endothelial cells, glomerular basement membrane (GBM), Mesangial cells, Parietal epithelial cells (>Crescents)

Clinical features

Hallmark:

Heavy Proteinuria: 3.5 g/24 h or Urine protein:creatinine ratio >3) 

Hypoalbuminemia, 

Edema

Lipiduria, Hyperlipidemia

Microscopic hematuria

Hypertension

Hypercoagulability                                                    

Hallmark:

Hematuria (RBC casts/dysmorphic RBCs)

Varying degrees of proteinuria and pyuria

Renal dysfunction

Hypertension

Associated Glomerular pathology

Minimal change disease (Primary and secondary)

Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS) (Primary and secondary)

Membranous-nephropathy (Primary and secondary)

Diabetic nephropathy

Amyloidosis

Acute post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis

Rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis (crescentic)

IgA nephropathy (Berger disease)

Membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis

Alport syndrome

These syndromes, however, are not mutually exclusive. Some glomerular diseases may progress from one pattern to another or may present with considerable overlap between them, as a nephritic–nephrotic syndrome; features of nephrotic syndrome can concurrently occur with any form of nephritic syndrome but are most commonly seen with diffuse proliferative glomerulonephritis (seen in systemic lupus erythematosus) and membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis.

questions.text:
The gross specimen appearance and the histological appearance of a renal specimen from a patient with renal growth are as below. Which of the following statements are true about the underlying condition?
  1. It arises from the intercalated cells of the proximal tubule
  2. They are usually well encapsulated
  3. Most cases are malignant
  4. Bilateral cases can be seen in patients with tuberous sclerosis
  5. The histological appearance is due to a large number of mitochondria
questions.solution:
The image shown is of a renal oncocytoma.

Renal oncocytoma arises from the intercalated cells of collecting ducts. Renal oncocytoma is a benign epithelial neoplasm that accounts for approximately 5% to 15% of renal neoplasms. Grossly, these tumors appear tan or mahogany brown, relatively homogeneous, and are usually well encapsulated with a central scar in one-third of cases.

Microscopically, they are composed of large eosinophilic cells having small, round, benign-appearing nuclei that have large nucleoli. Ultrastructurally, these eosinophilic cells have numerous mitochondria. The intensely eosinophilic granular cytoplasm is due to the presence of a large number of mitochondria.

Multiple or bilateral cases are seen associated with tuberous sclerosis complex (TSC) and Birt-Hogg-Dubé syndrome, but most sporadic oncocytomas are usually unilateral and single. 

 

Note:

Oncocytomas are epithelial neoplasms composed of oncocyte epithelial cells with abundant eosinophilic granular cytoplasm (due to the accumulation of mitochondria). Oncocytes can arise in various tissues and are referred to as follows: 

  • Hurthle cells/Askanazy cells (Thyroid gland).
  • Oxyphilic cells (Parotid gland).
  • Apocrine metaplasia (Breast).

questions.text: The fasting blood glucose levels of a  group of diabetics were found to be normally distributed with a mean of 110 mg /dL and a standard deviation of 10 mg /dL. From this data, it can be inferred that approximately 99% of diabetics will have their fasting blood glucose levels within the limits of ____.
questions.solution:
In this scenario with a mean blood sugar level of 110mg/dL and a standard deviation of 10mg/dL, 99% of diabetics will have their fasting blood glucose levels between 80-140mg/dL.

99.7% of the distribution falls within three standard deviations of the mean. This proportion is true for every normal distribution. Thus, we have to add and subtract 30 (three standard deviations = 10 x 3) from the mean to arrive at the limits within which 99% of the population would have their blood sugar, i.e., mean ± 3 SD which will be 80 and 140 mg.

The standard deviation is the most frequently used measure of dispersion. Range and mean are the other measures. The shape of a frequency distribution is determined by the standard deviation and mean which in turn depends on the individual observations. A frequency distribution with a symmetrical, bell-shaped curve is known as a normal distribution. It is also known as Gaussian distribution.

Related Pearl: Normal Distribution

The normal distribution curve is the most common shape taken by continuous data distributions. It is also called bell curve (bell-shaped) or Gaussian distribution after mathematician Karl Friedrich Gauss.

The following is an image of three different normal distribution curves.

Salient features of the standard normal distribution:

  • Defined by two parameters: the mean and the standard deviation
  • Has mean of 0 and a standard deviation of 1
  • Mean = median = mode
  • Symmetric and have bell-shaped curves with a single peak
  • Total area under the curve is 1
  • Frequency of values is more around the center and less around the tails
  • No skew in the curve
  • Data like blood pressure, heights, IQ scores, etc. form a normal distribution
  • The empirical rule of a normal distribution:
    • Approximately 68% of the distribution falls within one standard deviation of the mean (mean ± 1 SD)
    • Approximately 95% of the distribution falls within two standard deviations of the mean (mean ± 2 SD)
    • Approximately 99.7% of the distribution falls within three standard deviations of the mean (mean ± 3 SD)

Related Pearl: Variance, Deviation Scores and Standard Deviation

  • Deviation Scores: 
    • The deviation score of an element in distribution is the difference between the mean of the distribution and the element itself, i.e., subtracting the distribution’s mean from the element.
    • Denoted by the letter x
    • For example, if 29 and 15 are elements in a distribution that has a mean of 22, the deviation score of 29 would be (29 – 22) = 7 and the deviation score of 15 would be (15 – 22) = - 7.
    • Sum of all the deviation scores of elements in distribution will be zero
  • Variance (also called mean square) 
    • The mean of the squares of all the deviation scores of the distribution
    • Used to measure how far data is spread out
    • If the variance is zero, it indicates that all the elements in the distribution are the same and that there is no variability.
    • Population variance (σ2) is calculated as:
      • Find the deviation score of each element in the distribution
      • Square each of the deviation scores.
      • Obtain the mean of all these squared deviation scores
  •  
    • Sample variance (s2): 
      • more commonly used in statistics than population variance
      • The denominator is n-1 (and not N as it is in population variance)
      • For small samples, it is better to use n-1 in the denominator.
      • For a very large sample, like a population, subtracting 1 from a huge number will not make much of a significant correction. Hence, we may choose to ignore subtracting 1.
  • Standard Deviation (SD)
    • It is the square root of variance.
    • The standard deviation of a population is denoted by σ and the standard deviation of a sample is denoted by just s.
    • The formula for the standard deviation of a sample (usually <30):
    • For a population (large sample), the denominator would be replaced by just N.
    • It is particularly useful for normal distributions but can be used in skewed distributions
    • It is used to calculate the proportion of the population within the given SD
    • A low SD means that the data are close to the mean but a high SD would mean that the data are more spread out.
    • The empirical rule of a normal distribution states that:
      • Approximately 68% of the distribution falls within one standard deviation of the mean.
      • Approximately 95% of the distribution falls within two standard deviations of the mean.
      • Approximately 99.7% of the distribution falls within three standard deviations of the mean.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male patient diagnosed with benign prostatic hyperplasia is posted for laser ablation surgery. Which of the following lasers is commonly used for this purpose?
questions.solution:
Holmium YAG laser is commonly used for laser ablative surgery of benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH).

Surgical management involves the use of the transurethral resection of the prostate (TURP), which involves electrocautery. Laser ablative techniques use holmium YAG commonly. Laser treatment post-surgery is useful in maintaining the hemostasis of small vessels. KTP laser is used to vaporize prostatic tissue. 

BPH is characterized by symptoms of urinary frequency, urgency, nocturia, incontinence, slow urinary stream, straining to void, urinary intermittency (stream starting and stopping during micturition), or hesitancy, splitting of the voiding stream, and terminal dribbling. Physical examination reveals a smooth enlarged and non-tender prostate. Lab investigations reveal a normal PSA (prostate-specific antigen). Diagnosis is made based on clinical presentation and a lack of lab findings suggestive of malignancy (elevated PSA). A biopsy is rarely indicated.

Medical management includes alpha-adrenergic blocking agents that inhibit the contraction of smooth muscle that is found in the prostate. The other class of drugs is the 5α-reductase inhibitors, which inhibit the conversion of testosterone to DHT, the most active form of androgen. These drugs result in a 25% shrinkage of the prostate gland.

Indications for surgical management:

  • Lower urinary tract symptoms that are refractory to medical therapy
  • Refractory urinary retention
  • Recurrent urinary tract infection (UTI)
  • Recurrent gross hematuria
  • Recurrent bladder stones
  • Bilateral hydronephrosis with renal functional impairment

questions.text: If a drug is known to be distributed into the total body water, what dose of the drug is needed to obtain an initial plasma level of 5 mg/L in a male patient weighing 70 kg?
questions.solution:
The drug dose needed to achieve initial plasma concentration is the loading dose, which is 210 mg in this case.

The equation for loading dose or the volume of the distribution equation can be used for calculation.
Loading Dose = Vd × Cp

Since the patient weighs 70 kg and 60% of his body weight is water, he has 42 L (70 L x 60%) of total body water.
Loading Dose = 42 L × 5 mg/L = 210 mg.

questions.text: A 45-year-old traffic policeman came to the Surgery OPD with tortuous swellings on his lower limb. He then presents 3 months later with physical examination findings as shown in the image. Choose the option that correctly represents his findings under the 2020 revised CEAP classification?
questions.solution:
The given image with fan-shaped telangiectasia over ankle or foot is characteristic of corona phlebectatica which is classified as C4c under CEAP guidelines.

Varicose veins - are tortuous dilatation of veins due to venous insufficiency. It commonly presents as lower limb swelling with a sensation of heaviness, burning, and aching over the affected area or whole limb.

Diagnosis is majorly done using duplex ultrasound and very rarely involves MR venography or intravenous ultrasound(IVUS).

Treatment is achieved using modalities such as compression, laser ablation, endothermal ablation, radiofrequency ablation, endovenous glue, ultrasound-guided foam sclerotherapy, open surgery, etc.

The clinical class of C4 under CEAP includes changes in skin and subcutaneous tissue secondary to chronic venous disease. It is further classified as,

  • C4a-Pigmentation or eczema
  • C4b-Lipodermatosclerosis or atrophie blanche
  • C4c-Corona phlebectatica

Atrophie blanche(C4b) is a localized white atrophic skin frequently surrounded by dilated capillaries and hyperpigmentation, usually seen around the ankle. This is a sign of severe chronic venous disease. The image below shows atrophie blanche.

Lipodermatosclerosis(C4b) is due to chronic inflammation and fibrosis leading to a tight, contracted, 'woody' leg. Can lead to contractures over the Achilles tendon and is a sign of severe chronic venous disease.

Corona phlebectatica(C4c) are fan-shaped patterns of telangiectasia over the ankle or foot. Considered an early sign of advanced disease.

 Recent 2020 update on the CEAP system includes the following changes -

  1. C2r for recurrent varicose veins
  2. C4c for Corona phlebectatica
  3. C6r for recurrent active venous ulcer.

questions.text: An epidemiologist is tasked with ensuring the disinfection of wells in a city to reduce the spread of water-borne illnesses. 30 grams of bleaching powder was required to disinfect 2275 liters of well water. When measuring the chlorine demand with the Horrocks apparatus for this well water, which cup would have shown the blue color after adding the indicator?
questions.solution:
Horrocks apparatus used to measure chlorine demand of water. The 3rd cup would have shown a blue color for it to require 30 grams of bleaching powder to disinfect 2275 liters of well water.

Since 2275/455=5, the amount of bleaching powder required to disinfect 455 liters of water is 30/5=6 grams

To calculate the dose of bleaching required to disinfect 455 liters of water, the formula is (n×2), We know the dose required, and we have to calculate 'n' (n represents the position of the cup which was first to show the color).

6=n×2, therefore n=3.

The third cup would have turned blue upon adding the indicator.

Related Pearl: Horrock’s Apparatus

  • Horrock’s Apparatus is used to estimate the chlorine demand of water.
  • This is widely used in the disinfection of wells to find out how much bleaching powder is required.
  • Contents of this water-testing apparatus:
    • 6 white cups of 200 ml each and one black cup with a circular mark
    • 2 metal spoons (each holds 2g of bleaching powder)
    • 7 glass stirring rods and 1 special pipette
    • Two droppers
    • Starch-iodide indicator solution
  • Procedure:
    • Use 2g of bleaching powder to create a thin paste in the black cup. It is now called the Chlorine stock solution.
    • The six white cups are filled with the water to be tested
    • Add one drop of the stock solution to the 1st cup, two drops to the 2nd cup, three drops to the 3rd cup, and so on till adding six drops to the 6th cup.
    • Stir the cups and wait for half an hour.
    • Add 3 drops of starch-iodide indicator to each cup
    • Development of blue color in the apparatus indicates free residual chlorine. 
    • The first cup which develops this color gives an estimate of the amount of bleaching powder needed to disinfect 455 Litres of the sample water.
  • Chlorine demand or the dose of bleaching powder required is given by (n x 2) g for 455 liters of water, i.e., (n x 2) g of bleaching powder is required to disinfect 455 liters of water. Here, n represents the position of the cup (1, 2, 3, etc.) that was first to show a distinct blue color.

questions.text: A woman with a deformed nasal tip is set to undergo an augmentation rhinoplasty. The plastic surgeon is performing the procedure using an autologous auricular graft. Images A and B show the donor and recipient sites, respectively. What type of tissue is the structure that is being harvested during the procedure?
questions.solution:
The structure that is being harvested for the rhinoplasty procedure is a part of the auricular cartilage. It is a type of elastic cartilage.

Elastic cartilage, like hyaline cartilage, contains individual or small groups of chondrocytes that are surrounded by type II collagen fibrils. However, it differs from hyaline cartilage in that, much of the interterritorial matrix consists of fine yellow elastic fibers containing elastin protein.

Microscopic fidings of elastic cartilage:

  • Chondrocytes within lacunae
  • Elastic fibers in the matrix
  • Perichondrium with outer fibrous layer and the inner cellular layer

questions.text: A female patient presents with fever, odynophagia, and trismus. Her oral cavity examination appears as shown in the image given below. She was diagnosed with a peritonsillar abscess. Where does the pus usually get collected in this condition?

choices.text: Between the alar fascia and the prevertebral fascia
Between the capsule of tonsil and the superior constrictor muscle
Between the alar fascia and the superior constrictor muscle
Between the capsule of tonsil and the inferior constrictor muscle

questions.solution:
The site of collection of pus in quinsy/ peritonsillar abscess is between the capsule of the tonsil and the superior constrictor muscle.

Peritonsillar abscess or quinsy is a collection of pus in the peritonsillar space which lies between the capsule of the tonsil and the superior constrictor muscle. It usually follows an episode of acute tonsillitis when the crypta magna gets infected and gets sealed off. An intratonsillar abscess then forms which then bursts through the capsule to reach the peritonsillar space.

The illustration given below shows structures forming a tonsillar bed.

It presents with marked odynophagia such that the patient cannot even swallow his saliva which dribbles from the angle of his mouth. The patient is usually dehydrated. Other features include a muffled and thick speech, often called a hot potato voice, sore throat, ipsilateral otalgia, torticollis, and fever.

On examination, the tonsil, pillars, and soft palate are congested and enlarged. The uvula is congested and edematous and pushed to the opposite side. Mucopus covering the tonsil is seen. Jugulodigastric lymph nodes are enlarged and tender.

CECT, submandibular ultrasonography, and MRI are better suited for visualizing the abscess and its extent. Submandibular ultrasonography is also helpful for incision and drainage.

Management of peritonsillar abscess:

  • Hospitalization
  • Intravenous fluids to address dehydration
  • High-dose intravenous antibiotics to cover aerobes and anaerobes
  • Analgesics for pain relief
  • Drainage by needle aspiration or incision and drainage
  • Tonsillectomy when there is airway obstruction or recurrence.

Incision and drainage of the abscess at the point of the maximum bulge above the upper pole of the tonsil or just lateral to the point of junction of the anterior pillar with a line drawn through the base of the uvula.

The image given below shows the site of the incision in the peritonsillar abscess.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presented with a lacerated wound over the hand due to an accidental injury from a soiled & rusted knife. You decide to give him equine antitoxin as human antitoxin immunoglobulin was not available at the hospital. What standard dose of equine antitoxin would you use in this case?
questions.solution:
The standard dose of Equine antitoxin(anti-tetanus serum/ATS) is 1500 IU.

The standard dose of Human antitoxin(human tetanus hyper-immunoglobulin/TIG) is 250 IU. If this not available, equine antitoxin can be used.

questions.text: A child presents with hepatitis and progressive neurological degeneration. A slit-lamp examination of a patient showed the following picture. Which of the following is a biological amine derivative that will be decreased in the urine?
questions.solution:
The image depicts the Kayser–Fleischer ring, which is seen in Wilson's disease. 3-methyl-histidine, a derivative of histidine is found to be unusually low in Wilson's disease.

Wilson's disease is an autosomal recessive disorder. The abnormal gene for Wilson's disease is present on the long arm of chromosome 13 (13q14.3). It encodes ATP7B which is responsible for biliary copper excretion and for the incorporation of copper into ceruloplasmin, a glycoprotein. In Wilson's, copper is not incorporated into ceruloplasmin, which decreases ceruloplasmin half-life and hence decreased ceruloplasmin levels (<20 mg/dL) are seen in the serum.

Clinical features of Wilson disease:

  • Hepatomegaly (with or without splenomegaly)
  • Acute/subacute/chronic hepatitis
  • Cirrhosis, ascites, portal hypertension
  • Tremor, dystonia, parkinsonism, behavioral, and psychiatric changes
  • Coomb's negative hemolytic anemia (due to large amounts of copper released from damaged hepatocytes)
  • Renal Fanconi syndrome
  • Endocrinopathies
  • Ophthalmic characteristics:
    • Deposition of copper in the posterior capsule of the lens resulting in sunflower cataract
    • Kayser-Fleischer ring 

Kayser-Fleischer (KF) ring:

  • KF ring is a golden-brown ring formed due to the deposition of copper in Descemet’s membrane of the cornea
  • Characteristically observed in Wilson's disease but is not pathognomonic
  • Does not interfere with vision
  • Present in almost all patients of Wilson's disease with neurological/psychiatric symptoms
  • Present only in 30–50% of patients diagnosed in the hepatic or presymptomatic state, therefore the absence of KF rings does not exclude the diagnosis of Wilson's disease

questions.text: An elderly male who is a known hypertensive presented with pain and swelling in his great toe. The aspirated synovial contents visualized under polarized light microscopy showed negatively birefringent monosodium urate crystals. What is the antihypertensive that is preferred in such patients?
questions.solution:
Losartan is the preferred antihypertensive in patients having gout, because of its uricosuric action.

Losartan inhibits active sites for reabsorption and secretion in the proximal renal tubule, hence the net reabsorption of uric acid in the proximal tubule is decreased. Similarly, calcium channel blockers like amlodipine and diltiazem are found to lower the risk of gout.

Gout is a hyperuricemic metabolic condition, typically manifested by episodic inflammatory arthritis due to crystal formation and deposition of monosodium urate (MSU) crystals within the joints and connective tissue.

Acute recurrent gout flare is characterized by painful, warm, red, tender, and substantially swollen joints. The metatarsophalangeal joint of the first toe is involved in 70–90% of cases (podagra), followed by tarsal joints, ankles, and knees. Triggers of gout flares include purine-rich food, alcohol, diuretic use, local trauma, and medical illnesses such as congestive heart failure and respiratory hypoxic conditions.

Diagnosis is made by synovial fluid examination, which may show needle-shaped monosodium urate crystals. These crystals show bright, negative birefringence under polarized light. WBC count may be increased in synovial fluid. Serum uric acid level is usually elevated in chronic gout patients, but it may remain normal or low during acute attacks, because of the uricosuric property of inflammatory cytokines.

Management of acute gout includes the application of ice packs, rest, NSAIDS, colchicine, and glucocorticoids. In patients with chronic hyperuricemia urate-lowering agents like xanthine oxidase inhibitors(eg. allopurinol and febuxostat) or uricosuric drugs (e.g. probenecid) can be used.

Other options-

Options A and D: Angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors like captopril are associated with an increased risk of incident gout among patients with hypertension. β blockers such as propranolol, atenolol, metoprolol, timolol, and alprenolol, also have been shown to increase serum uric acid levels. 

Option B: Hydrochlorothiazides inhibit renal Ca2+ excretion causing hypercalcemia and may precipitate gout. Hence, hydrochlorothiazides are not used to treat hypertension in gout patients.

questions.text:
A 30-year-old male presented with a suicidal overdose of a drug. The patient is flabby and comatose with shallow failing respiration. BP is 80/40 mmHg and there is a lesion on the right ankle as shown below. The likely mode of treatment for this poisoning would include which of the following?

 

  1. Initial resuscitation is by the Scandinavian technique.
  2. Charcoal hemoperfusion is not helpful in this condition.
  3. Flumazenil is a non-specific effective antidote for this drug. 
  4. CNS stimulants can be used to revoke this condition. 
  5. Forced alkaline diuresis the most specific and sensitive treatment for this condition.
questions.solution:
The figure shows bullous eruptions. This history and clinical findings are suggestive of phenobarbitone poisoning. The correct answer with regards to the treatment would include - 1 and 5 only.

Acute Barbiturate poisoning:

Manifestations are due to excessive CNS depression—

  • Patient is flabby and comatose with shallow and failing respiration
  • Fall in BP and cardiovascular collapse
  • Renal shut down
  • Pulmonary complications
  • Bullous eruptions

The lethal dose depends on lipid solubility.

  • It is 2–3 g for the more lipid-soluble agents (short-acting barbiturates)
  • 5–10 g for less lipid-soluble phenobarbitone

Treatment

  • Gastric lavage
  • Scandinavian method: supportive measures such as patent airway, assisted respiration, oxygen, maintenance of blood volume by fluid infusion  and use of vasopressors—dopamine may be preferred for its renal vasodilating action.
  • Alkaline diuresis: with sodium bicarbonate 1 mEq/kg IV with or without mannitol is helpful only in the case of long acting barbiturates which are eliminated primarily by renal excretion.
  • Haemodialysis and Charcoal hemoperfusion. 
  • CNS stimulants are to be avoided. 

NOTE: There is no specific antidote for barbiturates.

questions.text: A 40-year-old P2L2 woman presents to your office with foul-smelling bloody discharge per vaginum. Her CECT reports show a 3.5 x 4 cm ulceroproliferative mass in the cervix invading the parametrium, with para-aortic node involvement. What is the line of management for this case?

choices.text: Radical hysterectomy + Pelvic lymph node dissection

questions.solution:
The patient has carcinoma cervix, which is at stage IIIC2 due to para-aortic node involvement. As per FIGO 2018 guidelines, the treatment for this stage is chemoradiation.

Chemoradiation can improve survival rates. It allows for remission in certain cases or a reduction in morbidity.

Other options:

Pelvic exenteration may be considered in stage IVA. 

Surgical treatment is considered in the early stages of the disease. Radical hysterectomy is preferred in stages IB1, IB2, and a few cases of IIA.

Related Pearl: Staging of Carcinoma Cervix

Stage I - limited to the cervix

  • A: Microscopic lesion
    • A1 - stromal invasion <3mm depth
    • A2 - a stromal invasion of ≥3 and <5mm depth
  • B: Macroscopic lesion
    • B1 - stromal invasion ≥5mm depth & tumor size <2cm 
    • B2 - tumor size ≥2cm to <4cm 
    • B3 - tumor size ≥4cm 

Stage II - involves upper 2/3 of vagina

  • A: Extends to the upper two-thirds of the vagina without parametrial involvement
    • A1 - tumor size <4cm 
    • A2 - tumor size ≥4cm 
  • B: Extends to parametrium but not upto the pelvic wall.

Stage III - spreads to lower 1/3 of vagina

  • A: Extends to lower 1/3 of the vagina
  • B: Extends to the pelvic wall (hydronephrosis/non-functioning kidney)
  • C: Involvement of the pelvic and/or para-aortic lymph nodes, irrespective of the tumor size and extent
    • C1: pelvic lymph node involved
    • C2: para-aortic lymph node involved

Stage IV - metastasis

  • A: Bladder/bowel involvement (adjacent pelvic organs)
  • B: Distant metastasis

Note: The involvement of vascular/lymphatic spaces does not change the staging. The lateral extent of the lesion is no longer considered.

Stage IIIB is the most common stage of presentation.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man presented with a slowly progressive swelling and pain in the middle of his right leg. On X-ray, multiple sharply demarcated radiolucent lesions are seen in the tibial diaphysis. Microscopic examination of a biopsied specimen reveals epithelial cells in a fibrous stroma. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Among the given tumors, adamantinoma is the most probable diagnosis based on the above-given clinical scenario.

Adamantinoma is a rare tumor of the diaphysis and presents commonly with pain. It usually presents in the 2nd or 3rd decade and arises from the epithelial cells. The most common site for adamantinoma is the tibia but it may also involve the ipsilateral fibula.

Radiological examination shows multiple sharply demarcated radiolucent lesions in the tibial diaphysis and a honeycomb/soap bubble appearance. Histology shows epithelial basaloid cell islands in a fibrous stroma.

Complete excision of the tumor is the treatment of choice.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman gave birth to a child with the features shown in the given image. On examination, the child had brittle bones, and x-ray scans revealed stippled epiphyses. Which of the following drugs is most likely to be implicated in causing this teratogenic condition?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a depressed nasal bridge (saddle nose). This image along with the stippling of bone epiphyses points to fetal warfarin syndrome or warfarin embryopathy. 

Features:

  • Repeated abortions
  • CNS abnormalities
  • Depressed nasal bridge/absent nasal bone/saddle nose at birth
  • Bleeding diathesis at birth
  • Growth retardation - hypoplasia of nose, eye sockets, and long bones with stippling of epiphyses 

Anticoagulation in pregnancy:

  • Warfarin: Although safe for the mother, it can lead to warfarin embryopathy, miscarriage, IUGR, and stillbirths.
  • Heparin: It is safe for the fetus but is less effective than warfarin.
  • LMWH: It is inadequate, and ACOG does not recommend its use in pregnant women with prosthetic heart valves.

Period of gestation

Anticoagulant

Till 12 completed weeks

LMWH or UFH

13 to 36 weeks

Warfarin

36 weeks to 6 hours before delivery

LMWH or UFH

6 hours after vaginal and 24 hours after cesarian section

LMWH or UFH (ACOG recommendation)

If delivery occurs while the anticoagulant is still effective, and excessive bleeding happens, then protamine sulfate is given intravenously. 

Anticoagulation of pregnant women:

  • The patient taking warfarin should discontinue it as soon as pregnancy is diagnosed and replace it with heparin 5,000 units twice daily subcutaneously up to the 12th week of gestation. 
  • Heparin is then replaced by a warfarin tablet of 3 mg daily to be taken at the same time each day and continued up to 36 weeks in patients with a high risk of thrombosis.
  • Thereafter, warfarin is replaced by heparin, which is discontinued 6 hours just before delivery.
  • Heparin (unfractionated or LMWH) is restarted 6 hours after vaginal delivery and 24 hours after the cesarean section.
  • Unfractionated heparin (UFH), LMWH, and warfarin therapy are not contraindicated in breastfeeding.

questions.text:
A 19-year-old male comes to the emergency department with complaints of severe colicky pain in the right iliac fossa, fever, and vomiting. On examination, there was tenderness at McBurney’s point, and guarding was present. He was diagnosed by ultrasound and posted for open surgery. Which of the following nerves are to be identified while opening the abdominal cavity?

i. Spinal nerve T11
ii. Spinal nerve T10
iii. Spinal nerve T 12
iv. Ilioinguinal nerve
v. Iliohypogastric nerve
vi. Obturator nerve
questions.solution:
The case stem suggests the patient is suffering from acute appendicitis and is taken up for an open appendectomy.

The nerves to be taken care of so as to not injure while open the abdominal cavity via the transverse right lower quadrant incision (Lanz) are Spinal nerves-T11, T12, Ilioinguinal and Iliohypogastric nerves.

The iliohypogastric nerve is found 2.5cm above the superficial inguinal ring.
The terminal part of the ilioinguinal nerve comes out from the superficial inguinal ring and goes into the external spermatic fascia.
The ilioinguinal and iliohypogastric nerves do not enter the rectus sheath and are found in the cutaneous planes.

The T11 and T12 nerves supply the lower part of the abdomen, below the umbilicus. T10 supplies around the umbilicus and hence is not included in this answer.

questions.text:
A young girl, who recently recovered from COVID-19, presents with fever, abdominal pain and rashes for 4 days. On examination, strawberry tongue is observed and cervical nodes are found to be enlarged bilaterally. What is the likely diagnosis?

HR: 110/min

BP: 80/60 mm Hg

RR: 20/min

CRP: 10 mg/L

ESR: 76mm/hr.
questions.solution:
This is a case of multisystem inflammatory syndrome in children (MIS-C), associated with COVID-19 infection.

Diagnostic criteria for MIS-C:

Children and adolescents 0–18 years of age with fever ≥3 days

AND two of these:

  • Rash or bilateral non-purulent conjunctivitis or mucocutaneous inflammation signs (palmoplantar erythema, lip hyperemia, periorbital erythema and edema, strawberry tongue, and malar erythema)
  • Hypotension or shock.
  • Features of myocardial dysfunction, pericarditis, valvulitis, or coronary abnormalities (including ECHO findings or elevated Troponin/NT-proBNP)
  • Evidence of coagulopathy (PT, PTT, elevated D-Dimers)
  • Acute gastrointestinal problems (diarrhoea, vomiting, or abdominal pain)

AND

Elevated ESR(>40 mm), C-reactive protein (>5 mg/L), or procalcitonin.

AND

No other obvious microbial cause of inflammation including bacterial sepsis, staphylococcal or streptococcal shock syndromes.

AND

Evidence of COVID-19 (RT-PCR, antigen test, or serology positive), or likely contact with patients with COVID-19.

Types of MIS-C:

  • MIS-C with shock/multi-organ dysfunction
  • Kawasaki phenotype
  • MIS-C without shock

MIS-C is treated with IV methylprednisolone. The dose can be increased in patients with shock. If the condition does not improve for 48-72 hours, specialists can be consulted for the addition of biologicals to the treatment regimen.

questions.text: Match the gross structure with its histology.
questions.solution:
The given histological image is of transitional epithelium with a star-shaped appearance, which is a feature of the ureter. In the gross image provided, the structure labelled as 1 is the ureter, specifically the left ureter. 

The other structures marked are:

2: Inferior mesenteric artery

3: Descending colon 

4: Femoral cutaneous nerve 

Histology of ureter:

It has 3 layers- the innermost mucous membrane, the middle smooth muscle layer and the outer connective tissue layer.

The innermost mucous membrane is made of transitional epithelium. It is 4-5 cell layers thick with an underlying lamina propria. The mucosa is thrown into longitudinal folds which gives the lumen a star-shaped appearance. These folds vanish when the ureter is distended. 

The middle smooth muscle layer consists of an upper 2/3rd of inner longitudinal and outer circular fibres and a lower 1/3rd- of extra outer longitudinal muscle layer. The muscle coat has 2 layers in the upper 2/3rd and 3 layers in the lower 1/3rd, which may not be distinctly differentiated from each other. 

The outer connective tissue layer, also called the tunica adventitia contains blood vessels, nerves, lymphatics and fat cells. 

Ureters are narrow muscular tubes that begin from the renal pelvis and extend up to the urinary bladder. They are about 25cm long, and 3mm thick with 5 constrictions along their length. They are constricted at the pelvic-ureteric junction, the brim of the lesser pelvis, the crossing of the ureter by ductus deferens or broad ligament of the uterus, during their oblique passage through the bladder wall and at the opening in the lateral angle of the trigone.

questions.text: A 56-year-old diabetic patient has an episode of seizure. He had a headache for 2 days and two episodes of vomiting. He had a right earache with discharge one week ago. He is drowsy, and has nystagmus and ataxia. A brain abscess is suspected. Which of the following is the next best step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
The patient's clinical picture is suggestive of a brain abscess. The next best step in the management of this patient is to perform a neuroimaging study and MRI brain is superior to CT in diagnosing brain abscesses.

A brain abscess is a focal, suppurative infection within the brain parenchyma, typically surrounded by a vascularized capsule. The term cerebritis describes a nonencapsulated brain abscess.

The most common presenting symptom of a brain abscess is headache, which is a dull aching pain that progressively worsens and becomes refractory to therapy. Fever, headache, and focal neurological deficits from the classic triad of brain abscess are present in only half the patients. The expanding brain abscess increases the intracranial pressure which typically presents as the Cushing's triad - bradycardia, irregular respiration, and increased blood pressure with widened pulse pressure. 

This patient's ataxia and nystagmus suggest a cerebellar involvement. Further, this patient has a history of otitis media (earache and discharge) which is the most common source of infection for a cerebellar brain abscess.

MRI Brain is superior to diagnosing a brain abscess when compared to a CT scan, in evaluating abscesses in the posterior fossa. MRI is also superior to CT in the early cerebritis stage of development of brain abscess.

On contrast-enhanced T1-weighted MRI, a mature brain abscess has a capsule that enhances surrounding a hypointense center. It is surrounded by a hypointense area of edema. On T2-weighted MRI, there is a hyperintense central area of pus surrounded by a well-defined hypointense capsule and a hyperintense surrounding area of edema.

In patients with signs of increased intracranial pressure, lumbar puncture is contraindicated as it increases the risk of herniation. 

MRI Venography is used to confirm the diagnosis of septic thrombophlebitis of cerebral venous sinuses. The patients present similarly with fever, headache, signs of raised ICP, and focal neurological lesions. However, the next best step in the management of this patient even if septic venous thrombosis is suspected, is an MRI brain which shows an absent flow void within the affected venous sinus. This is further confirmed by MRI venography, CT angiogram, or the venous phase of cerebral angiography.

questions.text:
The oral exam of an unvaccinated 7-year-old with fever and sore throat appears as below. Attempts to remove this pseudomembranous substance result in bleeding. A rapid strep test on a throat swab is negative. He has a documented history of allergy to penicillin and cephalosporins. Which of the following statements is/ are true about the anti-microbial drug he should be started on?
  1. It is a prototype drug for the macrolide group.
  2. It should be always administered on empty stomach for better bio-availability. 
  3. Efflux and methylase production mechanisms are chiefly responsible for resistance in the drug. 
  4. It has a therapeutic paradox in the treatment of diabetic gastroparesis.
  5. Its dose needs to be altered in patients with renal failure.
questions.solution:
This is a classic clinical description and oral examination findings of a patient with diphtheria. Diphtheria is principally treated using Penicillin. In the case of penicillin resistance or allergy, erythromycin is the preferred agent. The correct statements are 1, 3, and 4. 

Erythromycin is a macrolide antibiotic. It is a bacteriostatic agent that inhibits protein synthesis by binding reversibly to 50S ribosomal subunits of sensitive microorganisms.

It is commonly used for the treatment of gram-positive infections. Erythromycin is the drug of choice in diphtheria when a patient is allergic to penicillin. Erythromycin is also used for the treatment of atypical pneumonia. It is given for prophylaxis of endocarditis and rheumatic fever in people with valvular heart disease and allergic to penicillin respectively. Azithromycin is still preferred over erythromycin.

Food and gastric acid both affect erythromycin absorption and bio-availability. Hence, it is always given as an enteric-coated formulation. The drug can be taken both before food and after food, but the latter is preferred. Erythromycin activity is increased to several-fold in an alkaline medium which can be achieved after food when stomach acid is neutralized by food and alkaline chyme begins to form. Dose adjustment is not necessary for patients with renal failure as it is excreted in bile.

It can cross the placenta and affect the fetus and is preferably avoided in pregnancy.  Erythromycin inhibits the CYP450 enzyme system and thus inhibits the metabolism of theophylline, warfarin, cyclosporine, and methylprednisolone, thereby leading to their toxicity. Erythromycin increases serum concentrations of oral digoxin by increasing its bioavailability. 

Erythromycin stimulates GI motility by acting on motilin receptors and causes GI disturbances in the form of diarrhea, nausea, and vomiting. This therapeutic paradox has led to Erythromycin's off-label use as a prokinetic agent in the intensive care setting and in patients with diabetic gastroparesis and clearence of bezoars. 

Resistance to Erythromycin:

Resistance to erythromycin is mediated by plasmids. There are three mechanisms involved in the development of resistance. These include:

  1. Active efflux
  2. Production of esterases that hydrolyze macrolide by Enterobacteriaceae. 
  3. Modification of the ribosomal binding site (chromosomal mutation or constitutive methylase production)

Efflux and methylase production mechanisms are chiefly responsible for resistance in the drug. Cross-resistance is also seen with other macrolides. The production of Methylase is responsible for resistance to Streptogramin B and Clindamycin. This is collectively called - MLS type B resistance (Macrolides, Lincosamides, Streptogramin-B).
